debateinfo.title: FURTHER 1998 BUDGET MEASURES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (SOCIAL SECURITY) BILL 1999

subdebate.1.para: Consideration resumed from 20 September.

talk.start.para: âThe committee is considering the Further 1998 Budget Measures Legislation Amendment (Social Security) Bill 1999 and amendments (1) to (7) and (9) to (32) on sheet 1391 moved on behalf of the opposition by Senator Evans. The question is that the amendments be agreed to.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âI wish to table a replacement revised supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the government amendments and request for amendments to be moved to the bill. The memorandum was circulated in the chamber on 22 September.

âA sheet of revisions to amendmentsâsheet 1546âhas been circulated in the chamber. I seek leave to vary my amendments in accordance with the details on that sheet to bring them into line with the government's requests and amendments that have already been agreed to.

speech.para: Leave granted.

Schedule 2, item 53, page 32 (line 28), omit "or the relevant pension payday".

Schedule 2, item 53, heading to section 1188F, page 33 (lines 14 and 15), omit ": people not covered by section 1188D ".

Schedule 2, item 53, page 38 (lines 4 and 5), omit "or pension ".

talk.start.para: âby leaveâI move:

speech.para: That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:
(R10) Schedule 2, item 53, omit subsection 1188E(1), substitute:
(1) This section applies in respect of payment periods beginning on or after 20 March 1999 and not later than 19 March 2000.

When we were last considering this group of amendments I was on my feet, so I might just finish off my remarks in support of those amendments. This is the amendment to do with the government's attempt to reduce the total income paid to CDEP recipients who are also recipients of the parenting payment (single). I outlined the basic case last timeâI do not want to bore the chamber by going on too muchâbut I want to come to the key point, and that is that I think the government's measure is one that seeks to reduce the income to 4,000 sole parents and, in large part, to Aboriginal sole parents who choose to work on CDEP projects as well. The measure would effectively reduce their income by up to $100 a fortnight and we think that is a measure that cannot be justified.

I know that there has been some reliance on the Spicer report into CDEP in terms of equalising conditions, but on my reading of the report he did not actually recommend this measure. I think what is more important is that we look at the key issue of the impact on recipients. The chamber would be aware that single sole parents in Aboriginal communities are among the most disadvantaged people in our society. A recent research paper by Anne Daly on the plight of indigenous sole parents and other indigenous families highlighted that indigenous sole parents make up 40 per cent of all indigenous families with children under 15. They support more children than non-indigenous sole parents, often without further income support because of informal or foster care arrangements.

Twenty-five per cent of indigenous sole parents care for foster children compared with 14 per cent for indigenous couples and just 9 per cent for non-indigenous sole parents. They have lower levels of education and are less likely to be in employment compared with other indigenous families and non-indigenous sole parents. Forty-three per cent of non-indigenous sole parents are in employment compared with just 25 per cent of indigenous sole parents. On average, they have lower family incomes compared with indigenous couple families and non-indigenous sole parents, while supporting more children.

So we are talking about some of the most disadvantaged people in society supporting children. The effect of the government's measure is, as I say, to reduce their income by $100 a fortnightâsometimes a bit more, sometimes a bit lessâall in the guise of bringing conditions into line. We do not think this taking everyone down to the lowest common denominator is justifiableâcertainly not in this case. I know the minister also relied on the support of ATSIC and I understand that they have supported the measure on the basis of the package presented to them by government, which has other beneficial measures that I have conceded in terms of CDEP for Aboriginal people. But this chamber has to make the decision whether this measure is one that it wishes to support. I do not think there has been a cogent argument advanced for the chamber to take from these 4,000 highly disadvantaged people the income support that we are currently providing. We took that view when dealing with the youth disability allowance supplement the other day. I think that was the correct decision by the committee and I hope we will make the same decision here.

While bringing CDEP recipients into some sort of common arrangement, this does discriminate against Aboriginal people on CDEP in the sense that they lose their free income area as compared with other parenting payment (single) recipients. I do not think the government's justification is warranted. As I say, these are some of the most disadvantaged people in our society caring for children. I do not think we ought to be reducing the already fairly meagre income that they receive without a much better case being presented by the government.

talk.start.para: âThis is probably one of the more substantial measures in the bill in terms of the number of people potentially affected. As often happens in this type of legislation, it presents the committee with a bit of a cleft stick situation. There is a significant positive measure contained in this schedule which enables CDEP recipients to get access to the social security add-ons such as rent assistance, telephone allowance, the health care card, et cetera, that other social security recipients receive. But, as Senator Evans has outlined and as these opposition amendments seek to address, the schedule also leads to a reduction in the overall total income for a significant number of sole parent pensioners or parenting payment (single) recipientsâaround 4,000 according to Senator Evans. If the minister believes that figure is incorrect, I would encourage her to indicate it. Those 4,000 parenting payment (single) recipients will be up to $100 a week worse off, which is not an insignificant amount of money for anybody, let alone somebody on a low income.

speech.para: Nonetheless, it is a situation where one would suspect the government's attitude is to present this as a package and put it as an `all or nothing' approach, which would mean that beneficial measures which would also make a significant difference may be lost. Rent assistance can be quite a significant payment and a number of people would miss out on that positive measureâI am not sure of the total number of people affected by that; I am sure the minister could outline it. So it pits one group against another, which is a far from ideal situation. But that is what we are faced with, so that is what we have to address.

I have a couple of questions and I would be interested to hear the answers from the minister, because they concern something I have been giving consideration to in listening to the arguments that have been put forward. Firstly, can the minister confirm the number of parenting payment (single) recipients that will be affected by the measureâwhether it is 4,000? Secondly, what on average is the total income of those people currently in receipt of the maximum CDEP payment and parenting payment on top of that? And, thirdly, can the minister confirm whether that does lead to a cut of around $100 a week?

I have just had circulated an amendment which is not on the running sheet. I take on board the minister's comment about late circulation of amendments in social security legislation, but these things happen sometimes. I foreshadow this amendmentâI may or may not proceed with itâwhich is an attempt at a grandfathering amendment to ensure that those who are currently under this arrangement would not be disadvantaged whilst meeting the long-term aims of the government of having a uniform approach to income treatment for CDEP recipients. This may be a way through the situation that we are faced with.

Whilst I understand and support the concerns put forward by Senator Evans, I am also concerned that the positive measure contained in this schedule will be lost, which is an outcome I am not keen to see. I cannot recall if I have asked this before, but I ask if the minister could indicate the origin of this particular measure to do with sole parentsâwhether it was contained in the Spicer report along with the other aspects that are part of this schedule.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âI understand that the opposition amendments Nos 1 to 7 purport to reverse the government's proposal in relation to lone parents. If the opposition amendments were to succeed, the cost would be $6.102 million in 1999-2000, $14.92 million in 2000-01 and $14.92 million in 2001-02, totalling $35.943 million over four years. Four thousand lone parents would retain their current entitlements as a result of the amendments. On average, the loss would be $80 per fortnightânot $100 per week which I think is what Senator Bartlett said.

speech.para: I know that ATSIC has made it very clear that there is some resentment in communities that there is double-dipping by a protected class of people. Therefore, I fear that the attempt at a solution by Senator Bartlett would not resolve that problem, which is that it is seen as unfair that some people get two payments when others doing the same work do not. For my part, I am more concerned about the fact that women are often not considered eligible or not encouraged to be part of the CDEP projects when there are other people who are seen as more needy in the community in terms of income support. The CDEP money goes to those who have not already got income support, and one can understand the thinking behind that.

Senator Evans might like to take on board the fact that my advice is that opposition amendments Nos 9 to 32 appear to accidentallyâI say `accidentally'; I presume it is not deliberateâreverse the government's proposal to commence the CDEP add-ons measure with effect from 20 March. That is, they conflict with our requests Nos 1, 2 and 3 which set the new commencement date, and requests Nos 2 and 3 were already agreed to by the committee on Monday. I say that the revised commencement proposed by the opposition appears to be accidental because they did not announce such an intention during the debate at the second reading stage, and it appears to be an accidental result of attempting to remove all reference to pensions.
Senator Chris Evans interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âI am just giving you the opportunity to hear both, Senator Evans. In doing so, your amendments, in conjunction with opposition amendment No. 8, which we will come to shortly, appear to accidentally deprive pensioners of the entitlement to new CDEP participation. But I understand it also means that the net result would be that the scheme would come into effect on 20 September, which of course was the original date. But I understand that probably your drafting is defective. I do not think you mean that. I do not quite know how you want to resolve that now, but you would need time to take advice, I would think.

âI appreciate that the minister is trying to be helpful. My understanding of the drafting advice was that the revisions that I moved this morning overcame those difficulties and made them consistent with your amendments. I am not sure whether you are saying that the revisions that we just moved by leave do not do that or whether you are operating on the basis of the impact that would have occurred if we had proceeded yesterday. It would be helpful if you could clarify that.

speech.para: There is no intention to change any of your arrangements in relation to the timing of benefits. We tried to restrict the debate on this occasion to this question of the CDEP entitlements of recipients of parenting payment (single), so there is no intention to do that. I think you are aware that the complicated drafting required was requested last night to try to make sure that we had consistency between the government's amendments, which relate to the timing issues, and our policy intent, which is to retain that payment. As I say, I am not sure whether you are saying that the original draft failed to achieve that or whether this morning's revised amendments fail to achieve that. Perhaps you could clarify that. But I certainly put on record there is no intention to change any of those entitlements. It was purely our intention yesterday to single out this area for question and debate and acceptance of what we saw as a necessary change to the timing arrangements because of the delay in the passage of the bill.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âMr Chairman, I am waiting to receive advice on the opposition's amendments. I do not know whether they achieve a solution to the problem or not. I do not know how we can proceed at this minute without that advice. It is a pretty significant defect if it remains a defect. For example, we would have a great problem with the administration of Centrelink as a purely mechanistic issue which is not to be swept aside. It would mean that some of Centrelink's operations would require untested manual processes and things like that. I am sure you do not want that.

âMr Chairman, I just indicated to the minister that that was not the intention. Also, advisers from the opposition met with her advisers yesterday evening to try to make sure that we did not have any unintended consequences and that we had an agreement that would isolate out this issue. So I do not think there is any need for us to debate this, other than the fact that we need to get it right. There are, though, substantive policy issues in debate here that we could continue with while we work out whether or not we have got the technical amendments on timing correct or not.

speech.para: I am interested in Senator Bartlett's contribution. I am not sure what his position is as a result of that, but I know he asked the minister a range of questions which he wanted answered, some of which I think she responded to. I am happy to have this debate about where we are going in terms of the principal issues, and we can come back to whether we have achieved technically what we thought we were going to achieve. But, as I say, I would be interested in hearing from Senator Bartlett what he intends to do. Is he proceed ing with this amendment that I have recently received, No. 55, or is this a separate issue?

talk.start.para: âThe amendment which is on sheet 1547âwhich I have just had circulatedâis, as indicated by my drafting advice, a successful attempt at a grandfathering protection so that the new arrangements for parenting payment (single) would not apply to those who are currently in receipt of that payment but only to future recipients, so that people who have structured their lives around the level of payment they are currently receiving will not have to make the significant adjustment to the $80 a fortnight drop in income which will occur overnight when the measure comes into placeâI think 20 March is now the date aimed at. My amendment attempts to try to find a way through the difficulty that is presented here in terms of not putting at risk the positive aspects that are contained within the schedule, which is, I suspect, what may otherwise occur.

speech.para: One of the questions I asked the ministerâI do not think she answered, unless I was temporarily distractedâwas whether or not this measure relating to sole parents was contained as a recommendation in the Spicer report. Another issue on which I would be interested in the minister's comments is in relation to the bill as a whole. There are a number of other measures which we have not got to yet in other schedules, some of which, without pre-empting the views of the chamber, may well end up being opposed and removed. One of the issues that ATSIC have raised with me is the issue of the positive aspects of this measure contained in schedule 2 actually coming into being. One issue is in terms of the bill as a whole and whether, if the chamber makes other amendments, the government would be of a mind to hold up the bill because of changes that may be made to other schedules as well. An indication of the government's attitude to that would be helpful also.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âIn answer to Senator Bartlett's question about Mr Spicer, I am advised that Mr Spicer made it absolutely clear in his report that double dipping should be ended. Going back to the matters I was discussing with Senator Evans, perhaps I should go on, Senator Evans, to draw your attention to opposition amendment No. 8, because it has presumably unintended consequences, and the measures that we were discussing regarding amendments Nos 9 to 32 are consequent on the outcome of amendment No. 8.

speech.para: My advice is that if amendment No. 8âthe next one on the listâsucceeds, the CDEP supplement will be payable only to those on allowance type payments. Presumably, that is an unintended result, as you did not announce that during the second reading debate. This amendment and others consequential upon it should be opposed. The consequential amendments to be opposed on this basis are the opposition amendments on sheet 1391 and amendments Nos 9 to 32 inclusive. My concern is that you would effectively be removing the $20 amount for people on pensions. I do not suppose you meant to do that.

talk.start.para: âWhile Senator Evans is getting advice on that, I would certainly say that, from my reading of the amendments and the billâwhilst we are not actually debating opposition amendment No. 8, it is obviously linked to the ones we are debatingâit does appear to me that the minister's advice on her last comment is correct. As I understand it, if we knocked out that particular section, all pensionersâand there is a list of pensions there: widow pension, wife pension, disability support pension, age pension, any of theseâwould cease to be entitled to receive the CDEP participant supplement. That appears to me to be the consequence of that. That is something that I have concerns about because, as I understand it, the thrust of what we are debating here is simply the impact on parenting payment (single) recipients.

speech.para: I would like to make a point in response to comments made by the minister a couple of moments back in relation to women's participation in CDEP projects and how that may be affected by the various proposals that are being put around. I would have thought that the foreshadowed amendment of the Democrats to grandfather or to protect current recipients would not have an impact on the problem of women's participationâif it is a problemâbecause these people are already participants in CDEP and, regardless of whether this bill exists or not in its entirety, one would assume that they would continue to participate. The issue really is about the treatment of the income support payments for scheme participants into the future. The aims of my amendment are to not lead to an income drop for those who are already receiving particular incomes and to enable the future structure of the scheme to operate in the way that the government intends.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âI think Senator Bartlett is trying to do the right thing by women in those communities. But I think it would be pretty ineffectual, from my reading of remote indigenous communities, where the labour market is pretty inflexible. The only source of income for most people in communities is either welfare or CDEP. Those people currently employed under CDEP in a remote community, where there is only so much work and not much change in the potential work force, are going to continue to get the work, and the people who are excluded now are likely to continue to be excluded if they continue double dipping. I think that the amendment, whatever it might say, would result in those who are being discriminated againstâif you want to put it that wayânow because they are already in receipt of sole parent income support continuing to be discriminated against in terms of getting a job with CDEP.

speech.para: I share your concern about these people, but I think the quickest way to have them share in the dignity of employment in indigenous communities would be to put them on the same basis as everybody else in their community. The resentment that is occasioned by them having two sources of income where other people do not would be removed. They would be competing for a job on a much fairer basis with everybody else in their community. It is pretty well recognised by the indigenous communityâperhaps it was an unforseen consequence of some legislative effort years ago; I do not know the history of how it happenedâas grossly unfair to have one group of people in a small and close community treated so distinctly differently from everybody else when we are talking about the opportunity to have the dignity of a job.

talk.start.para: âI just want to address a couple of the issues. Firstly, I object to this claim of double dipping. I think that is a bit unfair.
âTwo sources of income.

âTwo sources of income, yes. These are the most disadvantaged people in AustraliaâAboriginal single parents supporting children. To accuse them of double dipping is an abuse of language and an unfair implication by use of that language. What we are saying is that these people receive, in addition, about $100 per fortnight for participating in work under the CDEP scheme to support their community. They receive the same single parenting payment that every other person receives. What they get by way of advantage for this alleged double dipping is $100 per fortnight in recognition of their sole parent status and their need to support their children.

speech.para: I understand what the minister is saying, but I think the language ought to be a bit more responsible. It is not double dipping; they are currently entitled, under the provisions of government legislation, to that income in recognition of their status. Senator Bartlett, you ought to recognise that. If there is such a problem with these people getting access to the work force, how come there are already 4,000 of them in this situation? There has been no evidence advanced for the propositions that the minister puts to us other than that there is some concern and women are being disadvantaged.
All I know is that these women will be disadvantaged, from the day you pass the government's proposition, by $100 a fort night. They regard that as a disadvantage to them and their children.

talk.start.para: âEighty.

âEightyâit depends on the number of children, as I understand your brief, Minister. As I said to you before, single sole parent Aboriginals have more dependent children than most sole parents. So we are talking about some of the most disadvantaged people in Australia.

speech.para: What we do know is that this government measure will reduce the income payable to them. Set against that, we have the government's arguments about a level playing field and some concern about relationships inside communities. On balance, what is more tangible? What is more real? What is more tangible and real to me is their capacity to support those children and the income support that they receive. For us to accept that we ought to reduce that, we would need to have a fairly tangible and cogent argument putâand I have not heard it yet.

I do not consider it double dipping. We have considered that those sole parents in Aboriginal communities who volunteer to be involved in CDEP deserve that sort of support. We may well make a judgment in the Senate that they do not deserve that support. That is fine; it is a judgment we will make. What I say, on behalf of the Labor opposition, is that we do not make that decision because we do not think it appropriate or fair. To suggest that somehow this is causing enormous problems and that women are being prevented from participating is proved false by the fact that you have 4,000 people clearly in this situation already.

There may well be difficulties. ATSIC may well have concerns about how that is operated. But I also note that there are other implications for ATSIC. Senator Bartlett has already hinted at what they may beâthat this is a take it or leave it package. ATSIC's view may well be that there are a range of beneficial measures contained in this bill, but they have been told, `Take it or leave it'. They have to support all the measures or nothing at all. I do not know that, but I suspect that is the case. I suspect that influences their view. I suspect that is now starting to influence the view of Senator Bartlett and the Democrats. Again, that is a political judgment for them.

If you look at this measure in isolationâwhich we need to doâand if you look at it from the perspective of those 4,000 single Aboriginal parents, there is a very real case to be answered. That is: why should they have their benefits reduced by a significant amount, reducing their capacity to care for their children because they will have much less income as a result of this measure?

I do not know about the grandfathering clause, Senator Bartlett. If you are not going to support us in opposing the government's measure, then I guess I would have to go with the grandfathering clause as the soft optionâthe second best alternative. But I would urge you to consider whether or not the minister has made the case for this entitlement to be removed and whether or not you really do think that these people are double dipping. I maintain they are not. Every other sole parenting recipient in Australia is entitled to earn an income up to those income levels if they participate in work. These people are participating, through the CDEP project, in work. Why should they be treated any less favourably?

You have the government saying, `On the one hand we want to have a level playing field in terms of CDEP but on the other hand we want an uneven playing field in terms of parenting payment single.' You can choose which level playing field you think is more appropriate. It just so happens that the one the government supports on this occasion saves them millions of dollars and disadvantages single parent Aboriginal families. I, on balance, prefer the other view. That argument has been articulated before.

In terms of the procedural issue that the minister raises, we think that our amendments achieve what we have stated to be our objective, which is that the status quo apply for sole parent pensioners and that they do not receive the CDEP supplementary benefit. We do not intend that they get an advantage from receiving the $20 CDEP supplement. We are saying that we want to exclude them from that on the basis that they retain the status quo. That was the intention of those amend ments. I am happy to enter into discussions with your officers if they say that is not achieved. We were not seeking to delay the payment of that to other groups and we were not seeking to further benefit those who receive a parenting payment single. That was the intention. I think you said that was what we were doing. If that is the case, I agree.
I note there is some excitement among the many advisers you have here today. I am glad to see you have more numbers here. I hope that helps the process.

talk.start.para: âI'll send some over to you to help you.

âMinister, I find it is quantity, not quality, on these occasions. That is no slur on the advisers present. As I said, our intention and the drafting instructions to the clerks were that the amendments be drafted so that the status quo applied to those in receipt of parent payment single, that the other measures the government announced proceeded as planned and that the changes you wanted in terms of timing proceeded as you intended. I think I have made that perfectly clear. We are not arguing about a policy issue there, so I hope we can just get to what we think we are achieving and resolve it.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âIt is getting harder to resolve, because Labor's amendments would actually introduce double dipping for pensioners who were joining CDEP in the futureâbecause the CDEP scheme is being opened up to all pensioners from 20 March next year. In other words, the double amount of assistance that single parents are getting now would become the norm for all pensioners from 20 March next year. Whether that is what you intended or not, that is what is going to happen as a result. I am fascinated that you are prepared to countenance double dipping but you are not prepared to countenance triple dipping. Well done! You are moving! The add-on of the $20 would obviously mean triple dipping, in your eyes.

speech.para: Essentially what we are dealing with here is the unintended consequence of the conver gence of two systems: the traditional social security income support system and the CDEP system. We have got a group which, if your amendments go through, will be larger still, come 20 March next year. We have got a group of people who have entitlement to two lots of assistance from the taxpayer. Nobody else in Australia has that. I particularly wanted you to hear me to the end of this answer, and then perhaps Senator Bartlett might have something to say, and that will give you the chance to get some advice.

It is not just bureaucrats in ATSIC who believe this needs fixing. The board of ATSIC believes it. You would have seen or certainly would know of the letter that Gatjil Djerrkura wrote to Senator Lees. I quoted from it two days ago.

talk.start.para: âYou didn't send it to us.
âThat is a pity, becauseâ
âThat is your decision.
âIt is not my decision. It has nothing to do with me. This is the board of ATSIC that has written. One of the sentences in it is this:

speech.para: The board acknowledges the government's strong argumentâ
they are talking about lone parent pensionersâ
that the introduction of new income treatment arrangements will address the potential double funding by government of CDEP participants who are also lone parent pensioners.

Specifically, the penultimate paragraph goes into the question of lone parents in some detail. It is not a question of the bureaucrats in ATSIC. It is the board of ATSIC that has wanted to see this ended and the new scheme introduced. If there is anything that the Labor Party has talked about over the years, it is the need to listen to indigenous people's views on their futures. This is a clear case where the Labor Party is prepared to ignore that advice.

Our government has been particularly concerned about sole parents in indigenous communities. Our government has put a massive effort in already, and is continuing to, in order to do something about the terrible domestic violence in indigenous communities which leads so often to sole parenthood. So do not accuse us of not having the concerns of sole parents in indigenous communities at heart. We are actually trying to make a difference. We are making a massive effort in this. That violence is something that have I watched grow in indigenous communities around Central and Northern Australia and North Queensland over the time that you were in government.

It is now time that the women in those communities were listened to, and this government has been listening to them and involving them in consultations about how best to deal with this scourge in their community. You might have had a darned sight fewer sole parents if that had been done earlier. It makes me very cross to think of the wasted lives, the damaged bodies, the children scarred psychologically and the continuation of the cycle of domestic violence in those communitiesâa cycle which could have been stopped earlier or could have been prevented.

If you really care about sole parents, support the government's endeavours in that and do not try a cheap shot about whether we have concern for some of the most deprived people in our society: we do have. Their lives are vital, as well as this double income support which they are getting from the federal taxpayer.

talk.start.para: âI should put on the record in perhaps a bit more detail the Democrats' beliefs in relation to this area and also some of the philosophical points that have come up, just to ensure that they are clearly on the record. Firstly, whilst I understand the minister's argument, I do think that the phrase `double dipping' is a pejorative one which implies some sort of inappropriate motive on the part of the recipient. I am not saying that the minister believes that, but I do think that in this area of welfare payments there is often a lot of potential community negativity that is able to be tapped into in relation to welfare recipients and that it is best to avoid language that might play on that by implying some inappropriate motive on behaviour. This is clearly a legitimate entitlement that people currently have, and these are not wealthy people, by any stretch of the imaginationâas Senator Evans has outlined.

speech.para: The minister, in responding to some aspects of the opposition's amendments, talked about the cost if they were passed. I think it was $14 million a year, roughly, in a couple of years time. As I say repeatedly with regard to social security legislation, I am certainly not of the view that it is not important to try to limit government expenditure and to try to save government money where appropriate. But it is important to emphasise that, when we are using figures like those, it is not just a matter of saving taxpayers $14 million or whatever the amount of money is but that it also means $14 million is not been provided to people who are, generally speaking, amongst the most disadvantaged. If you put it in that context, it takes on quite a different light: it is $14 million of assistance that would otherwise be provided to disadvantaged people but that will not be provided. Again, it is important in terms of the issue of language.

The comments that Senator Evans was making about the different choices of level playing field also need noting and responding to. Again, I quite understand the rationale of what he is putting forward but, if you were to extend that logic fully, then the opposition would really need to extend the current income treatment that sole parents receive to all other income support payments in relation to CDEP. If it is a philosophical or an ideological principle, then it would make sense for it to apply across the board rather than to just one group of people. I know that the amendments are not seeking to do that but, if we are following through that principle, we would need to do that; and I do not think that anyone is suggesting that we should do that.

I do think it is appropriate that there be consistency of treatment. I have spoken many times about the need for a consistent approach, the removal of anomalies and the simplification of the Social Security Act. I have also spoken many times about how we should not do that in a way that reduces people's entitlements rather than increases them. This clearly is a situation where, for whatever historical reason it appeared, CDEP income for sole parents is treated in a way that is different to any other social security recipient. That is clearly an anomaly.

I note the specific statements of ATSIC chairman, Gatjil Djerrkuraâa person for whom I have a lot of respectâon the treatment of sole parents receiving a pension like payment. That is something that does need to be taken on board. Nonetheless, I come back to the basic point that I have continued to try to make on this issue which is that those sorts of principles are important, budgetary expenditure is important, consistency of treatment is important and simplified acts is important, but we also need to remember that we are talking about people here. We need to try to ensure that we are not disadvantaging people, particularly people who are already amongst the least well off. That is the particular rationale behind the foreshadowed amendment of the Democrats.

There are a couple of other points I would like to make. Firstly, I point out to Senator Evans that amendment No. 8, which is to oppose section 1188D, still reads to me like it will affect a whole group of people rather than just parenting payment (single) which, from my understanding of his comments, is not the intent.

Secondly, in response to the minister's comments about the resentment that may be out in the community towards the perceived special treatment of some sole parents, I do not know how strong that is. I guess that is one of the things you cannot quantify. The discussions I have had with ATSIC people do not recall that being raised as an issue. One thing you can quantify is that these women will be $80 a fortnight worse off. When you are balancing up whether you want to be $80 a week worse off but perhaps have a little less perceived resentment in the community, I imagine most people would prefer to keep their $80 a fortnight unless that resentment is completely overpowering. I have certainly had no evidence at all that that is the case. I do not accept that as an argument in itself for significantly reducing the entitlements of people who are currently receiving these payments.

As Senator Evans pointed out, if there was some problems with these women being able to access employment through CDEP because of this treatment then there would not be 4,000 currently in this situation. That may be a problem that is stopping others getting in, but it is certainly not stopping the 4,000 that are already there. Again, I do not see that as a valid argument.

To put on the record the Democrats' response to these amendments, the view I have formed after listening to the various arguments that have been put forward and the responses to those is that the best course of action from the Democrats' point of view is not to support the opposition amendments at present, unless Senator Evans comes up with a stunningly brilliant contribution in a few seconds time.

talk.start.para: âAgain.

âYet another one, yes. I do believe, nonetheless, that it is important to try to ensure that these 4,000 peopleâI presume they are predominantly womenâare not disadvantaged by this change and do not have a significant drop in their existing income in a few months time. For that reason, I hope that the Senate will consider giving support to the amendment I have foreshadowed.

âI would like to speak to the opposition amendments. In doing so, I will go through a few issues that I believe are very pertinent to CDEP in North Queensland. I believe the program was trialled in the Northern Territory and Western Australia. There are areas where it is functioning very well to the benefit of the communities.

speech.para: In North Queensland it would appear, after having actually spent time in the communities discussing the issue, to have a downside that I do not believe was perceived or intended by the people who passed the original legislation and established the scheme. In North Queensland the CDEP is referred to as sit down pay. It has introduced a mentality into the communities whereby people no longer believe that they need to go out and work on the stations or, for that matter, in the programs that are being established by their own councils. They merely say, `We sit home and get paid as well.'

There appears to be a lack of actual contact with the people in the communities by the people who are progressing both the legislation and the schemes. If you go into a local communityâsay, Pormpuraaw, and I have actually been thereâthe local people will pay $250 for a slab. You say, `What is a slab?' A slab is a carton of beer. That can actually be purchased in either Chillagoe or Mareeba for approximately $20, driven out to the communitiesânot necessarily by white people; quite often by Aboriginal peopleâand then sold on-site. They will also sell a cap. You say, `What is a cap?' A cap is the quantity of spirit you can pour into the cap from a bottle of Johnny Walker.

Senator Bartlett says the people in the community will suffer, that if this payment is taken away from them, it will impact on their economic management. With the greatest of sincerity to Senator Bartlett, I would like him to show me any Aboriginal person in a community who sits down and works out a budget of what they are going to do with their pensions or their pay. In reality, it does not happen. The CDEP was genuinely intended to assist these people. I do not believe it does today. We can, and I believe this chamber should, continue to debate the issues on their merit as they are put forward, but I think we also need to have a practical look at their application.

Look at Hopevale: there are people in Hopevale who have been paying rent for the last 36 years. They will continue to do that until they dieânever, ever owning those homes. We look at the communities up there and wonder why they do not have any pride in the places they live in.

I do not believe that it is for us, with the greatest of intent, to provide these people with what we believe is a social answer to their problem. We need to get out there and talk to the people. I spent four days in Pormpuraaw. I have seen the local people picked up, taken down to the local police station, held over night, dried out, given a meal and sent home. That is the reality of what is happening in our communities.

We need to do two things. First, listen to the people in the communities and find out what they need to do to assist themselves. Second, if they are willing, assist them with some economic formsâin other words, give them the ability to take control of their lives and give them some purpose for living where they live. If, however, they choose to go back to their own traditional way of living, we need to listen to them as well.

I understand what the opposition is trying to do to preserve these payments to these people. There is resentment within the communities, where some of the communities are seen to be getting two paymentsâand you actually have to be in the community on a payment day to really understand what happens. If the opposition's amendments are successful and that $14 million that is being spoken of is moved into economic development within the communities for the community as a whole, it would bring the communities closer together and actually assist in progressing what we are trying to do.

talk.start.para: âThere are a couple of issues I wish to address. First, on this procedural question: I guess if the Democrats are voting against the amendments, it becomes a largely academic issue. But I would say to the minister that we have tried to cooperate in terms of getting a debate about the principles and not the technicalities. We met with her advisers yesterday and, as I said, we have tried to get the debate back to the question of principles. I was here until 10.30 last night and from 7.30 this morning. If you had a problem and you thought we had an unintended consequence, given that I put on the record three or four times yesterday what our intentions were, I think we would have been better suited trying to sort this out outside of the chamber prior to us coming in.

speech.para: You always talk to me about the need for prior consultation, good manners, et cetera. I would suggest to you that, if the government thinks there is an unintended consequence of an opposition amendment, you would be better off picking up the phone and talking to me about it. It seems to me that, rather than waste the time of the chamber here as we have again this morning, we could have had that discussion and fixed that.

I have been very straight about what our intention is. I have said it about eight times in the Hansard. I accept there may be a problem with an unintended consequence arising from our amendment. I am not sure how many people who actually receive the age pension are working on CDEP, or how many who receive the disability pension are working on CDEP. I suspect the figures are fairly small. In any event, if there is a problem, all I am saying is that we ought to be able to sort that out. Rather than come in and try to score a political point, it seems to me that we would have been better served trying to sort that out. I want to concentrate on the political issues and the principles.

Minister, you alleged there was some sort of cheap shot. There is no cheap shot involved. I wanted us to focus though on the impact of this measure. While Senator Harris made some very optimistic and hopeful statements about what could be done with the money instead, the reality I want to focus on is that these amendments deprive Aboriginal single parents of income. We have to focus on that. If the Senate makes that decision, I am prepared to accept that but I want to make sure we focused on that. That is why the opposition opposes this measure; we just cannot see the justification for reducing their benefits.

I do not want to labour the point. I do not suspect I am going to suddenly come up with a brilliant argument that convinces Senator Bartlett. He has clearly been influenced in recent times to review the Democrats' position and he has come up with a second-best option in terms of the grandfathering clause.

I do think it would be useful if the Democrats tabled in the Senate the letter to Senator Lees from ATSIC. I have only just been handed a copy of that letter. ATSIC did not choose to write to the opposition. But I noticed that the minister, in quoting, did not quote the whole paragraph from ATSIC; I think it is important that the whole paragraph go on the record so that ATSIC's position is not misunderstood. As I understand it, the letter starts:
While the board has expressed concern over the potential impact of the new income treatment arrangements for lone parent pensioners on CDEP, the board also acknowledges . . .

And it goes on. To be fair to ATSIC and Gatjil Djerrkura, the letter ought to be tabled, because it has become part of the debate here today. I do not feel that I should seek to do it; it is not a letter to me. But I think that would be useful.

I also want to put on the record that the opposition has been approached by a range of CDEP groups who have a different view from ATSIC about the impact of this measure. Of course, that is their right. They have a different perception of the impact. The opposition has been influenced by their views, but also by the discussions we had yesterday with ATSIC in which they briefed the opposition's advisers about their attitude to the bill. What we found particularly telling was that they could not suggest to us that there would be any greater participation in CDEP by sole parents as a result of these measures. That was quite telling in terms of our response: we do not expect that the sorts of things that the minister talks about, such as prevention of women participating in the schemes, will be altered by this. Certainly ATSIC did not put any argument to that effect. I think it important that ATSIC's position go on the record. I would appreciate it if Senator Bartlett would table ATSIC's letter so as to have their position clearly stated, rather than my reading certain bits and the minister reading other bits of their correspondence.

I put on the record that I am pleased that the minister is starting to listen to ATSIC and the views which they express. I hope this reflects a change of heart by the government more generally in terms of listening to what ATSIC and Aboriginal people have to say. I do take what they say seriously. I did not until recently have a copy of their letter but, as I say, they did not write it to me. In any event, I will not delay the Senate any longer on the basis of the arguments.

The Labor Party still thinks the government has not made a case for reducing the entitlements of these single parents. They are among the most disadvantaged, and we do not think that the arguments about tensions in the community or levelling the playing field warrant that reduction. That is a judgment people have to make. Given that the Democrats will not be voting for our amendments, I suspect the issue about the unintended consequences falls away, so I do not think we need to worry about resolving that.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âObviously I do not speak for Senator Bartlett, but I would suggest that there is absolutely no reason for him to need to table the ATSIC letter, as the ATSIC letter was handed to Senator Evans's adviser by my staff two days ago in the Senate. So the opposition has in fact been in possession of the ATSIC letterâ
âI have not seen it.
âYou gave the distinct impression that the opposition had not had the benefit of a copy of it. The fact is that your adviser, who is presently sitting in the box, was given a copy two days ago.
âHe may well have been; I have not seen it.

âI am happy to pick up the phone to you to avoid the waste of time we have had this morning. I am not saying this in a spirit of a lack of charity; I am just saying to you that I only got the advice this morning. It is a classic outcome of what I mentioned in my second reading speech two days ago. If the opposition are dealing in, say, taxation law or social security law and think that they can drop pages of amendments on the Senate as the second reading debate is proceeding and expect to get proper scrutiny by people who have got the ability to assess the implications in a very technical system, they are setting themselves up to look foolish in terms of unintended consequences.

speech.para: I am not trying to rub anybody's nose in anything, but if you believe in good govern mentâand I know this, having been in opposition for far too long myselfâif you have amendments of a technical nature, it is better to come into the chamber with those amendments having been looked at thoroughly by somebody who can give you advice on them. My office twice wrote to the opposition offering briefings on this legislation, with no response, and I understand that a briefing was given yesterday. Those amendments could have been printed earlier and therefore been availableâ

talk.start.para: âYour amendments came out yesterday.
âYou have had amendments from us for a long time.
âYour amendments came out yesterday.

âYou have had amendments from us for a long time. I am talking about your long list. We have just had two weeks in which the Senate has not been sitting. It was a pretty reasonable time to have your amendments looked at and to have the Senate prepare a running sheet. The Senate yesterday had to prepare two running sheets as a result of getting your list of amendments in a very, very short time. Maybe you do not believe in good government when you are not in government; maybe that is what you are on about. But surely a responsible opposition would still believe in the government of the day putting down legislation which is able to be administered and which is not producing unforeseen consequences.
âYour hypocrisy is breathtaking.

âNo matter how Senator Evans squawks from the opposition benches, the reality is that doing the Senate the discourtesy of getting so many technical amendments at the last minuteâsome of which have been demonstrated to have been absolutely unacceptable, I am sure even to himself, and certainly to the rest of the chamberâis something to be avoided in the cause of good government and not wasting at least an hour of the Senate's time. I am glad to see that commonsense is prevailing.
âThe question is that the amendments and the request for amendments (R10) be agreed to.

interjection.para: Question resolved in the negative.

talk.start.para: âThe question now is that schedule 2, item 53, section 1188D stand as printed.

interjection.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: âI move Democrats amendment No. 1 on sheet 1547:

speech.para: Schedule 2, page 40 (after line 6), at the end of the Schedule, add:

The amendments made by items 48 to 53 (inclusive) do not apply to a person who, on the day on which this Act receives the Royal Assent, is receiving parenting payment at the rate applicable for a person who is not a member of a couple. The provisions of the Social Security Act 1991 continue to apply to such persons as if the amendments made to that Act by items 48 to 53 (inclusive) had not been made.

The issues relating to this amendment have already been addressed, so I will not go on about it at great length. Basically the outcome will be that the Senate accepts the rationale of the change that the government is making in relation to the treatment of sole parents' income but protects the income of those that are currently on the CDEP Scheme so that those 4,000 people, as I understand it, will not experience that significant reduction in their income but new participants in the scheme will come on board as part of the new arrangements.

I will just make a couple of comments. I am quite happy to table the letter from Gatjil Djerrkura. I did not have a copy with me but I will table the copy that Senator Evans has kindly given to me. I had obviously seen a copy of it previously. It was sent to Senator Lees at the end of August and it was passed on to me as the party's social security spokesperson and I responded to that. I am happy to table that letter so that is on the record.

Senator Evans spoke about being approached by a number of CDEP groups about their concerns which are different to ATSIC. As he said, it is entirely appropriate for different people to have different views. I personally have not and, as far as I am aware, none of the Democrats have been approached by those groups. Without giving advice to ATSIC, if they send letters to the Democrats it would probably be a good idea for them to send them to the opposition as well. Usually when I meet with people about legislation I encourage them to talk to all parties. Much as I like to put the view out there that all wisdom resides with the Democrats, it does not hurt for them to talk to other parties as well. It probably would have been a good idea for ATSIC to send a similar letter to the opposition. But, conversely, I did not receive any representations from people involved in individual CDEP operations putting a contrary view. So I am going on the information and views that were expressed to me.

There were a couple of comments today about us having wasted time this morning. Whilst a bit of toing-and-froing about unintended consequences and dropping amendments at the last minute may not be that productive, I do think outlining the policy principles in relation to this issue is important and I do not see that as a waste of time. I think it is something worth emphasising.

I try to take a fairly low key approach, if you like, to social security legislation, as I do with immigration legislationâboth are areas in which public passions can be quite easily inflamed, sometimes in a negative way if one wants to stir things upâand I try to avoid too much fiery rhetoric because I do not think it is constructive in areas such as these. It is nonetheless important to put on the record in a dispassionate way that what we are dealing with, as this amendment is, is indigenous sole parent pensioners and we are trying to ensure that their income is not significantly reduced.

I take on board Senator Harris's comments before, whatever validity there might be in his comments about how various people budget or do not budget and spend their money. I think moving to significantly reduce the income of people who are already not well off cannot do anything other than have a negative impact on them. While there may be other measures that may mitigate that to some extent, reducing people's income by $40 a week or more when they are not well off to start with should not be dismissed. It is a significant action, and it has an impact on human beingsâhuman beings who are amongst the most disadvantaged. That basic point needs to be made and this Democrat amendment, which hopefully does not have any unintended drafting consequences, moves to protect those people.

talk.start.para: âDo you wish to incorporate that letter?
âI have asked to table it.
âI believe if you incorporate it, it may be better.
âI am happy to do that. I seek leave to incorporate that letter.

speech.para: Leave granted.
The letter read as followsâ
ATSIC
Chairperson
Senator Meg Lees
Parliamentary Leader
Australian Democrats
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Lees

I am writing to you seeking your support in securing the passage of the Further 1998 Budget Measures Legislation Amendment (Social Security) Bill 1999 which I understand is scheduled to be introduced for debate in the Senate during this week's sittings.

As you may be aware, the above Bill relates to the implementation of the Government's 1998 CDEP Budget Initiative, which will provide benefits to participants on the Community Development Employment Projects (CDEP) Scheme. The Budget Initiative seeks to address inequity issues experienced by participants on the Scheme. These issues were identified in both the independent review of the CDEP Scheme (the Spicer Review) and the report of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. The Budget Initiative will provide CDEP participants with access to the CDEP Participant Supplement (CPS) as well as access to add-on benefits.

The original implementation date for the Initiative was 20 March this year. I am most concerned that any further legislative delay of this measure will result in significant confusion for CDEP organisa tions and participants and will genuinely disadvantage CDEP participants who would yet again be prevented from accessing the CPS and add-on benefits.

The ATSIC Board has given its in-principle support to the package of measures contained in the Initiative and considers that the successful implementation of the Initiative on 20 September 1999 is important for providing access to the above benefits.

While the Board has expressed concern over the potential impact of the new income treatment arrangements for Lone Parents Pensioners on CDEP, the Board also acknowledges that this is an equity issue between the income treatment arrangements afforded to other pensioners and those on CDEP. The Board acknowledges the Government's strong argument that the introduction of new income treatment arrangements will address the potential double funding by Government of CDEP participants who are also Lone Parent Pensioners.
In conclusion I would urge you to do all in your power to ensure that the Senate considers the Bill in this week's sittings and to support its passage without amendment.
Yours sincerely
Gatjil Djerrkura OAM
Chairman

talk.start.para: âI thought I would perhaps hear from the minister as to what her attitude is. But, as I indicated on behalf of the opposition earlier, our preferred position obviously was to support our amendments which protected the position of sole parents in terms of the government's intentions in their entirety.

speech.para: This amendment is an attempt by the Democrats to afford some protection to those currently in receipt of both the parenting payment (single) and CDEP yet obviously does not do anything for the longer term situation of sole parents involved in CDEP. But it does seek to address one of the chief opposition's concerns, which I have stated earlier, which is to try to protect the income level available to these most disadvantaged parents and children. Our approach to this has always been to seek to protect their position and to argue that the arguments for simplicity and level playing fields do not overcome the impact on the individuals affected by this measureâthat is, that they have their income reduced by a significant amount, which then has a detrimental effect on their families.

The Democrats position, as I understand it, will at least protect those 4,000 or so single parents who are currently involved in CDEP and who receive the parenting payment (single). The opposition intends to support that amendment because it goes some way to achieving the policy outcome that we sought to achieve when we entered this debate and which we think is important. While we would have preferred our amendments being carried, which would have protected the position of all single parents involved in CDEP in future years, this at least has the advantage of ensuring that parents currently in receipt of the parenting payment do not have their income reduced by in the order of $100 per fortnight, which would have an immediate impact on their capacity to care for their children and to support their families. That was at the core of our concern about this measure so, to the extent that the Democrat amendment does that, we support it. It is a second-best option, but it is one that we are prepared to support.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âThe government will not be supporting the Democrats' amendment. The social policy reform of which this is a part has come through an independent review by Mr Ian Spicer, who recommended that this matter be reformed. On the specific area of people receiving two payments, the proposal has been endorsed by ATSIC, as the letter which has now been incorporated in Hansard demonstrates. In plain equity terms, it is unfair that some people in a community should be treated so very differently from everybody else, none of whom you would say were rich. They are all on the same level of welfare dependency and are all bordering on poverty. The arguments which have just been made are not acceptable.

speech.para: The effect on women is one that concerns me. Senator Bartlett, of all people, having worked in social security in the past, would well understand how a good social policy is a simpler policyâin terms of administration, the ability of people to access their due entitlements, et ceteraâand that, wherever grandfathering occurs, you get complexities in administration and a less clearly defined system for people to access their entitlements. It is particularly not good social security policy to increase the number of people who are grandfathered for any reason. It is usually done for a political purpose, and that is what is happening in this case. The package has come forward from the government after independent inquiry by Mr Spicer and after endorsement by the elected representatives of the indigenous communities. I would have thought that would weigh heavily on senators' minds. We need to endorse it here, but the government recognises that we will not win this vote.

talk.start.para: âI rise to indicate that I will be opposing the amendment but, in doing that, I would like to clarify the reasons why. It may seem unfair to oppose a motion that intends to assist and protect the people whom you are directing that payment to. The reason I clearly oppose the amendment is that it does not achieve the intended outcome. I tried very briefly before to describe what happens in a community on the day a pension cheque arrives. You really have to be there and experience it to understand what happens. There is resentment within some of the communities. Some of the communities work exceptionally well on the program, but others do not, and in those communities the program has a very adverse effect on the people whom we are intending to help.

speech.para: Senator Evans's comment about my suggestion of having this amount of money appropriated to schemes that would economically help the communities is an indication either that I am not articulating very well or that he does not agree with the idea of people having dignity. We are putting an amount of money into communities without taking the next step of ensuring that it gets to the women and children whom it is intended to get to. In communities like Pormpuraaw and Kowanyama, it does not have that effect. It goes into the community and is spent in the way that the communities in those areas traditionally spend it. It does not get to help the mothers to go down to the local store to buy provi sions for their childrenâthat is, provided the local community store has the funds to purchase those goods so they can buy them.

I believe we need to listen to the people in the communities as to how we help them, not impose our ideologies on them. There are ways in which we can help them. We can help them have the integrity of their artwork so that their artwork is not pilfered by people who put it into the tourist shops in Cairns and areas like that with no benefit to the communities from where it has been pilfered.

These are the areas where we need to assist these people. I believe it would be far more effective to take the amounts of money that we are talking about and turn them around into programs that will actually help all of the communities. We also need to look beyond the communities. A substantial number of Aboriginal people live in the wider community and their needs, in some cases, are as great as, if not greater than, those in the community. Though it may seem a contradiction in terms, my reason for opposing the amendment is that I believe it would be far better to have the equality of the single payment for these people within their communities, to take that additional money and to put it into a process that those communities collectively believe will assist them more.

talk.start.para: âI speak briefly in response to comments in relation to the amendment. Firstly, I think Senator Harris's comments to a large extent relate more broadly to the CDEP and his views on the operation of that. This issue is obviously a small part of an aspect of the treatment of income relating to the CDEP. I will not necessarily respond to his broader comments about the worth or otherwise of the CDEP as it operates. I have visited a number of indigenous communities myself, both in Queensland and in the Northern Territory. I certainly have some understanding of the situations there, although I would not claim to be an expert by any means.

speech.para: Whilst I very much endorse the view that just giving people money is not the answer and there are a lot of other issues that need to be incorporated, I am very wary of a view which is taking hold that money is not unim portant. Money does come in reasonably handy. It is not the only thing one needs. Despite some of the romantics out there who think love is all you need, I think money does come in handy occasionally as well. Personal income and basic income support payments are a crucial component of giving people the opportunity to have some control over their lives and some dignity. I certainly do not suggest that it is the only thing, but it is important not to undervalue the basic and crucial aspect of ensuring that people have enough money to live on.

The Minister for Family and Community Services made some comments about good social policy. I understand what she is saying in relation to that, but I do think it is important to remember that social policy is not just about reviews, academic aspects and coming up with something that makes logical sense but also about the impact on people. I know she is not saying it is not, but I want to keep emphasising that in this type of legislation more than most we are dealing with issues that impact very much on people.

I acknowledge that grandfather clauses make for administrative messiness, but they also serve more than a political purpose in the narrow sense of the word. I do not think they are totally politically driven a lot of the time. They are a mechanism for smoothing out the negative consequences of change, and that applies in many areas. It is frequently used for that purpose where a change is recognised as being appropriate but a smoothing mechanism is put in place to try to ensure that people are not crunched along the way as the change is made. Whilst it might not be pure social policy, it is still good social policy in the sense that it does prevent negative impacts on individual people.

Finally, I want to emphasise that the Democrats have not changed our position since Monday as a result of being leaned on by anybody or anything like that. In the comments I have made throughout this debate, I have outlined our concerns about the impact of this measure, but I have certainly not committed us to a particular approach. We have had to balance up the competing claims and the very strong representations from ATSIC wanting the measures to get through. Although it has not been categorically stated, it is clearly an attitude of the government's that we are dealing with a package in the schedule of the bill. There are some very positive measures in it which I know ATSIC and the indigenous communities are very keen to have commence and come into operation. There was very much a real risk here of losing those good measures, and that obviously had an impact on the Democrats' approach on this issue.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Bartlett's ) be agreed to.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: âI move opposition amendment No. 33 on sheet 1391:

speech.para: (33) Schedule 3, page 47 (after line 4), after item 42, insert:
Add:

(4) A person is not qualified for an employment entry payment under this Part if the person is qualified for a special employment advance under Part 2.22A and has made a claim under section 1061EP in respect of the same employment.

I wish to address my remarks to the general question of employment and education entry payments in debating this amendment and hopefully not repeat them with every amendment. The government's legislation seeks to abolish the employment entry payment, which is a non-refundable grant, and replace it with a repayable advance called the new special employment advance, which is in effect a loan. With the current system, the employment entry payment is a non-refundable payment, and the government's proposal is to change that into effectively a loan. The government also seeks to abolish the education entry payment and, to the best of my understanding, not replace that at all for recipients of allowances.

The opposition are attempting to protect the employment and education entry payments and come some way towards supporting the part of the government's approach that allows a bit more flexibility in what they call the special employment advance. We are seeking to protect the employment entry payment and to provide the option of the advance for those who find it preferable. As I understand it, the government are saying it is preferable that people take an advance if and when they require it and not be entitled to the payment. We say there is some merit in the approach of giving it a bit more flexibility because some people may require the larger amount which is available under the advance. We accept that that may be useful on some occasions.

But I think there is a fundamental flaw in the sense that it means that people entering employment are entering into further debt at a time when they may well have been unemployed for some time and have acquired a great deal of debt either to institutions or to family and friends. For a lot of people the idea of getting into further debt will not be a terribly attractive one. But, in the sense that the government's approach provides the option for those people, we think that may well be a measure that allows more choice and more flexibility. However, we do not see the argument for the employment entry payment being abolished. We think that there are real costs associated with starting employment and that the payment provides a useful addition to helping people make the transition from unemployment to employment. The payment was introduced in 1991 and has provided some assistance to those people. We do not see the argument for that being removed.

I admit it is small and I admit that it is not necessarily an incentive for people to take employment but it provides a very tangible assistance for them when taking up work. It provides them with some opportunity to ease that transition into employment and to meet some of the costs associated with starting employment. For that reason, we support the employment entry payment. Our amendment seeks to provide some flexibility. If the government wishes to offer this advance scheme as an addition then we are prepared to support that, but we are not prepared to see the employment entry payment abolished. We think it is a very worthwhile and useful measure that assists people in the transition from unemployment to work. We are a bit perplexed as to why, apart from being a cost cutting measure, the government would seek to remove it.

In terms of addressing the education entry payment at the same time, I know this is the subject of later amendments but it is a related measure in terms of the debate. We do not understand why the government wants to abolish the education entry payment. We think it provides very useful assistance to people wishing to study.

I would be interested to hear from the minister what the rationale is for removing that payment, because we think it just removes a key incentive for people to actually seek to further their skills. The payment provides some assistance for people who are enrolling in study. When we are talking about unemployed people, I thought the whole thrust of government policyâand I think this is a bipartisan approachâwas to encourage people to improve their employment skills in order to make themselves more employable and to be able to take on better and more rewarding jobs. We are a bit unclear as to why the government would want to remove that payment which facilitates that movement from unemployment to study, allowing people to better themselves. We will be opposing that measure.

As I say, while we seek to come some way towards the government's approach in terms of employment entry payments, we seek to maintain the current entry payment for those who wish to access it. Apart from being a savings measure, I do not understand the reason for removing that entitlement. We think both payments provide some incentives for people to better themselves by seeking employment and seeking study, and we think the abolition of both of those entry payments would be a counterproductive measure.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âThe government's intention is to introduce a special employment advance because it will greatly extend the coverage and the provision of advance payments to income support recipients taking up work. Applicants for the SEA will need to demonstrate that either they have earned income from casual work but have not yet received that income, or they have received a definite offer of employment of at least six weeks duration but do not have sufficient financial resources to take up that employment.

speech.para: Senator Evans just now was asking for the rationale behind the introduction of this measure. I say to him that the Working Nation departmental evaluation of the employment entry payment scheme, which was initially introduced as an incentive provision, has indicated that it does not appear to be a major force in influencing customers' decisions to take up work. In addition, the scheme is complex. There are differences in the rates and the conditions attaching to the scheme that depend on the customers' payment types.

For example, you do not get an employment entry payment if you are going into part-time work, because usually if you are going into part-time work you are still on part Newstart allowance and you cannot therefore get an employment entry payment. You can get an employment entry payment only once in 12 months, and for people who are struggling to get back into the work force the ability to take up a succession of part-time jobs throughout the course of a year is very important. So, having had your employment entry payment once, you are then precluded from getting it again during the course of that year.

Now, with the special employment advance, you can get it any time you need it. It is very much more flexible, it is a bigger sum of money and it is available for that transitional phase from perhaps being long-term unemployed, or certainly unemployed, into more sustainable long-term employment. I think those are very good reasons for saying the special employment advance is the right way to go. It builds on the purpose behind the employment entry payment, but it is a much better arrangement. There is also a separate group of people who have been in casual work and who have not yet been able to receive that income. Teachers are a classic example of this. There has, I think, been a lot of lobbying of successive governments over a number of years to try to fix that because they are deemed to have received income that they have not in fact received. So the special employment advance is useful for that group of people as well.

I do not think that there is any virtue in retaining the employment entry payment when you have got a larger payment that is available any time you need it, compared with the employment entry payment which is available only once in a year. For the employment entry payment to not be available for people who take up part-time work and are still on part Newstart allowance seems to me to be a pretty deficient kind of employment entry payment because it is a much more likely way that a lot of people will get back into the work force. They will not easily go straight from unemployment, especially if it is long-term unemployment, into a full-time job. They are much more likely to put their foot on the escalator again through the means of part-time work. To do that and not be eligible for the employment entry payment seems a bit of a nonsense to me. I think this is an important reform. You do not need to retain the employment entry payment.
