talk.start.para: âIn speaking to the opposition amendment I will also speak to the foreshadowed ones that are coming up next and which relate to the same issue, just to get my comments out of the way all at once. Initially, in response to the minister's comments about the review and the current operation of the employment entry payment, if there are problems or deficiencies in the way the payment currently operates I would have thought the better way to go would be to address those deficiencies rather than scrap it altogether.

speech.para: In relation to the special employment advance that is being proposed, I have great reservations about that. The opposition's amendment does not knock that out so that is not an issue to explore further, but it is very different from the employment entry payment. The opposition's amendment will, as I understand it, enable that advance to operate whilst retaining the employment entry payment, thus giving people the option. Down the track, if the advance operates as well as the government seems to think it will, it may be justifiable to revisit the issue of the employment entry payment if the employment advance operates in a more effective way.

But there are a couple of big differences about the advance as opposed to the employment entry payment as it currently exists. Firstly, it is an advance. It is not a payment; it is a loan which needs to be repaid. As I said in my contribution at the second reading stage, I have great reservations about the introduction of the principle of social security payments being put forward as advances or loans rather than as entitlements. This is only a very small measure in the grand scheme of the operation of the Social Security Act. But, as I said at the time, there is such a thing as the thin end of the wedge, and I have concerns that this may be one of those circumstances where, once this principle is established in the act, it will be extended to a wide range of other payments over time, and the concept which has actually been floated by some commentators in recent times that social security payments should follow the way of HECS fees and be a debt or a loan that is recoverable rather than a payment that is paid through entitlement is the sort of approach I would have great reservations about.

Having said that, the operation as detailed here in the explanatory memorandum shows the difference. The concerns or the problems that the minister outlined about people taking up part-time work may well be genuineâI am sure they are genuineâbut that is not the whole story in relation to the employment entry payment. I think if you look at the explanatory memorandum and how it will operate you will get a clearer idea of the main motivation hereâthat is, that the outlays from the special employment advance would, in a few years time, be less than $1 million a year, yet the savings from the employment entry payment being abolished are $18 million.

The memorandum does not mention the modifications to the education entry payment which I understand is being done as well. I would have thought there were some cost or savings implications there. I do not know if they are folded into the total of the employment entry payments as outlined in the explanatory memorandum, but I assume they are also being claimed as a savings measure. For those reasons that I have outlined, the Democrats support the aim of the opposition in this amendment and the next couple of amendments.
Amendment agreed to.

âAs with some of the other issues in relation to this bill, we need to look further than just the wording of what is being proposed, which is to partially remove some of the employment entry payments. speech.para: I believeâand maybe the minister can assist me hereâthe intention of replacing that with a special employment advance is that the person, once in the work force, is then required to pay that advance back. Of the two systems, I believe that the government's position in reducing the availability of the entry paymentâwhich the person can take with no obligation whatsoever to pay it back and no obligation to continue in the employment which that entry payment assisted them to getâand replacing it with an advance to the tune of $500, which they are required to repay, is a healthy situation on two counts. Firstly, it will give that person far more support to continue in their employment. Secondly, it requires that person to have the personal discipline to budget to pay that back. In relation to society that is a far better process to be following.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

speech.para: What I particularly like about it is that it is available to a number of people who currently cannot get the employment entry payment because they are still on a part Newstart allowance and are taking up part-time work. If that job does not pan outâwhich sometimes does happen, for a variety of reasonsâthen they can come back again and get another advance. I think it is a pretty fair kind of thingâfair to the taxpayer and fairer to the person than what is currently provided with the employment payment which we are proposing now to abolish with the introduction of this measure.

The advice I have had is that, quite frequently, this is when you get petty crime, with people without any money at all trying to quickly get themselves a bit of spare cash. talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:
(1) Schedule 4, item 13, page 77 (after line 30), after subsection (2), insert:

(2A) If the person is qualified for a crisis payment because of section 1061JG, the amount of a crisis payment payable to the person is the fortnightly amount at the maximum basic rate of the social security pension or social security benefit that is payable to the person.

One Nation believes that mandatory imprisonment and severe punishment for offenders involved in violent crimes, organised crime and drug trafficking are essential. The protection of our citizens and the prevention of repeat offences should be of the utmost concern and be foremost in the determination of appropriate sentencing. Lengthy custodial sentences should be the only reward for those offenders. We must protect our society.

Over 25 per cent of prisoners admitted to Queensland jails are fine defaulters. It is expensive and counterproductive to jail these offenders. In the light of that in Queensland, the National-Liberal coalition has introduced a private member's bill that reflects one of One Nation's policies, that fine defaulters should be kept out of jail. Further, they should have their income or social security garnisheed at its source, to ensure the fine payment. In case of extreme hardship, they should be sentenced to community service.

By not jailing fine defaulters except as a last resort, it is anticipated that in Queensland there would be a saving of approximately $12.6 million from the Corrective Services budget. It costs the state taxpayers in Queensland approximately $45,000 per annum to incarcerate a prisoner. In Queensland, Pauline Hanson's One Nation state parliamentarian teams have been influencing the government's simplistic policies to bring them up to date with the expression of the will of the people. It comes as no surprise that we have to implement simplistic policies in this chamber that are obviously driven by economic expediency and not by the needs of a particular disadvantaged group within our community.

This government is proposing to halve the allowance currently provided for newly released prisoners. This crisis payment was introduced to provide some assistance to persons who had a very high level of need. This help was in the form of a current special benefit prison release payment, which twice provided a one-week payment. This payment was designed to assist newly released prisoners to obtain accommodation and transport facilities and to meet living expenses while integrating into the community. The proposed one-off crisis payment, being a one-week payment, provides less financial assistance.

A research program was conducted recently in Queensland by the Prisoners Legal Service Inc., and I congratulate them on their work and their findings. The Prison and Debt project was designed to inquire into the effects of imprisonment on the debt levels of prisoners and to ascertain the nature and extent of any flow-on social or criminological effects of indebtedness in the prison population to families and prisoners in the wider community. The project's desired outcome was to identify and remedy the detrimental effects of imprisonment on prisoners' debt levels. The project identified that debt levels for prisoners increase while they are in jail and that their debts frequently rise to such levels that they cannot repay them or effectively manage them upon release. A key finding of the report was that 49 per cent of those interviewed admitted to committing further crimes upon release, in order to repay burgeoning debt.

The report identified that most prison sentences served in Australia are short. The Prisoners Legal Service identified that over 21 per cent of people serve less than three months. Sentences this short can, however, have serious ramifications, including the loss of job, home, car or all personal possessions with the growth of debt. Debts of imprisonment are often additional to debts that prisoners are already experiencing difficulties with or cannot repay. It is worth reminding the Senate that 25 per cent of prisoners are fine defaulters. It is reasonable that a proportion would have paid their fines, if finances had been available. So we have a cat chasing its tail.

The community suffers by the release of significant numbers of prisoners with an unpaid level of debt, a debt they cannot repay. The effect is in terms not only of a possible increase in the crime rate but of an increase in the number of despairing citizens who may not commit a crime but are forced to live on the edge of society. These are the people who prick our conscience when we leave our restaurants or shows and see them cold, lonely and hungry, wandering the streets.

Many of the simplest of remedies, if implemented, will contribute to ensuring that the families of prisoners are enabled to maintain a stable family unit. A newly released prisoner deserves to be given an opportunity to return to society with the means to regain their dignity. They deserve to be given a chance to overcome their punishment and to reunite with their family's lives.

A case study by the Prisoners Legal Service in Queensland demonstrates why One Nation has a policy committed to keeping fine defaulters out of jail. I wish to relate this case study. A single parent with a two-year-old child was left struggling to pay three loans, for a car, furniture and a housing loan bond. She obtained part-time work but did not declare it on her benefit form and kept drawing her full benefit. When Centrelink became aware, she began to pay back the money, selling her TV and stereo and falling behind in other bills. She was charged with fraud and, by the time she fronted the court, she had paid all the money back to the government. She received a three-month sentence and was taken immediately to the watchhouse. Her mother cared for her son, but relations between mum and the daughter were strained.

Prisoners are not allowed to phone government departments from jail. She incorrectly received two further payments from Centrelink but was unable to call them from jail to cancel the payments. Her flat was broken into when she was in jail. Intruders lived in the flat for about three weeks, gaining access to her bankcard signature and thereby withdrawing her Centrelink overpayments. They trashed the flat and left a large phone bill. On release from jail, this lady had a debt to Centrelink and a debt to the Department of Housing and owed money for gas, electricity and telephone. The chances of being reunited with her son were minimal, as she could not obtain a private flat to rent.

Do not think that One Nation is going soft on crime. We are not. We firmly believe that perpetrators of heinous crimes deserve to have the law book thrown at them. The rights of the victims and their families must be taken into account during sentencing. We firmly believe that prisoners should face punishment, restitution and rehabilitation in that order. However, state governments continue to jail fine defaulters. We are only exacerbating an already untenable position. These sentences create disastrous changes in many people's lives, including the loss of jobs, homes and personal possessions. Increasing debt levels make the punishment out of all proportion to the debt. Then the federal government withdraws the little support it was offering.

The Catholic Prison Ministry states that they believe that people will usually make the choice to live a lawful lifestyle when they are supported in an environment affirming their self-worth and providing for their basic needs. The crisis payment at its current level goes some way towards assisting newly released prisoners, who have paid their debt through their time in jail, to be given some opportunity to successfully move back into society.

The government's approach always seems to be based on how they can save moneyâwhich group is the least vocal and least respected in the community; where is the little Aussie who can be squeezed a little more tightly? The upper crust hardly have to worry about the potential of re-offending as they live in blue ribbon seats and are insulated from this problem. The average Aussie, however, must take it on the chin, grin and bear it and then grizzle as insurance companies refuse to re-insure their properties. I would invite senators to stay in homes in Goodna and Darra where insurance companies have refused to insure vehicles, homes and contents. We have a government whose only intervention is to decrease the level of support available to a newly released prisoner so that they can integrate back into the community.

Let Pauline Hanson's One Nation point out some costs. We need effective strategies that could lessen the distress caused by those who are incarcerated. This government seems to only know how to slash and burn and allocate funds to those most disadvantaged. On introduction into jail it would make sense for Centrelink to provide all prisoners with a form to be filled out by those receiving benefits thus advising of their sentence. Thereby, Centrelink would avoid paying funds incorrectly and would avoid incurring the cost of reclaiming those payments. Centrelink would allow three months breathing space for prisoners after release before commencing to deduct payments from them in order to facilitate a smooth transition into mainstream life. The Child Support Agency could provide prisoners with a form to be filled out by those with a debt to CSA advising of the sentence, thereby saving the tax department unnecessary costs in catching the defaulters.

These recommendations are just some commonsense approaches provided in the excellent report of the Prisoners Legal Service in Queensland. We cannot and will not support any cutback in crisis payments to newly released prisoners. Unlike some in the government, we continually care for those in need. We want to see them given a chance to retain their self-esteem and self-worth. We do not want to see more displaced, homeless Australians.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âI can see that Senator Harris has his heart in the right place for prisoners. Unfortunately, a lot of his speech and certainly his allegations were ill founded. There are no savings at all in this proposal. We are not halving the allowance, as he said. In fact, the amount of money going to the prisoners remains the same. We are bringing it forward so that they have it when they come out of jail. It is a benefit to prisoners. It is helping them.

speech.para: They get three weeks pay as they did before, but before they got it after they got out of jail. Now they will get one week as they go out of jail and two weeks as soon as they have signed on the dotted line. If they are in real hardship they can get an advanced payment. I am sorry, Senator, but I am afraid some of the things you said were based on a misunderstanding.

If you doubled the rate of the crisis payment for all people, it would cost nearly $2.4 million a year. If you simply did it for prisoners you would be up around $500,000 on top of what is paid now. There is no way that we are trying to cut money to the prisoners. We believe that the society is not served by having prisoners leave prison with no money to buy food or get shelter. That is why we are introducing the measure. We are bringing the payment up front so that they get it earlier.

I am distressed that you would think that that is what we are doing. It is a beneficial measure. It is a beneficial measure for, say, people whose homes have been caught in a bushfire and who suddenly need an immediate payment. It is a beneficial measure for people who are escaping domestic violence. I would have thought you would have endorsed it wholeheartedly. It is a new measure, but it is not cutting any money from the prisoners. It is bringing their payment forward so that they do not leave jail without anything in their pocket to buy a bus fare.

talk.start.para: âThe Democrats agree with a lot of what Senator Harris said and the intent of his amendment. The government should be congratulated for introducing a crisis payment. It is extending much needed assistance to a fairly small group of people, but, nonetheless, a group of people who will very much benefit from the measure. Sometimes we deal with measures that only deal with a small group of people and may seem fairly insignificant in the scheme of things, but for that small group of people and those individuals it can make an enormous amount of difference. The fact that the numbers are not huge should not detract from that.

speech.para: I would like a bit more clarification from the minister in relation to the way things operate currently for released prisoners, as opposed to how things will operate under this new crisis payment. I have received representations from the Welfare Rights Network about the impact of this measure on prisoners. I am not criticising the positive aspects of the measure in relation to other people, but certainly they had concerns that it would lead to a disadvantage for some newly released prisoners compared to their current situation.

The excellent report Senator Harris quoted extensively from is one that bears close study. It is an important area. I am not sure I would agree with the full thrust of all of Senator Harris's rhetoric about prisoners and our jail system, but his concerns and the concerns put forward by the Queensland Prisoners Legal Service are very important. Regardless of your views about crime and punishment and law and order, I think everyone in the community would recognise, even from a self-interest point of view, that it is totally counterproductive to release people back into the community in a situation where they are in extreme hardship or very pressing debt. A very small amount of extra assistance at that time when they re-enter the community can save an enormous amount of money down the track by making it less likely that they will re-offend and more likely that they will have an opportunity to re-establish themselves in the community. Obviously, that is not only in their interests but in the interests of the entire community.

So the principle that Senator Harris outlined is one that I wholeheartedly agree with. Personally, I think where necessary, extra assistance should be provided to released prisoners over and above others for the reason I just outlinedâthat it is in the community's interest to ensure people are able to get back on their feet as effectively as possible. It is in no-one's interests to have people re-offend or go into a situation of poverty. Indeed, it is never in the community's interests to have anyone in ongoing and entrenched poverty.

Just returning to the issue of how the system works now: my understandingâwhich the minister can correct and I am sure will correct if it is incorrectâis that currently people can receive the special benefit prison release payment, which is designed to provide immediate cash assistance. That recognises that newly released prisoners can incur delays in obtaining employment or social security payment, and it provides up to one week of payment of special benefit at twice the normal rate. That is my understanding of how things are able to operate now, whereas the proposed one-off crisis payment contained in this schedule will provide only one week's payment at the normal rate. That is where Senator Harris was coming from in suggesting that they will get half of what they currently get now.

That is my understanding from what I have been advised. If that is the case, then certainly I would be supportive of Senator Harris's amendmentâfor the reason of restoring the situation as well as for the broader reason that it is in the community's interest to provide extra assistance for released prisoners to some extent over and above the detail that I have asked about now.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âI just double-checked in case I had in any way misunderstood or misled anybody. The fact is, as I told Senator Harris, the level of assistance available to released prisoners claiming a social security allowance will not change under the new arrangementâthe level of assistance is three weeks pay for three weeks. The difference is when they get it. Released prisoners will get the equivalent of three weeks payment in the first fortnight after release, as they do currently. They will get the crisis payment plus one week's pension or benefit when they are released, with the remaining week's pension or benefit at the end of the first fortnight. Pensioners who are released from prison will receive the same level of assistance as allowees.

speech.para: Senator Harris, you may be interested to know why this was necessary. With the New South Wales truth in sentencing legislation, prisoners can now be released at midnight, and this will prevent the hardship that is occasioned by people being put outside the jail door with no money at all. You made the suggestion in your speech about filling in a Centrelink form, et cetera. When we were in opposition, we found that the previous government did not know people were in jail and were continuing to pay themâsometimes for years. That obviously was not a system that could continue and, as part of our major effort against fraud and ensuring compliance in the social security system, we introduced data links and exchange of information with the corrective services around Australia so we could prevent that happening. Prior to that, the Commonwealth did not know when people were in jail. Now we have the ability to get this money to people earlier than previously. We are not changing the level of money that they are entitled to.

talk.start.para: âThank you, Minister, for conveying that the government's intention was to move towards ensuring that these payments did not continue while prisoners were in jail. As I explained earlier, unfortunately it is still happening. So if there is a form that is supplied by Centrelink, we need to go back and look at that process. In this lady's case, her predicament was that not only was she paid those two payments while she was in jail but somebody accessed her flat, accessed her cards and actually withdrew that amount. So the reality is that the problem still exists at this time and that definitely needs addressing.

speech.para: To come back to the reason for the amendment that we have moved, it has been clearly indicated to us, not only by the Catholic Prison Ministry but also by other people that we have spoken to, that on their reading of the bill the prisoners will be disadvantaged.

talk.start.para: âThey will not be disadvantaged.

âI appreciate the minister saying that they will get one of the payments earlier, and I commend the government for that. But it will also leave the prisoners in a situation where, two weeks out of jail, they will have a longer period while they are waiting for another payment. I still commend the amendment to the chamber, based on the understanding of both the Catholic Prison Ministry's interpretation of this bill and the interpretation of other agencies that we have discussed the issue with.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âI would like to very briefly say that I am disappointed that the people who came to you do not appear to have come to me; I might have been able to explain this to them. They are labouring under a misapprehension, and they have obviously advised you accordingly. People will not in any way be disadvantaged, either in level of payment or in timing of receipt of payment. They will be advantaged; it is solely to their benefit. I am disappointed that they have misread that. That is the fact of the matter.

speech.para: If you have any examples of where the connection between information going from the state corrective services department to Centrelink is not working properly or where there is some associated crime being committed as a result of somebody being in jail, you might come and talk to me about it to see whether there is anything that we can do to make the system even better.

talk.start.para: âAt the risk of breaking my duck, I indicate that the opposition are inclined to support the government and oppose the request on the basis of the explanation given by the minister, which was that the level of funding under the crisis payment arrangements will not disadvantage prisoners and that they will get money earlier to assist in their transition. On that basis, while I appreciate the points Senator Harris made, we are inclined to accept the government's argument that they have adequately dealt with those concerns under the schedule dealing with the crisis payment. We will be voting with the government on this occasion.

speech.para: Request not agreed to.

talk.start.para: âWe now move to Democrat amendment No. 2 on sheet 1544. The question is that schedule 5 stand as printed.

âI would like to speak to this schedule and indicate the reasons why the Democrats are opposed to it. It relates to the newly arrived residents waiting period, which is a topic that I have spoken on a number of times in this chamber over the last couple of years. I will not go into a fully-fledged storm of outrage. As I said earlier on, I try to approach social security issues and immigration issuesâthis one combines the twoâin a non-inflammatory way, although I must say that this particular aspect of the two-year waiting period is one that I do have a bit of trouble retaining a dispassionate approach to, because I find it one of the more distasteful aspects of social security policy over recent years. The measure itself is only a small aspect of that, and there is an argument of consistency in relation to the measure which the government has put forward to promote consistency in the application of the waiting period. It relates to applying the newly arrived residents waiting period to aspects of the Health Insurance Act and health care cards.

speech.para: Whilst it might not sound like a particularly significant thing, it is a measure that will, according to the explanatory memorandum, in a couple of years time save around $13Â½ million. As I repeatedly point out, saving taxpayers' money is a good thing. But taking assistance away from people in need is not a good thing. In many aspects, this whole issue of the two-year waiting period is a false economy. Not providing assistance to people when they are first settling in the country can make it a lot more difficult for them to establish themselves and can often lead to greater cost, not just to the public purse but to the social fabric down the track.

The two-year waiting period is a measure that the Democrats have consistently opposed, and we continue to oppose it. I know that the ALP initially opposed the measure, and it came into being through the support of Senator Harradine. At one stage an attempt of mine to repeal it was unsuccessful because of the vote of Senator Harradine. We had a brief Senate committee inquiry into it, by which time we came back here and I had another attempt at repealing it; Senator Harradine had been convinced but unfortunately the ALP had ceased to be convinced. So once again the measure remained in place. That was a source of some disappointment to me, I must say, but obviously I did not argue quite as expertly as I thought I had. Perhaps I had assumed, given Labor's previous support for the position of removing the two-year waiting period for special benefits, that that position would be retained.

In the Senate committee inquiry, the ALP produced a suggestion, which I think was repeated here in this chamber, that there would be a need to review the two-year waiting period and its impacts after a couple of years. That couple of years has now passed and we certainly think that it would be a good idea to assess more broadly the impact that the two-year waiting period is having across the board.

Certainly a lot of information has been provided to me from people who are working out in the community with migrants that it is having a significant negative impactâit is generating hardship for a number of people, for a number of families. Again, that number may not be huge but, for those who are suffering hardship as a result of this measure, telling them that they are only a small number does not really help them very much. It is still a measure that is causing very significant suffering, and I think it sends out some very unhelpful messages more broadly about some of the stereotypes about migrants coming here to go on social security and bludge off the Australian community and things like thatâsome of those more distasteful suggestions that are voiced on this issue from time to time. I think this measure gives implicit support to some of those comments from other people.

The Democrats continue to be very concerned about the impact of the two-year waiting period. This schedule has only a small impact on that in terms of its extension to health related issues. I will refrain from moving another amendment to try to change the two-year waiting period to enable access to special benefit because I can reasonably assume what the outcome would be in the chamber. Nonetheless, I indicate that the Democrats' concerns are still as strong as ever.

I urge all other parties to reconsider this issue in terms of the actual impact it is having on people in this community. As I say, with this schedule in particularâthe specific measure we are opposingâit is another $13Â½ million of assistance in health issues which can be amongst the most important areas of need for people in the community. Oftentimes they can find a way of getting by in terms of income but those extra health costs, particularly if they have children, can really make the difference. I am assuming that the Democrats will be unsuccessful in getting this schedule deleted from the legislation, but I urge all parties to keep considering this issue and the real impact that it is having on families out in the community at the moment.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âVery briefly, I will respond to Senator Bartlett. Most of his contribution was directed to the wider issue of the two-year waiting period generally. The schedule that we have before us now relates purely to New Zealanders. If the Democrats were to be successful in their opposition to this schedule, it would mean that, despite an agreement between the governments of New Zealand and Australia, Australians would have to serve a two-year waiting period in New Zealand for benefits in New Zealand but New Zealanders coming here would be able to access benefits straightaway.

speech.para: I do not think that is something the Australian community would think was fair. We see it as fair that all migrants or anybody coming to live in our country should be treated the same unless they are refugees or humanitarian migrants. This has been negotiated between the two governments so that there is equal treatment of the citizens of both countries in each of the countries. I am surprised that the Democrats would want to have Australians treated one way in New Zealand and New Zealanders able to access benefits straightaway in Australia. The government does not support the Democrats' opposition to this schedule at all.

talk.start.para: âOn behalf of the Labor opposition, we will not be supporting the Democrat opposition to this schedule, although it will no doubt cause me some grief at my rugby club, which is 98 per cent New Zealanders. We try to encourage players to come across the Tasman to play.

speech.para: Senator Newman interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âWe are still very much an amateur club, Minister. Some have trouble getting work permits, too. On this occasion we will not be supporting the Democrats.
âThe question is that schedule 5 stand as printed.

interjection.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Requests Nos 11 and 12 on sheet EA260 revised (by Senator Newman)âby leaveâagreed to:
That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendments:

Add:

; or (d) satisfies the Secretary that the person has moved from his or her original place of residence because of an extreme circumstance which made it reasonable for the person to move to the new place of residence (for example, the person had been subjected to domestic or family violence in the original place of residence).

talk.start.para: âI wish to oppose schedule 9. This is the changes the government proposes to the liquid assets test. Schedule 9 tightens the rules under which people can be precluded from receiving social security benefits for up to 13 weeks on the basis of their liquid assets. The schedule provides that a person who is engaged in full-time study cannot be regarded as unemployed for the purpose of the liquid assets test waiting period. The changes will have the effect of making an individual wait up to an additional 13 weeks for unemployment benefits if they elect to study before seeking employment. If someone makes the decision to study, they may face a maximum waiting period of up to 26 weeks rather than just 13 weeks if they decide to go straight on to unemployment benefits. We see this as a disincentive to study and acquire new skills and we have much the same concerns as we did about the education entry payment.

speech.para: I understand what the government's rationale is but, as we understand it, the provision will deny 2,500 Newstart recipients access to the allowance and about 60 sickness allowance recipients access in a year. These are people who might otherwise be caught by the government's proposal and be denied access to the allowances. It seems to us that there is no question of double dipping here. It is a question of whether you provide encouragement for people to study and not put potential barriers in the way of people moving from study to employment or to seeking employment.

We think that the impact of this measure is to actually make it less attractive for people to seek to study and puts another barrier or consideration in their way in terms of them seeking to study and then seeking to join the work force. We do not think that disincentive is a good thing. We think the current provision is a better way of treating students moving between study and the work force. We do not think the government's proposition is good policy, and we will be opposing it. We would be better off leaving the current situation as it is and allowing students to move from study to employment without this further barrier.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âSince the liquid assets test was previously before the parliament, we have found that the way the legislation has been interpreted by the tribunals means that it is not being applied consistently. As a result of that, schedule 9 is to provide consistency across payment types, which seems a pretty fair way of approaching something. We in this chamber do not generally endorse payments or add-ons to payments being treated in different ways or special conditions for payments being very different across payment types. This measure simply ensures consistency in the application of the liquid assets waiting period. In addition, a person transferring from Austudy payment to a Newstart allowance would not normally have to serve a liquid assets test waiting period, because they would be considered to have been in receipt of an income support payment for a continuous period. The government therefore do not intend to support the opposition's proposal to oppose schedule 9.

âThe Democrats are also concerned with the impact of schedule 9. It is, again, small in the scheme of thingsâ$1.5 million in a couple of years timeâbut it will have an impact on some individual people. It often seems to be the case when we are rationalising inconsistencies and providing for uniform treatment that it ends up being a savings measure rather than a cost, and this is another example of that. More broadly, the Democrats' view is that this provision will act as a disincentive to study by increasing the amount of time that people who undertake study will have to wait to access income support. As is frequently said by people from all parties in this chamber, providing incentives for people to undertake education is a very important aim. This measure will act in the opposite direction and, for that reason, the Democrats will not support it.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âI recognise that I am not going to win this vote, and it is a pity. In our view, a loophole has now been opened by virtue of a decision. It will be used by more people now that it is available. This schedule was an attempt to close that loophole. I point out that an AAT decision recently held that a person could be unemployed while undertaking a full course of study. The effect of that decision for Newstart claimants is that education leavers with liquid assets in excess of the established limits can avoid the application of the liquid assets test waiting period despite having significant liquid assets. To me, that is a nonsense, and I would have thought most Australians would have thought it was a nonsense too. I am disappointed that the parties in this chamber are prepared to see a loophole open that will only be pushed wider as it becomes known. Nevertheless, I hear the views of the other parties.
âThe question is that schedule 9 stand as printed.

interjection.para: Question resolved in the negative.

talk.start.para: âIn opposing schedule 10, I cannot support a pensioner education supplement amendment that so callously removes what is in reality a small payment to some of the disadvantaged members of our community. It has been identified that 97 per cent of the greatest losers will be sole parents. The remaining losers will be carer payment recipients. The government always commends itself on caring for carers but then, in the next breath, it removes a small benefit from a group of people who are prepared to stay home to look after their loved ones. I cannot support a motion that primarily removes from support for sole parents an opportunity to improve their mental or physical wellbeing and, in doing so, prepare for their future and for the future of their children.

speech.para: It would appear the Liberal Party's economic rationalists are at it again in what will be a short-term gain for the government's coffersâapproximately $6.5 million in 2001-02âand long-term pain for the people who will eventually be required to move back into the work force. Those people will find their skill levels seriously depleted in an environ ment that all sides of politics agree is changing rapidly, particularly with our new technology. The irony is that, in the long term, governments will pay more, as they will have to offer training and educational opportunities for those who will now be both long-term unemployed and unskilled.

The government is saying that, if you study only 25 per cent to 50 per cent of a full-time course, your costs are automatically halved. Depending on the course, you may well find that you still have to travel as many days as you did previously. Your books can vary significantly in cost from subject to subject, but you will still need to the same amount of books and, as of 1 July, you will also have to manage a goods and services tax. The funds are not designed to provide a pat on the back for using your initiative and pursuing further education whilst forced to stay at home. They were to assistâand I stress the word `assist'âin keeping your skills, knowledge and abilities to a level that works towards keeping you work ready.

The skills obtained from further educational opportunities also provide social and emotional benefits. Single parents and carers in particular often become isolated from mainstream society. Educational opportunities provide these community members with an ability to mix with others both older and younger than themselves. It is not unusual to find that students find new support networks that can assist them in developing new parenting, caring and recreational outlets that assist in maintaining a healthy mind and body.

The reduction of payments to part-time students who study between 25 per cent and 50 per cent of the full-time course demonstrates a lack of commitment by the government to provide worthwhile educational opportunities to all members of the community. It demonstrates simplicity in the way this determination has been made in that part-time study does not necessarily equate to a lesser amount of outlay for the student. It impacts on those people whom this government has indicated it particularly cares aboutâthat is, the carers. It does nothing to support sole parents who have a genuine desire to either keep their skills up to date or improve their skills in many areas, including work, parenting and social skills. For this reason, I will not support the schedule.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âThe pensioner education supplement measure will amend the rate of payment to better reflect the study load being undertaken by a pensioner. It is not a question of economic rationalism; it is just straight commonsense. If you are doing a half load, you do not get a full-time supplement. If you are doing a full-time load, you get a full-time supplement. Pensioners on a study load of 50 per cent or greater will continue to get the full rate of PES, which is $60 a fortnight, while pensioners undertaking a study load of between 25 per cent and 50 per cent will get the half rate of PES, which is $30 a fortnight.

speech.para: The pensioner education supplement for disability support pensioners and veterans affairs pensioners will remain unchanged. In passing, I suggest that people who are getting income support as a parenting payment (single) or carers who are getting a carers payment would, one would presume, find it pretty difficult to take on a full-time study load and still maintain their caring role. I think the reality is that a large proportion of people would in fact be taking a half load or maybe even less because the role of carer is very demanding. It is unrealistic to think that you can take on a full study load and be a full-time carer at the same time.

The government are very supportive of carers, as Senator Harris has acknowledged. In each budget since we came into government, we have done things that needed to be done to help carers. We continue to have a very keen concern for them. Carers and people on parenting payment (single) can also get access to the JET schemeâthe Jobs, Education and Training schemeâwhich helps people get the skills to get into the work force, to get off welfare dependency, to be self-sufficient and to have the dignity of being self-reliant. The government are totally committed to the concept of people being able to improve their state, educational ability and skills. We just think it is pretty rationalâif that is what economic rationalism isâfor people to be paid for the amount of study that they are doing. That is what this reflects. It reflects the amount of study against the amount of supplement. At the same time, people are still getting their full pension payment in social security. There is no effect on that. I think it is a very reasonable thing to do. I think the taxpayer would, too.

talk.start.para: âThis section deals with the pensioner education supplement, which is a non-taxable supplementary payment of $60 per fortnight for pensioners who qualify as either full-time students or concessional study load students. It is designed, as I understand it, to assist pensioners towards financial independence through participation in education courses. It is another incentive towards education. The government is proposing to cut that payment to $30 for those who have only a part-time study load. Whilst it may seem logical on the surface that you get half the payment if you are doing half the study, I do not see this payment as operating in that way. I see it as a basic incentive payment for pensioners, regardless of their study load, to undertake education.

speech.para: If you are going to apply a pure logic principle, I cannot see the purely rational reason why the government is exempting disability support pensioners from this measure. It has said that it is in recognition that people have less capacity to increase their study loads in response to this change. That may be the case. For the reasons the minister just outlined, I am sure many carers would also have difficulty in increasing their study loads in response to this change. I cannot see any simple logical reason why disability pensioners should retain the full payment despite studying part time while other pensioners now have their payment cut in half. My understanding is that this will impact on nearly 8,000 recipients of the pensioner education supplement. I cannot see a reason why that payment should be reduced. It would clearly provide less assistance in the purpose that the payment was designed for, which is to assist pensioners to undertake education.

It seems to me to be basically a cost cutting measure that will hit the pensions of sole parent pensioners and carers. The Democrats believe that we need to be doing all we can to assist people in undertaking education. This will reduce the income of a significant number of people by $30 a fortnight for a reason that seems fairly flimsy to me. The Democrats will be joining Senator Harris of One Nation in opposing this schedule.

talk.start.para: âI must say that I am a bit torn on this proposal. I think it is fair to say that the Labor Party accept that there is a sound basis for the sort of approach the government has adopted. If you look at the Austudy pensioner education supplement that the payment is being based on in terms of the study load, it has a basic logic to itâthat the commitment given to study will be dependent, and the costs associated with it will be dependent, in part on the amount of study undertaken. So we have an inclination to say that there is some sense to that. We obviously have had a great deal of criticism of the government's approach in terms of support for sole parents and the cuts to JET and what we see as the government's under-utilisation of work in that regard.
âThere has been an expansion of JETâit has been expanded.

âYou made early budget cuts to JET, Minister. As I understand it, Centrelink is not meeting its targets for the number of participants in the scheme, after the government's cutbacks. So we do think the government needs to do better in support for sole parents who are making the transition from welfare to work. The Labor Party is concerned to have a much better strategy for that transition, particularly for sole parents, so I have some sympathies with the concerns raised about this being a measure that seems to be cost cutting rather than achieving any great benefit for those seeking to undertake study.

speech.para: On balance, the Labor Party has agreed to support the government's position because of the rationale of having the allowance based on a connection with the amount of study undertakenâthat is, a payment that is made in recognition of the costs associated with that study. I think Senator Bartlett raised a question which I was going to raise that I would appreciate the minister answering, and that is the question about the disability support pension and why that is treated differently. I would like to understand the government's rationale for that. It is clear in the explanatory memorandum that that is exempted and I am not quite sure that I understand why. The minister adds that there is also a second exemption for veterans. I think it would be useful, both for me and for the record, for the government to explain the rationale for that. On balance, the Labor opposition will not be opposing the schedule.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âEssentially, the thinking behind the exemptions was that it is often very difficult for people with disabilities to undertake a full-time study load. From memoryâI could not vouch for this for certain because it is a while since I looked at the detail of thisâa fairly small proportion of people who had disabilities were taking a full-time load, and this was coupled with the fact that they usually have greater costs in accessing a service like education. I think that was the main reason for the exemptions.
âAnd the veterans?

âI think part of the rationale there was largely that they tend to be older people who also frequently have problems with mobility. It concerned only those veterans who were recipients of the invalidity service pension or invalidity income support supplement paid under the veterans' act. So it was very much focused on people's invalidity.

âIt is pleasing to note Senator Newman's recognition of the impact of the workload on carers and single parents, but I would still like to highlight the outcome of what the government are intending to do. First of all, in reality, it is going to become a disincentive to people who have this heavy workload of caring for their children or a close relative to embark on these educational programs. As a result of that, in the long term the costs will be greater to the government. If they had provided this extra assistance to these people and helped them to be able to further their education while they were carers or while they were single parents, these people would be in a far better position to enter the work force at the end of that period. I believe that, while the government may be making some short-term gain in implementing this reduction, in actuality they are creating a higher cost in the long term.

speech.para: It is therefore very difficult to understand the rationale and the compassion of the government in reducing this payment to these people. They obviously need all the incentives that we can give to assist them to keep up with the changes in technology. These changes are immense now and I believe they will continue to have a more substantial impact on a person's ability to become re-employed. Therefore, I believe the government is, in actuality, being short-sighted in moving this reduction in assistance.

talk.start.para: âThe question is that schedule 10 stand as printed.

interjection.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: âWe now move to government amendment No. 17 on sheet FC206 revised.

(a) the Secretary determines:
(i) that a claim by a person for a social security benefit is to be granted; or

talk.start.para: âOrder! It being almost 12.45 p.m., I call on matters of public interest.

âToday I propose to speak in a continuing debate on the topic of regional development in Australia. When I last spoke on this area, I was speaking about the need for us to move to a system in this country where regions are given assistance to lift themselves up by their bootstraps. The research shows that, rather than top-down assistance on a massive scale as we saw under the Whitlam government with the creation of the failed growth centres concept, what will work a lot better across regional Australiaâand in particular in smaller centres which are struggling in such difficult economic circumstancesâis an approach where their leadership is developed and honed towards growing their own economies. The role of government in that case is one of assisting that leadership and those attributes of a particular area to develop.

speech.para: Last time I was talking about the town of Walcha on the New England in New South Wales and how government decisions, state and federal, could mean the difference between the death of that town and dynamic, robust growth. Today I want to start by talking about another small centre, Hamilton, in western Victoria, before going on to looking at a wider region. I visited this area several weeks ago at the invitation of David Hawker who is the member for Wannon. He wanted me to visit in particular the educational facilities in his area. However, I actually managed to get an overview of the area. It is a very interesting contrast to see the ways in which different types of government assistance over time have impacted on the western Victorian district.

One of the major intervention impacts was in the early 1980s when the then government supported the establishment of the Alcoa aluminium smelter in that region at Portland. The problem with that project was that the government had taken power from the eastern Gippsland area and taken it right across to western Victoria. It was good for regional development in that area, but it raises a question about major government intervention if it then creates a situation that might put a particularly large company at some economic risk.

What people have to understand about the aluminium smelting process is that aluminium is really just solid electricity. There is so much power going into smelting aluminium that the best and most efficient place to put the smelter is very close to the power stations. The reason why the fourth largest aluminium plant in the world is at Tomago in Newcastle is that there are an enormous number of power stations in that area. Down in Hamilton and in that area in western Victoria we had that type of government intervention, but we really need to develop more than that. Governments cannot save the economy of those regions by constantly putting in large projects because often those larger projects employ only a few hundred people. What we need is a more dynamic, sustainable, grassroots, bottoms-up type approach to support the economy in these areas.

I went to have a look at what Hamilton had going for it. It was, in the past, a major wool area in this country. I have been to a number of wool areas; they all seem to claim that they are the home of the world's finest wool, and Hamilton was no exception. But of course the wool industry has fallen on hard times, and in a lot of the wool-growing areas and on a lot of grazing land they are growing blue gum timber. It is a very fast growing timber and gets to full maturity in 12 years. That industry employs people when you plant the trees and it employs people when you cut them down, but it does not employ many people in between. So they need to look at their strengths in this small areaâthis town of 10,000.

When I met with the people thereâI met with the community leaders the night before and then did inspections the next dayâI discovered that Hamilton has a tremendous capacity in the area of education. Not only has it got excellent high schools but also it has an excellent interface between education and the rural industry. It has set up training and extension programs for agriculture that not only serve western Victoria but also serve the whole of Australia. The programs are growing out of that area. The RMIT university has established a centre there for the work and projects of the university which could be extended a lot further to provide education on a more comprehensive basis for people in western Victoria. Other universities have set up campuses on such a basis in some of the smaller centres, and when speaking to the people at RMIT we really encouraged them to do further work in that area.

But the fascinating thing about education in that area is the high schools. The high schools in that region are unique in that one is a boarding schoolâthe last one west of Melbourne, so it certainly has a comparative advantage thereâand there is a range of high quality private schools. I met with all the principalsâagain, with the local member, David Hawkerâand that seemed to be a necessary catalyst. It was an idea they had thought about for some time, but when we had the meeting all the ideas they had seemed to jell in a cooperative arrangement. So they are going to do cooperative things in marketing, particularly marketing themselves to other countries as an area in regional Australia you can come to to get a high quality high school education and then move on to university. They are also looking at cost sharing in a number of ways, such as across the three schools in subjects that are not in particularly high demand. A number of the languages come to mind: different campuses could offer different languages and then students from the different campuses could, say, attend Indonesian or German or whatever the language class was. You would then get a critical mass in terms of size of class. They are looking at some of the economies in that area. It is a matter of these smaller areas identifying their strengths and then growing those strengths.

I want to move now to a contrasting area. The resource base of the western Victorian area, particularly Hamilton, was fairly light in terms of its diversity. I will move on to one that has terrific diversity and potential, but it has lost many jobs: I refer to the Upper Hunter. With the downsizing of BHP there has been a major focusâby state and federal governments and all sorts of groupsâon the Lower Hunter and what is happening there. But in the Upper Hunter there are major problems because of the number of ways in which its economy is adjusting and shifting. It is a very strong economy but it is going through a lot of technological change and a lot of adjustments to our competitive market position.

I want to briefly move through the strengths of the Upper Hunter and the way in which industry is going. Its primary driving force is coal. Coal in the Hunter and the Upper Hunter has a terrifically bright future. This is shown by the fact that the coal loader at Newcastle has been expanded. They would not put $90 million into a new coal loader if they did not think we were going to have increased production. Production will increase, but what is happening is that new mines are opening up and are creating employment but they are high-tech operations and they do not employ as many as the older mines used to employ, and in this highly competitive coal market some of the older, less efficient mines in the same area are shutting down. So you have got mines opening up and mines shutting down, and the net effect is on employment in that, because of high-tech procedures, you have got a drop in the work force.

The second areaâand it feeds off the coal minesâis power generation. There are two major power plants in the Upper Hunter, including the very high-tech Bayswater Power Station. Again, power has moved into a competitive market. We are competing particularly with Victoria. One of the effects of creating greater efficiencies in a power stationâthis has occurred in the last 18 monthsâis that the number of people it used to take to manage one power station now manage two. The work force has gone from 1,400 to 700 in that time. So that competitive market we have in Australia which is driving down power prices and improving the economy has an effect which we have got to take very much into accountâthe fact that a smaller, more efficient work force creates an employment problem for us.

The third areaâand I now am moving on to areas where government can actually make a bit of a differenceâis the area of forestry and timber. The regional forest agreements, RFAs, that have been brought in by the Carr government are shutting down major timber towns across the Hunter Valleyâtowns like Dungog, places like Bulahdelah. The focus of quite a number of towns was the timber industry and sawmills in those towns. The way the RFAs have been set up means there is not a sufficient supply of timber for many of those towns, and already the mills are shutting down and people are losing their jobs.

This is something that, if we got the balance right in terms of sustainable development in timber, we could actually change. People in the Gloucester area in the Hunter Valley have told me, for example, that they had it set up in such a way that they could log timber and not have to return to the same coup for 200 years. That is a sustainable system. But, for some strange reason, in the RFA process in the Gloucester area they locked up so much timber that it has not become viable for that areaâsomething the state governments certainly could do something about in terms of jobs.

The other area that has been a victim of changing technology and changing markets in the Upper Hunter has been the abattoirs. A high-tech abattoir has been developed at Scone, and that is expanding and doing well. The nearby town of Aberdeen had an older, more inefficient abattoir, which closed with the loss of 450 jobs. This is a one-company town. This was the major job generator in Aberdeen. The state government has tried to come in to assist in various ways, but that abattoir is going to remain closed.

The state government, which has the primary responsibility for regional development, has had great difficulty in responding in an area of very rapid technological change and very rapidly changing markets. We have in the Hunter the Minister Assisting the Premier on Hunter Development, Richard Face. He set up a beyond 2000 Upper Hunter committee which has been running for two years and was publicised widely in the news a few weeks ago. When asked the basic question, `How many new jobs has the committee generated?' his answer was, `None in that area.' That was a very disappointing outcome.

One area that has some hope in the Upper Hunterâand it has tended to have some fluctuations over timeâis where federal government involvement occurs with the large military base at Singleton. When I went up to meet the mayors and the general managers I heard that there had been a reduction in activity at the base. But we do have the results before us now of what is actually happening at Singleton, and I am pleased to report that the actual number of training daysâbecause Singleton is a training baseâthe number of personnel involved, the amount spent, all of those things, are very much on the up at the moment. Given the current military situation, I think that is likely to continue. So, there is that base underlying the Upper Hunter.

The meeting I had with the mayors and with the general managers discussed quite a number of projects. We had a look at some big projects that are coming into the area. The conclusion that we reached, really, was that these create jobs in the hundreds; what is needed is jobs in the thousands. We are only going to get that through involvement and development of small business in that area. In my next speech in this area I will continue with that story.

talk.start.para: âWe can look forward to instalment No. 3 in the ongoing saga. I would just like to say to Senator Tierney that I think he is committedâand his aspirations are certainly laudableâin relation to regional development. Certainly we on this side of the chamber would agree that the role of governments is to assist regional Australia. We give them a hand up, not a handout. However, Senator Tierney's aspirations may well be somewhat truncated and limited by the empirical actions of the federal government in this area as exemplified by what I would like to talk about today with regard to what happened in Victoria on Saturday.
âThat was interesting.

âIt was very interesting, indeed. Probably Senator Tierney and others on the other side of the chamber would have had the degree of prescience necessary to predict it. Certainly Mr Anderson did make a statement several months ago in which he talked about two nations. I think many members of the opposition were concerned about what was going to happen in Victoria. However, from the federal government's perspective, nothing happened in terms of altering the policy paradigm in that respect.

speech.para: On this historic day, 18 September, the Victorian electorate delivered a very clear message to not only the Kennett government but also the coalition government in terms of rejecting an archaic and outdated approach to regional development policy, something which most of the Western world has rejected. Labor's regional development policy included worthwhile initiatives, such as Working Nation. Regional Victorians said they had had enough of being ignored. They had had enough of being bullied and enough of being completely cut out of the loop in terms of industry regional development employment initiatives. They said enough is enough.

Anybody with even a passing or cursory interest in the Victorian resultâwhich I imagine would be everybody in the federal parliament and in many state governments and oppositionsâcould not fail to note the reality of what happened in regional Victoria. Regional Victorians quite clearly voted against the Kennett government and its urban-centric policies. When I say `urban-centric', I do not actually mean `urban development'. I am actually talking about a piecemeal approach to urban developmentâwhich we also would not support; we support synergy between regional development policy and urban policyâthat was clearly a policy failure.

The Kennett government's policies were based on economic rationalism taken to absurd lengths. They took the voters for granted. When the voters voted the way they did on Saturday, they knew precisely what they were doing. I think it is sad that coalition senators, such as Senator Alston, have responded in this chamber by saying, `It was a protest vote. Look who they voted for. Perhaps they woke up on Sunday and wished they had changed their vote.' People in Victoria knew what they were voting for. If you actually have a look at the voting patterns, unusually for state elections, they did not park their vote with the minor parties. They went straight from the coalition to Labor. That was a very clear message. It was not a protest vote; it was a vote for Labor policies. They were clearly sick and tired of the Kennett government's policies, and there is no doubtâI think it has been successively shown by a number of electionsâthat they are also very concerned about, and sick and tired of, the federal coalition's policies.

The policies of the federal and Victorian state government contributed to high unemployment in Victoria. After seven years of conservative government, 140,000 jobs had been created in Melbourne and only 10,000 in the rest of Victoriaâsomething not lost on regional Victorians.

talk.start.para: âHow many have been lost, though, as well?

âI will get to that, Senator Woodley. There have been massive reductions in state services. For seven years, regional Victorians have endured cuts to health, education and other community services with no real tangible benefit, from their perspective. The government promised imposition of new fees and charges for infrastructure in areas such as regional roads and Catchment Management Authority taxes.

speech.para: The Victorian result showed that governments who ignore regional communities do so at their own peril. In fact, in my own state of Tasmaniaâwhich is also your state, Mr Acting Deputy President Sherryâthat was very clearly shown in the result in the last federal election, which was a vote from regional Australia sending a message to the coalition government.

Under the coalition government, regional communities have been forced to make large sacrifices for the sake of what is termed `economic responsibility' by economic rationalists and yet they have not seen any real major benefitsâthe benefits have been minor. Voters in Victoriaâand those in the rest of Australia, I suspect, are currently feeling the sameâhave said they are simply not prepared to put up with it any more. They want a hand up, not a handout. It is important to have policies that provide a hand up, and that is what we are missing. There is a policy vacuum.

The federal government has to take greater notice of the issues facing regional communities. It is simply not possible anymore to transfer policies designed for metropolitan communities to regional areas and hope that no-one notices. There is an absolute truth in the axiom that the problems facing regional Australia are the same but the solutions for regional communities are different. That is the bottom line here and something that was completely lost in terms of the Victorian election. Regional communities expect and deserve elected representatives who will represent their concerns and interests. They demand and deserve policies that respond to their circumstances in a direct way, acknow ledging that there are exigencies in regional Australia with respect to economic and social conditions and that policies are required to target those exigencies.

One policy which has done untold damage to regional communities is the omnipresent competition policyânot national competition policy in the broad, I hasten to say, because national competition policy does have benefits for everybody, from the big end of town to small rural communities. It is the way it is implemented that is the bottom line here. There is nothing wrong with providing services in an efficient and cost-effective way that has benefits for service providers and for the community. Like a lot of things, NCP delivered wrongly also has major costs. We have yet to see a balanced approach taken with regard to national competition policy to ensure that the community can benefit. Time does not permit me to go into that, but at a later stageâalong with Senator TierneyâI will do a stage 2 which will deal with national competition policy specifically. A lot of it is in relation to how it is interpreted and how it has been mismanaged since the original intention of the policy introduced under Labor.

In Victoria, the Kennett government has taken competition policy to the absolute extreme. Mr Kennett used national competition policy as a smokescreen to implement what was clearly an ideological agendaâan agenda which has been shown, since Saturday, to be thoroughly rejected by the Victorian electorate. His view was that the power of the market ought to reign supreme, sweeping aside any balanced discussion of the impact on regional communities, benefits and associated costs.

NCP in Victoria has become synonymous with compulsory competitive tendering and contracting out. CCT is based on the idea of introducing competition to service provision, with the aim of finding the most efficient service provider. Local government has been particularly hard hit in terms of being at the forefront in relation to compulsory competitive tendering, given the plethora of services it provides. These services have been exposed directly to competition policy, which has resulted in major redundancies and contracting out.

The ASUâthe Australian Services Unionâhas estimated that 15,000 jobs, Senator Woodley, in local government in Victoria have effectively been contracted out. Of these 15,000 jobs, 5,000 have been filled by private contracts, which leaves a final loss of 10,000 jobs. Half of these 10,000 jobsâ5,000âare in regional Victoria. I can imagine that those figures may well be replicated across the board. You can imagineâas Senator Woodley and Senator O'Brien knowâthe impact that job losses have on small regional communities and the impact on the sense of pride of small communities. Job losses are not the only cost that has been associated with CCT. A recent study by the Victorian University of Technology unearthed the following costs: significant cost increases associated with the tendering process, often outweighing the proposed savings that are supposed to emerge from CCT; the breakdown of important service synergies like the loss of local knowledge, well-established relationships, informed helping networks and a general sense of community, which is something that regional Australia is very concerned about; the destruction of worker morale and job commitmentâpeople in local communities develop relationships with people who provide services and, when the contracting out occurs on a willy-nilly basis, this is lost; and the loss of information sharing and collaborative participation, particularly in the area of human services. These costs are significant but, here again, that is what the economic rationalist says. What we need to do is have a look at the human face of the costs in terms of service provision.

As I said before, local government has been forced to carry the costs of CCT in Victoria. There have been some benefits but there have been major downsides, particularly in the area of human services. A survey in 1996 by the Loddon, Buloke and Towong shires of 38 non-metro councils found that 50 per cent of local government respondents reported no savings from CCT at all; 75 per cent of respondents said that CCT had been a net cost to councils. Yet in recent weeks local govern ment has again been forced into a position of uncertainty and caution, this time by the predictable flow-over from the first wave of the federal government's industrial relations laws.

What has happened as a result of this is that a major anomaly has emerged in relation to CCT that has meant that workers doing identical work could be paid different rates, based on outsourcing and the competitiveness of individual tenders. In effect, local government outsourcing has seen a transfer of work activities from the council to private contractors, usually on a lower wage and usually with worse conditions. This is despite the government's claim that no worker will be worse off in relation to this. That is yet another blatant breach, Mr Acting Deputy Presidentâwhich is no surprise to you or meâof the no-disadvantage test and something which we clearly pointed out in the discussions on the first wave.

The Federal Court, as we predicted again, has been forced to come in, clarify and clean up another major anomaly in the first wave industrial relations legislation. Recent decisions by the Federal Court have reinforced the finding that outsourcing did involve the transmission of business. Clearly, people are doing the same work when they move from a government instrumentality or a local council to a contractor. Why should they get paid less if it is the same work?

This decision will impact on up to 40 contractors who deal with municipalities in Victoria alone. The situation is best illustrated with the recent example of home care workers in the Dandenong region of Melbourne. These workers, predominantly women, are a group of unsung heroes. Working in people's homes, isolated from colleagues and performing tasks requiring great compassion, these workers show a commitment and application which would put most of us to shame. Yet when the company Silver Circle won the contract from an internal work force of the Greater City of Dandenong they refused to apply the same conditions. They refused to apply the Victorian Local Government Authorities Interim Award and council's certified agreement to their work force. The 90 home care staff employed by the Greater Dandenong Council had to accept award reductions or lose their jobs. The home care staff refused and the contract was awarded to Silver Circle. Many of the employees of Silver Circle had been performing identical functions but were receiving $2 an hour less, for no good reason whatsoever.

The ASU, on behalf of its members, sought a Federal Court order forcing Silver Circle to pay its employees the council's and not the inferior conditions and wages it was offering. On 14 September, Silver Circle consented to a court order that recognised that the council award and certified agreement were predominant. Interestingly, the company put up a bit of a fight but, in the end, caved in. It knew that, as a result of a string of Federal Court actions, it had lost the case and it agreed with the ASU on the compromise. I would like to recognise the work of the ASU, particularly that of Brendon O'Connor, the assistant national secretary of the ASU, in relation to his assiduous approach to this matter and, on the broader issue of national competition policy, the other assistant secretary, Tim Lee.

Obviously the shortcomings of the federal government's legislation have caused all sorts of problems for local government in Victoria. Despite having received the wrong advice, councils have acted responsibly, taking a cautious approach to future outsourcing and seeking to resolve similar cases. We are talking about up to 5,000 local government workers who are affected by this Federal Court decision. Their claims over loss of pay and conditions as a result of contracting out will amount to millions and millions of dollarsânot simply in terms of the impost on the councils but also in terms of the imposts on the contractors themselves. That is an issue we need to bear in mind in terms of a commitment to small business.
