To conclude, here again local government has had to take the brunt of slipshod policies on industrial relations by the government and also of complete myopia by the federal government, in particular by the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government, who ought to be taking an interest in these matters and ought to be ensuring that industrial relations initiatives which were introduced do not impact in disparate proportion on local government, do not leave them in the lurch and do provide them with a situation where there is sufficient certainty.

talk.start.para: âToday in this debate I wish to talk about a worldwide movement known as Jubilee 2000. Recently in the Senate, Senator John Watson spoke on this issue and previously I have also mentioned it. Today I want to bring some more information to the Senate's attention. The movement Jubilee 2000 is based originally on a passage from the Hebrew scriptures in Leviticus 25 which proclaims a number of things. A contemporary version or summary of that passage in Leviticus says:

speech.para: You shall let the land lie fallow, that is, you shall practise Sabbath; You shall forgive debts, letting forgiveness in: You shall free captives and proclaim liberty; You shall find out what belongs to whom and give it back; You shall hold a great feast, learning to sing the canticles of "jubilate".

That is a very ancient statement about a vision that the Hebrew people had of what the world would be like if we could do all of those things. But it is interesting that, perhaps almost 3,000 years later, groups as widely diverse as governments, churches and aid organisations have combined around the world to proclaim Jubilee 2000.
To give the Senate an idea of how many people are involved in this movement, I will read to the Senate from an information document about the coalition that has taken off around the world:

A powerful group of organisations and churches met in Washington in 1997 to launch Jubilee 2000 in the US. They include Bread for the World, Friends of the Earth, the Fifty Years is Enough campaign, the Sojourners, Witness for Peace, the Methodists, Mennonite and Presbyterian Churches, and the Catholic Bishops Conference. Jubilee 2000 in the USA is conducting a vigorous campaign to persuade members of Congress to back Jubilee 2000.
It goes on:

Additional to the nations already mentioned there are currently campaigns in Ireland, Ghana, Zambia, India and Kenya and we are supported by groups in Canada, France, Tanzania, New Zealand, Norway and many other countries.
A central effort of the worldwide campaign is collecting signatures for the world's largest petition.
I understand that upwards of 22 million signatures are being collected around the world.

In Australia, the National Working Group for Jubilee 2000 has representatives from the Anglican Diocese of Sydney, the Social Issues Committee of the Anglican Church, the Australian Baptist World Aid, the Baptist Union of New South WalesâSocial Issues Committee, the Catholic Justice and Peace Commission, the National Council of Churches, TEAR Australia, World Vision, et cetera. It is a very widespread and diverse group who have got together to attempt to proclaim, if you like, a jubilee for the year 2000.

One of the issues that the Jubilee 2000 movement has taken up is world debt. This is a very critical issue for many nations in the world which have gone past any ability to repay what they owe to creditor nations. In many nations of the world, particularly the poorest nations, debt is absolutely crippling them, not only crippling them in an economic sense but causing great hardship for the populations of those countries. The Jubilee 2000 Charter proposes, amongst other things:

. There is an overwhelming need for remission of the backlog of unpayable debts owed by highly indebted poor countries. Debt remission should relate to commercial, government and IMF/World Bank Debts, and debt reduction would comprehensively include all three forms of debt.
. Creditors as well as debtors must accept responsibility for these high levels of indebtedness.
. The remission should be a one-off, unrepeatable act, tied to the celebration of the new millennium. It would set no precedents for future loans.

And so it goes on. There is already amongst many of the creditor nations movement through the United Nations for the highest indebted countries to have some relief, but this goes beyond that and seeks to get at the very real problems there are in many of the poor countries of the world.

Today I want to go a little beyond what has been proclaimed in this worldwide movement because it concentrates on only one principle of Jubilee. I would suggest to the Senate that the other principles of that Jubilee ought also be included. These other principles include, for example, environmental responsibility. `Let the land lie fallow' was the old Hebrew command. Of course, that is more than simply engaging in particular agricultural practices. It goes far beyond that. It is about caring for the land in a global sense, because we understand today that that is the only way we can in fact save this earth from where it is heading if we do not begin to be far more responsible than we have been in past centuries. It is about sustainable agriculture. It is not only for Jews and Christians, for whom this command ought to be a high priority, but for all of the world's people learning to care again for the land and to be responsible.

It is about freedom from slavery. I guess some people would say, `Well, we got rid of slavery a long time ago.' But we have not. There is the slavery which unemployed people know and understand and live with every day. There is the slavery which is very real around the world where millions of young people, particularly children, act and live and work as slaves. Child labour is a form of slavery.

Another principle of the Jubilee speaks about the release of prisoners. One of the growth industries in Australia and in many of the developed nations is the building of prisons. We in Australia are all aware of the overrepresentation of indigenous people in our prisons. We are aware of the mandatory sentencing laws in Western Australia and the Northern Territory. Particularly in the Northern Territory, those mandatory sentencing laws fall very heavily and overwhelmingly on the indigenous people of that state.

I want to mention the work of a friend of mine in Brisbane, Father Dick Pascoe, who has worked tirelessly for many years to try to do something about the overrepresentation of indigenous people in prison. He has done this at great personal cost. He has been slammed in the media without any opportunity of giving a proper reply to those who have defamed him. He would be the first one to admit that not all he has done has perhaps been successful but, nevertheless, he has never given up in seeking to proclaim a Jubilee for indigenous prisoners in Queensland. He has sought, as we all ought to do, new ways of dealing with prisons and especially in dealing with proper rehabilitation, which often gets put down to the very bottom of the list when it comes to understanding the way prisons operate, especially in terms of prison budgets. We must take seriously this particular aspect of the Jubilee.

The Jubilee also talks about the return of land to the original owners. We know that we have a High Court decision in Mabo which forever extinguished the doctrine of terra nullius, but it is quite clear through the mail I get that many people in Australiaâmany groups within Australia, many organisations within Australiaâoperate and speak as though Mabo never happened, as though native title does not exist. Some people complain about the cost of native title. Of course it costs. Over the last 200 years plus it has cost indigenous people an incalculable cost in the loss of land, in the loss of language, in the loss of culture, in the loss of their children, in the loss of hope and in the loss of life itself. The cost for them can never be calculated. Those of us who say that it is costing too much ought to put that cost that we presently may be faced with against the cost to the indigenous people of this country over the last 211 years. We must also commit ourselves therefore to this principle of Jubilee.

These are the principles of Jubileeânot only the forgiveness of debt but freedom for slaves, the release of prisoners, to take seriously our environmental responsibility and the return of the land to the original owners. It is interesting that that very ancient Hebrew text was updated in the Christian scriptures by Jesus himself, who proclaimed his own Jubilee in exactly the same terms. What I want to say to the Senate today is that in Jubilee 2000 we have an update of 3,000 years of history of a vision which goes back that long of proclaiming to all the world a Jubilee. For the land, for those who are oppressed, for those who are in debt and for those who are in prison there is the possibility of freedom and liberty and a new way of life. In order to update and proclaim Jubilee 2000, there must be a commitment of all to proclaim that Jubilee in the land in which we live and to all the principles of Jubilee:

You shall let the land lie fallow, that is, you shall practice Sabbath; You shall forgive debts, letting forgiveness in: You shall free captives and proclaim liberty; You shall find out what belongs to whom and give it back; You shall hold a great feast, learning to sing the canticles of "jubilate".

talk.start.para: âI rise today to speak on the matter of the constitutional referendum on the question of Australia becoming a republic. I have taken the view that, in deference to the constituents who have contacted me about this matter, I would state my position on the public record. I would like to thank those who have taken the time to communicate their views to me on this important matter and to let them know that I have thought long and hard about the issues and their ramifications for our nation's future.

speech.para: I commence by considering the history of the recent debate which has brought us to this referendum. In 1991 the Centre for Comparative Constitutional Studies at the University of Melbourne facilitated a constitutional centenary conference which I had the privilege of attending. The aim of the conference was to initiate debate and raise public awareness of our Constitution as we moved towards its centenary. The issues recommended for review by the constitutional conference were far broader than the single issue of the head of state and covered a range of issues including judicial independence, trial by jury, federalism, protection of rights and the impact of globalisation. The process had strong bipartisan support from the then Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, and the then Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, and the stage was set for a long-term, sensible and mature consideration of our Constitution.

The whole concept of constitutional change, bubbling and simmering from a groundswell of public information, education and discourse, was something that evoked a strong kinship with our founding federationists. I did not envisage, therefore, a constitutional debate hijacked by a desperate Prime Minister Keating urgently needing to placate the Left and hoping the issue might divide conservative parties. In one fell swoop we moved from bipartisan support for a mature and extended examination of constitutional reform to the single issue of an Australian republic. By railroading the process, Paul Keating set back by years the cause of sensible and constructive debate on constitutional reform. The result has been a divisive constitutional debate and one where the broader issues of reform and community education and consultation have been lost in the `republic before 2000' hyperbole.

The yes advocates make it sound very simple, but I have concerns with the proposed model. According to some, moving to a republic is a simple task of taking our copy of the Constitution and liquid papering out any and all references to the Crown, sovereign and the Governor-General and replacing them with the phrase `President of Australia'. I am highly sceptical that this can be done whilst retaining our political stability, our constitutional certainty and the soundness of our institutions. Whilst I accept that the transfer of the reserve powers to the President can be achieved through the proposed amendment, I remain unconvinced that the conventions which have governed the behaviour of our governors-general will necessarily follow.

I have been profoundly disturbed by the lack of appreciation in the current debate of the values imparted by the concept of the Crown within our parliamentary democracy. An examination of our history shows an evolving Australian concept of the Crown which takes the lessons of European history and adapts them to the unique demands of the Australian nation. This ever-evolving Australian concept of the Crown has guaranteed the dignity and freedom of Australians since our inception as a nation.

Contrary to the easy rhetoric of the republicans, the notion of the Crown in the Australian Constitution is far more than just the person of Elizabeth II. Over the centuries with the passage of time, war, regicide and heated debate has evolved the Westminster system and the constitutional monarchy. The role of the Crown has not only survived but also evolved to become the foundation for a system of democracy which is stable and sound. The Crown has been a solidifying and unifying institution in the Australian Constitution and is removed from the influence of politics and partiality. Yet too often the Crown and the protection it provides to our citizens are disregarded in favour of a confused, simplistic and sometimes petty discussion of the person of the Queen and her heirs.

Queen Elizabeth II is the monarch who represents the human face of the Crown, just as the Governor-General represents the Queen in Australia. The role of the Governor-General has been a role that has evolved since its inception in 1901. Since 1965 all governors-general have been Australian citizens. The way in which they have seen their role in modern Australia has been different for each Governor-General, but the evolution and the transformation of the role has been a consistent and common feature.

The Governor-General is entrusted with all the reserve powers of the constitutional monarch. Too often in this debate, the reserve powers have been brushed aside as a technical matter or treated like a nuisance or, at worst, characterised as somehow being undemocratic. The reserve powers are the invisible hand of our constitutional monarchy, regulating the behaviour of those who exercise power over the citizenry and ensuring flexibility in times of crisis. That is what I would emphasise, so I will say it again: the reserve powers are the invisible hand of our constitutional monarchy, regulating the behaviour of those who exercise power over the citizenry and ensuring flexibility in times of crisis.

It is disingenuous to seek to disentangle the reserve powers from the historical context from which they evolved. We cannot guarantee that, with a stroke of the referendum pen, these conventions will transfer from the old Constitution to the new. We cannot guarantee that a President would be guided by centuries of law and convention which have evolved over a long time. Nor can we guarantee that the tenets of the Westminster system and the inherent impartiality of our present head of state will transfer to a President without diminution. I do not believe that there has been enough debate on the issue of reserve powers and the proposed transferral of these powers to the President, and this is because of what I believe to be a Cinderella mentalityâa determined push by sections of the community to achieve constitutional change before the clock strikes midnight on 31 December 1999.

A constitution is a living and breathing document that is the essence of the people who live under its laws, institutions and values. Those who argue that to value the current constitutional system is to be out of date or to belong to a bygone era of Mother England are missing the reality that the Australian constitutional monarchyâwith its unique Australian understanding of the Crownâis modern, relevant and evolving. The Statute of Westminster in 1942 and the Australia Acts in 1986 both demonstrate the manner in which the Constitution has adapted and evolved and can continue to adapt and evolve without sacrificing our stability of process and the strength of our institutions.

For nearly 100 years, Australia has functioned as one of the most modern, relevant and inclusive democracies in the world. Without civil war or widespread national division, our Constitution has accommodated great social and political change with only minimal constitutional hiccups. The guarantee of freedom, dignity and the rule of law which the Crown extends to all Australian citizens has drawn millions of migrants to our shores and improved the quality of life of succeeding generations of Australians, regardless of their country of origin. For these reasons, I will be voting no to a republic in the referendum on 6 November 1999.

In closing, I would like to make the point that I consider that one of the more disappointing aspects of the debate thus far has been the level of personal vitriol generated by some with opposing views. I do not pretend to be the fount of all wisdom on the issue, neither do I wish to enter into personal attacks on those who have taken a different view. I do not intend to enter into that sort of debate and would like to put on the record my respect for those who have given a great deal of thought to this issue and have been willing to put their views into the public arena, many of whom differ from me in their views. It may well be that history will judge me to have been overly cautious. If the Australian people choose to move to a republic on 6 November, I will commit myself to working hard to ensure a strong and successful Australian republic.

talk.start.para: âThe matter I want to talk about today does not deal with the republic at all but deals with public accountability. This government keeps talking about its commitment to reduce the charges it imposes on industry, and that is an appropriate policy objective. Government must provide services as efficiently as it can. A reduction in the costs imposed by government authorities on industries that use their services was a key policy objective of the former government. While I was not part of that government, I think I can fairly claim that both the Hawke and Keating governments were successful in their endeavours.

speech.para: This government has also talked about the need for transparency of the cost basis for government charges. I also agree with that commitment. It is just as important that governments not only keep charges down but also justify the basis for charges they impose.

Last year, I asked a question on notice about a review that government had undertaken into the operation of Airservices Australia. That review in fact was completed in March 1998. According to the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, the purpose of the review was to determine what changes were needed to the structure of the authority to `facilitate the introduction of competition to the potentially commercial functions of the organisation'. I asked for a copy of that report that followed the review, but the minister, Mr Anderson, refused to release the document, as he normally does. Mr Anderson could never be accused of being a supporter of open government. In response to a question on notice, Mr Anderson said:
The Government has decided not to release the report, and I am not prepared to comment on its findings and recommendations.

Clearly, the endgame in all of this is the privatisation of Airservices Australia. That means the privatisation of everything, including air traffic control. The government has already attempted to privatise some air traffic services by way of regulation, but the Senate, quite rightly, blocked this move.

As I said earlier, the claimed objective of the government's strategy generally and in relation to Airservices Australia in particular has been to cut costs and ensure that charges imposed on industry are transparent. It was, therefore, of some concern to me and, I am sure, the aviation industry when details of the salaries paid to managers and other staff in Airservices Australia were leaked to the media. This information was obviously leaked by someone who considers the salaries paid to some officials are difficult to justify.

I was asked to comment on those alleged salariesâand I say `alleged' because I understand that the chair of Airservices Australia, Mr John Forsyth, has claimed that the schedule of salaries that has appeared in the media is not accurate. I look forward with considerable interest to Mr Forsyth releasing an accurate schedule of senior executive salaries to correct the record, if such a correction is required. In fact, I invite him to do so.

It is important to note that Airservices Australia is accountable to the minister and the parliament through the Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Act 1997. It should also be accountable to the industry it serves and the Australian travelling public, who, through their tickets, ultimately fund its operations. That is the point I made to a journalist from the Sunday Telegraph who wrote a story about this matter. If Airservices is paying its executives very large salaries, it must be able to justify those salaries.

The list of salaries paid to Airservices staff, which, as I said, somehow found its way out of that organisation and into the media, contained some very big numbers indeed. The minister has advised me that Airservices has initiated a full investigation into the leaking of the management salaries. The Manager, Corporate Security, Mr Peter Beaver, is undertaking the investigation. That inquiry was initiated by the Chief Executive Officer, Mr Pollard. Mr Anderson has advised that he expects the Beaver inquiry to be complete and a report with Mr Pollard by the end of this month. Clearly, both Minister Anderson and Airservices are very sensitive about the fact that these salary packages were made public, and one cannot be surprised at that.

Some time prior to the Airservices management packages being exposed through the Sunday Telegraph, I placed on notice a question not about salary packages but about salary increases paid to Airservices executives. I asked how many increases in salaries or related benefits senior Airservices Australia officers had received since July 1995. I thank the minister for providing me with a prompt answer. I will not go through all of the information provided in that answer, but I want to highlight certain information contained in it. I might add that the answer itself generates a large number of issues, and the minister can, therefore, expect a large number of follow-up questions on the Notice Paper shortly.

The Chief Executive and Managing Director, Mr Pollard, was appointed to that position in November 1995. He received a salary increase on 6 November 1996, on 6 November 1997 and again on 6 November last year. I will be interested to see if Mr Pollard receives a further increase in his salary on 6 November this year. The minister refuses to tell the parliament the quantum of each of these increases. According to the list of salaries that I referred to earlier, Mr Pollard currently earns $329,000 a year. I assume, again, that Mr Forsyth will correct this number if it is wrong.

The General Manager, Corporate and Employee Relations received a pay rise on 1 July 1996 and another one on 14 May 1997, after what is described by the minister as a scope change. On 1 July 1997, just 47 days later, the General Manager, Corporate and Employee Relations received another salary increase. Then he received another increase on 1 July last year. The basis of all these increases, according to Mr Anderson, was independent advice from Mercers Cullen Egan Dell, the average weekly ordinary time earnings index and a performance appraisal by the Chief Executive Officer. The final decision of salary increases for this position rests with Mr Pollard, not with the board of Airservices. According to the list, this position currently attracts a salary of $256,214.

The position of General Manager, Air Traffic received a pay rise on 1 July 1996, 14 May 1997, 1 July 1997 and 1 July last year. The basis for the increases, according to Mr Anderson, was, again, independent advice from Mercers Cullen Egan Dell, the average weekly ordinary time earnings index and a performance appraisal by the Chief Executive Officer. Again, it was Mr Pollard who had the final say on whether or not a salary increase was granted.

The General Manager, Planning and Development has also done very nicely. She received a pay increase on 1 July 1995, 1 July 1996, 1 July 1997 and 1 July 1998. According to the list I referred to earlier, she currently receives $276,229 per annum. In the context of these salaries, it is salutary to recall that, as I understand it, the Prime Minister's salary is in the vicinity of $205,000.

My understanding of the workplace relations regime under this government is that increases in salaries must be directly linked with increases in productivity. That is the key objective, as I understand it, of the Workplace Relations Act. But the increases in salaries paid to managers in Airservices Australia appear to be based largely on increases in average weekly earnings and an index provided by Mercers Cullen Egan Dell, which I understand to be related to surveys of executive salariesâin other words, so-called comparative wage justice, something that is not available to the ordinary work force.

These increases appear to be locked in. They are granted on the same date each year. Accountability, in terms of an appraisal of the performance of these managers and the basis of increased salaries based on productivity gains, apparently rests entirely with the Chief Executive Officer. His only obligation is to consult with the Airservices board in relation to the principles that apply to salary packages. I asked the minister whether there was any obligation on Airservices Australia to advise the Department of Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business of the quantum and basis for each salary increase. Mr Anderson advised no, even though Airservices is a government authority. He said this was not a requirement on Airservices Australia.

So what we appear to haveâand the government can clarify this issue quite easily by telling the parliament how much these senior public servants are paid and what the quantum of increases in their salaries has been since July 1995âis a process of remuneration in Airservices that is not open to any sort of scrutiny at all, and it is the industry, and therefore ultimately the travelling public, who must pay the cost.

I remind the Senate that earlier this year the government increased the avgas and avtur levies, despite having made promises to reduce them. According to the government, the additional funding was to meet the shortfall in the aviation industry's contribution to the Civil Aviation Safety Authority's aviation safety programs. The reality is that CASA had overspent, and the government simply went back to the industry and extracted more money from it to meet the shortfall. The government also imposed a temporary surcharge on all aviation fuels. What for? To boost the Airservices budget. The government blamed the Senate for the increased levy because it would not allow the government to privatise air traffic services. That, I might say, was little more than a crude attempt to link a budget shortfall with an issue of public safety.
In conclusion, I will quote the Prime Minister, Mr Howard. In his 1999 corporate affairs oration, he quoted Milton Friedman:

In a free enterprise, private property system, a corporate executive is an employee of the owners of the business . . . in so far as his actions, in accord with his social responsibility, reduce returns to stockholders, he is spending their money. In so far as his actions raise the price to customers, he is spending the customer's money. In so far as his actions lower the wages of some employees, he is spending their money.

talk.start.para: âMilton Friedman said that?

âThat was indeed the Prime Minister quoting Milton Friedman. One only need reflect on that statement when wondering just why we do not get more information on this situation. This is about accountabilityâaccountability of Airservices Australia to this parliament and, through that, accountability to the aviation industry and the travelling public, who must pay the bills.

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 1.47 p.m. to 2.00 p.m.

subdebateinfo.title: Business Tax Reform: Research and Development

talk.start.para: âMy question is to Senator Minchin, Minister for Industry, Science and Resources. Is it not the case that, by retaining the R&D tax concession of 125 per cent while reducing the company tax rate to 30 per cent, the government has cut the real value of the R&D tax concession by one-sixth? Given the substantial falls in business expenditure on R&D since your 1996 cut to the R&D tax concession, did your department make any assessment of the implications for business expenditure on R&D of this further cut in the value of R&D tax concession? Will the minister release any such assessment?

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Industry, Science and Resources

talk.start.para: âWhen we came into government we found we had a $10,000 million deficit and massive debt. We also found that we had significant rorting of the R&D tax concession involved in the process of syndication. Unlike the Labor Party, which sat around for 13 years doing nothing, we acted when we came to office both to correct the problems in the deficit and to remove the rorting involved in syndication. That involved a cut in the R&D tax concession from 150 per cent to 125 per cent. It was a necessary action to ensure the sharing of the burden of dealing with Labor's incredibly irresponsible approach to the deficit.

answer.para: I might point out that it costs $300 million annually to restore the 150 per cent tax concession. Labor has not made any attempt to indicate how on earth they are going to find $300 million to put the tax concession back up to 150 per cent. They just blandly say, `Put it back to 150 per cent.' Nowhere do they say how that is going to be paid for.

What we have done is to provide to business the most fantastic reforms of business tax ever in this country, something Labor did not do in its 13 years. We are reducing the company tax rate to 30 per centâone of the lowest tax rates in our region and one of the lowest corporate tax rates in the developed world. That of itself will provide a very significant incentive to engage in R&D expenditure. I need only quote to you, Senator Conroy, Tony Cutcliff of the Institution of Engineers on the impact of business tax reform. He said:

The business tax reform will result in a rush of foreign money into high technology, more local R&D, more jobs for engineers, a halt to the brain drain and a healthier, more certain climate for domestic investment in start-up companies.
Mr John Mullarvey, Executive Director of the Australian Vice Chancellors Committee, said:

The lowering of the company tax rate to 30 per cent gives companies increased scope to think about medium and long-term benefits of higher investment in R&D and this is essential if we are to encourage more and better linkages between business and our research centres.

What we have put together in this tremendous package that we released yesterday does retain the 125 per cent R&D tax concession. The lowering of the company tax rate and the tremendous reforms of capital gains tax, which the Labor Party has supported, will lead to greater investment in and support for R&D.

talk.start.para: âMadam Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. I will actually go back to the original question, which the minister failed to address. Did your department make any assessment of the implications for business expenditure on R&D in relation to this further cut? Will the minister release any such assessment? Has your department modelled it?

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Industry, Science and Resources

talk.start.para: âWhat is clear from industry surveys and others is that you cannot attribute the recent falls in business expenditure on R&D to the lowering of the tax concession. I am as concerned as anybody to see business expenditure on research and development increase. We are doing as much as we can to bring that about. We are actually increasing the amount that we spend on support for R&D.

answer.para: What we have seen from survey after survey is that the recent falls in business expenditure on R&Dâ

talk.start.para: âMadam Deputy President, I raise a point of order and it goes to relevance. The minister had four minutes to address the question. He now has a further minute, which is almost up, and he is yet to address the question. The answer that he is giving is not addressing the question. I ask you to direct him to answer the question.
âThe minister is entitled to answer the question in the way he sees fit. I presume he is relating it to the issue of R&D announcements.

âMadam Deputy President, what is clear from all the surveys and our work in our own department is that there is no clear evidence that the recent fall in business expenditure on R&D is a function of the lowering of the R&D tax concession to 125 per cent. There are a whole range of reasons why business expenditure on R&D has fallen. One is the low commodity prices in the minerals sector. The minerals industries in Australia are the primary spenders on R&D, and their recent difficulties have obviously led to them spending less on business R&D. (Time expired)

âMy question without notice is to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. Minister, would you please inform the Senate of the government's proposed changes to the Australian business taxation system? Would you also inform the Senate of what the key proposed changes are, and what feedback there has been in response to the government's announcement?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: âI thank the senator for his important question. Madam Deputy President, I think the Australian Financial Review got it right today when one of their major headlines said `An overwhelmingly positive climate for investment'. What the Treasurer announced yesterday was the third plank in the historic overhaul of the taxation system by the government. This overhaul will create an environment for Australia to achieve higher growth and, more importantly, will lead to job creation. Furthermore, the review of business taxation aims to provide a sustainable revenue base so that the government can continue to deliver services to the community.

answer.para: Yesterday the Treasurer announced the government's business taxation proposals, as recommended by the Ralph committee, to lower the company tax rate from 36 per cent to 34 per cent in the 2000-01 financial year and to 30 per cent thereafter. As Senator Minchin just mentioned to the Senate, this represents one of the lowest company tax rates in our region. The United States has a 35 per cent rate; New Zealand, a 33 per cent rate; Japan, 42; and Canada 44.

Our capital gains tax regime will also be overhauled. For individuals, only 50 per cent of the capital gains are to be effectively taxed, with the result that the highest rate of tax for individuals will effectively be 24.25 per cent. As for superannuation funds, only two-thirds of capital gains will be taxed, which will mean a concessional rate of 10 per cent.

To move to the second part of the senator's question, about the community reaction to the tax package, it is true that there was an overwhelming response and that the response was overwhelmingly favourable to what the government announced yesterday. For example, the Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia said that the government response to Ralph is `fair and balanced' and that super fund members will gain through only two-thirds of capital gains being taxed. The Investment and Financial Services Association says that overall the review has `produced a set of proposals that will greatly enhance the capacity of the economy to produce improved savings and investment results.'

The Australian Industry Group says that on early examination they believe that it represents a `generally positive and balanced approach to business tax reform.' And so the story goes on. The Financial Planning Association of Australia applauds the government's support for investors through tax reform. The Australian Society of CPAs says that small business and small investors are `winners' from Ralph. Importantly, the National Farmers Federation has indicated that most of Australia's farmers will be more competitive because they will be operating under a simpler and fairer system. There was also a statement from the Australian Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers Association, whose director is a Mr David Epsteinâ

talk.start.para: âMy friend.

âOur friend, Senator. He is the former chief of staff to none other than Mr Beazley. He says that these reforms as proposed set out the possibility of unprecedented gains and benefits to Australian business. His press release said that `the new business taxation package proposed by the government today should provide considerable benefits for Australia's electrical, electronic and telecommunications industries'. (Time expired)

âMy question is to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. I refer to the Ralph review of business taxation, which estimates the cost to revenue of $500 million over five years from the conversion of ordinary income into capital gains. Can the minister confirm that this is due to the substitution effect caused by the lowering of the capital gains tax rate versus higher marginal income tax rates? Is this substitution cost to revenue included in the government's `Fiscal Impact of Announced Measures' table contained in attachment T? If this cost to revenue has not been included in the government's calculations, can the minister please explain why it hasn't?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: âThe recommendations of the Review of Business Taxation are comprehensive and, in some cases, involve fundamental change to the taxation of business income. The government has decided to respond in two stages in order to balance the need to provide certainty to the business community and the need to allow the due consideration of the review's proposals.

answer.para: We believe that the measures which have been announced are revenue neutral, as mentioned. The capital gains tax measures, as referred to by Senator Cook, in fact effective ly produce income. Of course, one of the reasons for that is that with a more effective capital gains tax regime we avoid, among other things, a lock-in effect. That is one of the reasons we are seeing that the changes to the capital gains tax regime will produce great benefits to people who invest in assets and also produce an increase in revenue.

talk.start.para: âI call Senator Cook.

âThank you, Madam Deputy President. I was taken by surprise because the minister had plenty of time to finish his answer but he did not actually answer the question. Is this substitution cost to revenue included in the government's `Fiscal Impact of Announced Measures' table in attachment T? Is it or is it not? Does the minister agree that, as a matter of tax practice, the lowering of capital gains tax rates will encourage a substitution between lower taxed capital income as opposed to higher taxed ordinary income? Does the minister agree that creating and widening differential tax rates between the taxation of capital income versus the taxation of ordinary income only creates further anomalies in the taxation system, which will be exploited by aggressive tax planners?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: âThe reforms make, as I said in an earlier question, Australia's CGT internationally competitive. There is some scope for arbitrage acknowledged in Ralph, and he concluded that the benefits to the economy outweighed these concerns. Mr Ralph indicated that they would be complex to legislate against. I would point out to you, Senator Cook, that assets must be held for at least 12 months before being eligible for the 50 per cent exclusion.

âI rise on a point of order, Madam Deputy President. I did ask an explicit question: are they included in table T or not? You have not answered that. I had hoped, Minister, that before you sat down you would actually answer that question.

interjection.para: Government senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âI am pleased to see the answer so far, but it has not been to the question. I actually asked the question in the hope of getting an answer.
âOrder! There is no point of order. The minister is entitled to answer the question as he sees fit.

âThank you, Madam Deputy President. The question, if I remember it correctly, was will the reforms cause a switch from income to capital to avoid tax, and that is what I am answering. Sorry for answering your question, Senator! But if you want me toâ
âYou are dodging the question.
âAs I said, this issue raised by Senator Cookâ(Time expired)

âMy question is to the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, Senator Alston. Will the minister inform the Senate of the benefits to the Australian economy from the government's improvements to business tax? In particular, how will these measures boost the information technology sector to generate growth and enhance innovation? Is the minister aware of any alternative policy proposals, and is the government giving these any serious consideration?
âI call Senator Alston.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âThank you, Madam Deputy Presidentâ

question.para: Senator Cook interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder, Senator Cook!
âWe will come to your policies later. I will demonstrate in clinical detail whereâ

question.para: Opposition senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! Minister, would you please address the chair. Senator Cook and Senator Faulkner will cease interjecting.

âYes, I will. I was provoked, Madam Deputy President. I thank Senator Mason for his question because it goes to the heart of the difference between the parties in this important area. What we are concerned about is to stimulate innovation. We want to see investment in venture capital industries. We want to see people, with the incentives available, to really get in there and commercialise new ideas. It is not a matter of just talking about them, of getting out to the John Curtin Hotel and saying, `Isn't it a good idea that we could punish some of these people who have been earning too much money. We will take their capital gains away from them.'

question.para: We are particularly concerned to ensure that the industries that have enormous potential in this country are not handicapped by an out of date and outmoded taxation system. The reforms that were announced yesterday have received very widespread support. Merrill Lynch Asset Management said that these are very favourable tax reforms. Clearly, they build on the Prime Minister's plans to encourage investment. Australia's IT&T communications sector is an engine of growth. Arthur Anderson's corporate tax partner said that the concessions for the foreign pension funds really make Australia competitive with the ordinary tax rules in America, the UK and other major countries.

The CGT rates are enormously important if we are to stimulate investment in areas where there is normally a higher degree of risk attached. The rewards are there, but there has been a degree of conservatism displayed over a number of years, particularly by Australian superannuation funds. Certainly the US pension funds and other major pension funds around the world have treated Australia as a no-go area as the rates are punitive. They have made that abundantly plain on a number of occasions. We have had discussions with some of the leading pension funds to address this issue.

I will pick up on the point about Labor's approach to this issue. At the last election when they were busy trying to introduce a whole range of other highly unpopular tax reforms they proposed that they would allow overseas funds, in concert with Australian investors, to invest through a limited number of tightly regulated, approved venture capital funds which would be required to place emphasis on start up and early stage development.

Where you draw those boundary lines would be an absolute nightmare. But critically important, what they were proposing was that US pension funds could not make their own decisions. They had to do it in conjunction with Australian super funds. In other words, they were playing the old protection game. They were trying to ensure that you could not just come in and make a decision on its meritsâyou had to find a local partner.

talk.start.para: âYes.

âExactly. In other words, completely removing the flexibility from investors who want to make intelligent decisions on the merits and who might want 20 or 30 per cent or, on the other hand, might want 100 per cent. If that is the way in which they need to be persuaded to invest, then that is the degree of maximum flexibility that they ought to be allowed. That is what our system will permit. That is not what Labor was prepared to countenance. Once again, they were trying to tie one hand behind the back, trying to dictate how they should do it, in conjunction with whom they should do it and, in all sorts of ways, guarantee that the system simply would not work.

question.para: It is perfectly clear that there is overwhelming support for our proposal. Labor tried the Management and Investment Companies Program, which did not work. They had 13 years to tackle all these issues and simply did not. The Venture Capital Association now says that instead of $500 million a year now flowing into venture capital funds in Australia the amount could quickly double or triple to reach up to $2 billion within the next few years. That might be very bad news for you, but it is very good news for those who are seriously interested in the issue. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âMy question is directed to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. Does the minister agree that in lowering the company tax rate to 30 per cent while the top marginal rate remains at 48.5 per cent, the government has created an even greater incentive for individuals to incorporate rather than remain as PAYE taxpayers? Can the minister explain why, in creating this added incentive, the government has not simultaneously introduced anti-avoidance provisions in order to protect against further erosion of the PAYE tax base via the alienation of personal services income which is encouraged by the significantly widened differential between the company tax rate and the top marginal individual tax rate?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: âSenator Sherry, we make no apology for lowering the company tax rate. We actually think that that is very good policy. To be quite frank, if I interpreted the shadow Treasurer correctly, the Labor Party thinks it makes sense to lower the corporate tax rate. I am not aware that the Labor Party wants to lower the rates of personal income tax, particularly for the higher income earners.
âDo you remember what the question was?

âThat is exactly what the question was. We again have the Labor Party completely nitpicking. The Labor Party, as I understand from its spokespeople, has signed on to the 30 per cent corporate tax rate. The Labor Party is not proposing any change, if I am right Senator Sherry. When Senator Sherry stands up he can perhaps explain to us whether the Labor Party is proposing to lower the income tax rate for those at the highest level. If you are not proposing to do that then your question has no substance at all.

answer.para: The Treasurer has indicated that there are some other measures that the government has foreshadowed in this tax package concerning the alienation of personal services. The Treasurer stated:

Now in addition to that there are some other measures that are foreshadowed, for example, personal service, measures directed against personal service incorporation, non-commercial losses, and the Government's view is that we in principle believe that steps will have to be taken in those areas.

talk.start.para: âMadam Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the minister inform the Senate of the current trends in shifts from the PAYE tax base to incorporation? Can the minister advise the Senate whether the government made any estimate of how many more people may seek to incorporate to take advantage of the lower company tax rate announced yesterday? If not, will the government be seeking to make such an estimate?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: âIt is always a problem when the supplementary question is written before the answer is listened to. Senator Sherry, you asked me whether we were proposing to take any steps, and I invite you to read the last part of my answer in which I quoted the Treasurer, Mr Costello, from yesterday.

âMadam Deputy President, I have a point of order. My point of order goes to relevance. The supplementary question went to current trends in shifts from the PAYE tax base. He did not refer to that in his original answer. He should try to answer the supplementary question.

âSenator Sherry, can I make it clear to you: I said the government's view is that we in principle believe that steps will have to be taken in those areas. That is what we saidâthat is what I said, and that is what the Treasurer said.

subdebateinfo.title: Business Tax Reform: Capital Gains Tax

talk.start.para: âMy question is to the Assistant Treasurer. Is the minister aware that taxation statistics say that 72 per cent of capital gains tax is paid by taxpayers earning over $50,000 a year and that half of that is paid by the top 1.6 per cent of taxpayers? Is the minister aware that, if capital gains tax for individuals is halved, the benefit on a $1,000 capital gain to a self-funded retiree on the lowest tax rate will be $85, which is a third of the benefit on a $1,000 capital gain for a high income earner? Can the minister explain to the eight million Australian taxpayers paying full tax on their wage-based income why the 600,000 mostly high income Australians should pay a much lower tax rate on their capital-based income? How will these individual capital gains tax cuts contribute to a fairer and more equitable tax system?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: âSenator Murray, you have to appreciate that the government is changing the capital gains tax regime from a situation where we taxed the real rates but at high rates, and of course there was an indexation factor and averaging. Now we are moving to a regime where we are taxing the nominal rates at a lower rate. We think this is a very positive move. In fact, I have to say this move has been very widely welcomed throughout the community, particularly in the press.

answer.para: Senator Murray asked why we are doing this. We believe that Australia needs a more internationally competitive tax regime and that is one of the moves which will help encourage that. We also believe that, by these changes in capital gains tax, we will encourage people to save and invest. We think that is very positive; it is extremely positive for jobs. With these changes, we cut down on a whole host of red tape as well. To be quite frank, these changes are very positive. It is worth noting, as I mentioned in the answer to Senator Cook, that this will produce more revenue not less because it leads to a more efficient system.

Self-funded retirees will benefit very substantially under the tax package, and self-funded retirees vary from those on high incomes to those on comparatively low incomes. Let me just list, apart from the change we made in the capital gains tax, some of the other areas where self-funded retirees will benefit. First of all, we are cutting income tax rates, which is a big plus. Again, I do not think there is any proposal around this chamber to raise those rates. We are delivering the largest tax cuts in Australian history.

One of the other very important factors in this which has been particularly welcomed by self-funded retirees is refundable imputation credits. This is one of the key demands from the self-funded groups. They have wanted the government for many years to move on this front to provide refundable imputation credits, and that is precisely what we have provided. Another big plus for self-funded retirees out of the government's overall tax reform package is the health insurance rebate, which again was a big demand from many people in the self-funded retiree area.

So there are many big pluses in this package for self-funded retirees, indeed for all Australians. Senator Murray mentioned that there would be a different rate between income and capital. That is not atypical around the world in tax systems. Australia wanted to adopt world's best practice and we particularly wanted a tax system which encourages people to save and invest. That is precisely what we have done with this tax package and with the other reforms we have announced in the area of income tax and indirect taxation.

talk.start.para: âMadam Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. Thank you, Minister, for your answer. I think, in summary, the equity issue will need further exploration. The minister would be aware that the abolition of indexing and averagingâwhich he mentionedâpays for only about 60 per cent of the cost of cutting capital gains tax for individuals, with the remaining $500 million coming from so-called extra capital gains. Isn't it the case that, if that money fails to arrive or if the Treasury estimate of tax avoidance through lower capital gains ends up an underestimate, then the capital gains tax cut is not funded and it would then just represent a net loss and a windfall tax cut to higher income earners?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: âIn response to Senator Murray's question, the figures we announced yesterday were figures which were prepared by the Ralph committee. They were not figures which were prepared by the government. We have said that we accept the figures which the Ralph committee prepared. These are figures which have been drawn from the work of that committee. They are the best estimate available and we think, on that basis, the figures we have produced are very sound indeed.

âMy question is directed to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. How many hundreds of millions of dollars of tax will the Howard government allow to be avoided each year by complete inaction on the issue of the alienation of personal services income? Will the government release the advice it has received from the Treasury and the tax office on this issue? Why will the Howard government not act against very high income earners who are not paying their fair share of tax?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âWe are certainly committed to taking action to ensure that people pay their fair share of tax. Indeed, I think in February this year the Treasurer made it plain that there were a number of measures under contemplation. Certainly we do not condone any action that might be taken in respect of personal services or other structures that would enable people to avoid a legitimate burden of tax.

answer.para: You will recall that Ralph recommended against imposing a minimum level of taxation to be paid by companies. We have accepted that recommendation and decided to instead ensure that the system is tightly regulated so that you do not have those avoidance mechanisms available. We will do the same, where necessary, for individuals. The whole notion of entity taxation is, I think, a tightening of the system. In various ways I think we will certainly ensure that we do not have people avoiding their fair burden of tax.

talk.start.para: âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. I am not sure that the Acting Leader of the Government understood the question at all. Why did the Howard government ignore the Ralph report's clear warning about the avoidance nature of the alienation of personal services income? Given these warnings, does the Prime Minister endorse the Treasurer's remarks yesterday, where he justified not addressing the issue by claiming that the problem only relates to the top one per cent of high income earners? What is the real reason the Howard government will not act against very high income earners who are not paying their fair share of tax?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âYou will recall that after 13 years of Labor, in a last desperate attempt to obtain re-election, the Labor government identified something in the order of $800 million that could be recouped from high net worth individuals. That is a matter that the Australian Tax Office has been working on since that time. The Treasurer has indicated that we will take steps if necessary to ensure that people are not able to use that status by inter-companyâ
âThis does not relate to the question.

âWell, you are talking about personal services. I am saying to you that the one per cent of high net worth individuals are often able to artificially minimise their taxation by inter-company arrangements, by simply shuffling levels of income around in such a way that you do not ever have a proper taxation point. We are not prepared to tolerate those actions, and we will be taking the necessary action.

âMy question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry. The Tasmanian salmon industry has grown from producing 20 tonnes in 1986 to 7000 tonnes in 1997. Minister Anderson, in a press release on 20 December, said that AQIS had finalised its decision based on extensive studies of some 24 diseases of salmon, most of which do not occur in Australia. The AQIS decision is based on scientific and technical grounds, which is entirely consistent with Australia's rights under the SPS agreement of the World Trade Organisation. AQIS, the Bureau of Resource Science and the Commonwealth Chief Veterinary Office have spent two years examining the scientific issues involved and consulting with scientific experts. Will the ministerâ
âOrder! Senator Harris, your time has expired for asking the question.
âI seek leave to conclude my question.

interjection.para: Leave not granted.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âI do not think it is possible to divine what it was that Senator Harris was leading to, but to the extent that he was concerned about the procedures adopted by AQIS, it is quite clear that AQIS did subject the whole issue of salmon to very extensive assessment. It was required to accelerate its analysis to meet World Trade Organisation requirements. The process was transparent. It invited submissions from interested stakeholders and took into account the scientific issues raised by those stakeholders. It announced revised quarantine access policies for salmonoid products, non-viable fish, marine fin fish and live ornamental fish on 19 July last. And the policies are based on an extremely comprehensive and thorough import risk analysis process using the most up-to-date scientific information and the input of 14 independent Australian and international experts. It is the most intensive study of fish quarantine conducted by a quarantine service. It follows from all that that the measures announced by AQIS bring Australia's quarantine controls into conformity with our obligations as a member of the World Trade Organisation, and we will continue to adhere to those obligations.

âMadam President, I ask a supplementary question. Thank you, minister, for very accurately setting out what AQIS did. If the minister is so confident that the importation of Canadian salmon will not pose a disease risk to our industry and environment, will the government indemnify our salmon producers against any loss sustained from such a result of lifting the import ban?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âAs I indicated, we are not in the business of second-guessing the experts. It is not a matter for the government to express its own independent degree of confidence. What we are required to do, if anything, in terms of confidence, is to be confident that AQIS has the necessary resources and capability to conduct those inquiries. It did conduct very extensive inquiries; it did take expert advice; it did consult the industry extensively; and it has indeed been looked at independently at World Trade Organisation level.

answer.para: Against that background, the government is confident that the AQIS findings are validâin other words, there is not likely to be any significant risk posed by the importation of Canadian salmonâand that the restrictions that have been introduced will provide the necessary degree of comfort. In those circum stances, there are simply other commercial risks that will be required to be taken by industry. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âMy question is directed to Senator Newman, the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Could the minister explain how Australia is going to be able to rotate Australian troops who have been deployed to East Timor, given that the Howard government abolished the Ready Reserve Scheme in their first term of government, they removed leave for Defence Force reservists as an allowable matter under workplace relations legislation, and they have effectively disregarded the Australian Defence Force Reserves ever since they were elected?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âIsn't it interesting that somebody who took no interest in defence matters before is suddenly jumping on a bandwagonâ

answer.para: Opposition senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder on my left!
âwhen her own government's involvement in defence was quite dishonourable in many respects. For example, the 13 years of Labor meant that we had a navy with so many admirals and not enough ships.
âWhat rubbish. Why don't you answer the question?
âOrder!
âYou cannot answer it. You don't know. You're just bluffing.
âOrder, Senator Cook!

âMadam Deputy President, I rise on a point or order. It is not sufficient to simply hear what you say by way of direction and totally ignore it. What Senator Cook is embarking upon is a deliberate tactic of intimidation, designed to shout down a minister who has been asked a question by one of his colleagues. You indicated twice that he should come to order. He totally ignored you. If Senator Cook has any point of order to take, there is a proper process to be followed. He is not in any shape or form attempting to do that. He is simply sledging and screaming across the chamber in a way that does no credit at all to this chamber and certainly does not assist Senator Newman in answering the question.

âMadam Deputy President, on the point of order: I think you would agree that it is an important question that has been asked in relation to how Australia is going to be able to rotate the Australian troops who have been deployed to East Timor. I think there is no more important issue in the public mind in Australia at the moment. I think the Senate is entitled to an answer to that question. We now have a situation, thanks to Senator Alston taking a spurious point of orderâ
âWhat is your point of order?
âI am speaking to yoursâthat Senator Newman has now been able to turn up the brief on this matter. Let's get an answer.
âI would ask for order on both sides.
âOh!
âWhat have you got against that?

âThank you, Senator Bolkus. I do not need your assistance or your chastisement of other people. Senator Cook, I would appreciate silence from you, too. Minister, you may return to your answer and I hope you will be able to make it relevant to the question.
âIf I had 10 minutes I would be able to tell the Labor Party a bit more about defence and their failures during the time they were in government.
âAnswer the question.
âOrder, Senator Carr!

âMadam Deputy President, it is very relevant to the question that was asked because the defence force that we inherited from Labor was top heavy with senior ranks, it did not have enough warriors, it had too many clerks, and that has been remedied over the 3Â½ years that we have been in government.
âWhat about rotating the troops?

âMadam Deputy President, they like to shout me down. They do not like to hear the facts. But the reform process which has been in place since we came into government has meant that as of now our government has been able to bring a second brigade in northern Australia to such a state of preparedness and readiness that it can support the brigade that has already gone from Townsville. The brigade in Darwin was raised in June or July this year to 28 days readiness. The Labor Party never had two brigades at that level of readiness in all the 13 years they were in government.
âWhat about the rotation?
âOrder!
âYou silly duffer! I am just telling you about the readiness and rotation. Why don't you listen?
âMinister, please address the chair and ignore the interjections from Senator Carr, which are unparliamentary. I will have some order, thank you.

interjection.para: Opposition senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder!
âWhoa, Hyacinth!
âOrder, Senator Schacht!
âTell us about the clever duffer.
âSenator Crowley, I am on my feet, thank you. I will have some order. Minister, please address the chair and try to ignore the unruly interjections from Senator Carr, thank you.
âMadam Deputy President, I do rather sympathise with you that some of your colleagues are duffers.
âIt is not parliamentary to reflect upon other members in this place, either.

interjection.para: Opposition senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder on my left!
âIt is hard to draw a conclusion other than they are duffers because I had just given an answer which demonstrated that there was the abilityâ
âMadam Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. The minister's language is unparliamentary. I have already borne some of her sledging. I ask you to ask her to withdraw.
âMinister, I would appreciate you using language which is more circumspect, please. Would you mind withdrawing the aspersions you cast upon members on the other side, please.
âMadam Deputy President, am I to understand from that that it is unparliamentary to call Senator Carr a duffer?
âIt is unparliamentary to reflect upon other members of this place and the other place, as you well know.

âMadam Deputy President, if it has been taken that that is a reflection on Senator Carr, then I withdraw it. However, I would like to suggest he do a bit of study about what the answer he was given actually means. It means that the first brigade is able to be supported and you will have a rotation of front rank troops ready to go. We have that now.
âIs that right? The second one in three months.

âNo, 28 days from the end of June. So we have two brigades now that are ready to go and can reinforce each other. That was the purpose of my answer which Senator Carr had so much difficulty understanding. I think it was actually a direct answer. Senator Collins asked for details about our performance in government. The significant answer is that we have regulars now ready to go at a level of readiness and in numbers that the Labor government never managed to achieve in 13 years of focusing on submarines that would not fire weapons and that were dangerous to go to the bottom of the ocean in, and an over-the-horizon radar system which has left Telstra with a very big embarrassment and difficulty, and which is still not working effectively.

answer.para: The Labor Party focused on big toys for big boys like Mr Beazley and Senator Ray. They did not show any concern at all for the fact that our peacekeeping rolesânow our peace enforcement rolesâand any warlike service at all required men and weapons on the ground to take and hold ground. That is the reality that our troops are facing. Thanks to the reforms that we have put in place, our men and women are better protected and better able to be reinforced than any such force that has gone away since Vietnam.

talk.start.para: âMadam Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. Contrary to the minister's sledging, I do have an interest in the impact of the government's IR agenda on the Defence Force. I have spent half of my life living in RAAF environments.

question.para: Government senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder on my right! The minister cannot hear with the noise that is being made.

âMy question was about Defence Force leave, and the supplementary question is: will the minister guarantee that Australian troops that have been deployed to East Timor will receive that and be replaced within six months so that they are not separated from their families for an unreasonable period? Can the minister outline what action the government is taking to ensure this in an environment where there is no longer Defence Force leave for reservists?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âI am afraid the last sentence leaves me a bit perplexed. Suddenly you are talking about reservists' leave.
âYou have never heard ofâ
âOrder!
âSenator Crowley, it is nice of you to help Senator Collins, but I do not think you are taking it any further.
âMinister, would you please address the chair and ignore Senator Crowley's interjections.
âI am sorry; I should not be distracted. The reality is, as I understand from what the minister has said previously, at this stage the length of the deployment is not known.
âBut we have no Defence Force!

âSenator Collins would like to answer for me. The reality is that it is expected that the peace enforcement process will be relatively short but that peacekeeping process which will follow will be longer. At this early stage, both of them are of uncertain duration. As far as I know, no announcement has yet been made as to what the term of service will be. But the ability to rotate people is there because we now have two brigades that are able to go when needed. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Business Tax Reform: Manufacturing and Mining

talk.start.para: âMy question is to Senator Minchin, the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources.

question.para: Honourable senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder! There is too much general conversation going on across and around the chamber. I cannot hear Senator Crane, and I guess the minister cannot hear either.
âWould you like me to shout to get over the noise?
âNo, I would not like you to shout. I would like you to speak at a normal level, and I would like everybody else to remain silent.
âWould you like me to take a point of order on this?
âNo. Just ask the question.
âI ask the minister: how will the government reforms to the indirect and business tax systemsâ

question.para: Opposition senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âOrder, on my left! I do not need any help.

âMinister, how will the government reforms to the indirect and busi ness tax systems assist Australia's manufacturing and mining industries to be more internationally competitive? In particular, could you inform the Senate of the very positive reaction to this package?

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Industry, Science and Resources

talk.start.para: âI thank Senator Crane for his lucid question. Two great sectors of this economy have borne the brunt of Australia's horse and buggy tax system. They are manufacturing and mining. Manufacturing and mining, in particular, have had to wear the load of the wholesale sales tax which, for reasons that are completely inexplicable, the Labor Party seems to think is such a wonderful taxâshared only by the Solomon Islands and a few others, of course. We have recognised that the tax system is putting a completely unfair burden on manufacturing and mining in this country. That is why we have reformed our indirect tax system, and that is why we announced yesterday major reforms to Australia's business tax system. They will, in combination, represent and mean a very big boost for mining and manufacturing, for investment and exports and, most particularly, for employment in these two key sectors.

answer.para: The manufacturing sector get the benefit of the drop in the company tax rate to 30 per cent by 2001. They lose absolutely the burden of the wholesale sales tax. Fuel costs are reduced; compliance costs are reduced. Our tax reforms are terrific news for the 85 per cent of manufacturing enterprises that qualify for the new simplified tax system and retention of accelerated depreciation. In relation to the car industry, we have rejected the Ralph committee's recommendation that the FBT arrangements be modified in a way that we believe will damage that vital industry.

Research by the economic modellers Econtech shows that manufacturing output will increase by three per cent as a result of our tax reform initiatives. Output in the mining sector is going to increase by over six per cent as a result of our tax reforms. Mining also gets the benefit of our cuts to the company tax rate. They retain the benefits of the deductibility of the removal of mining overburden, prospecting and exploration. They remain immediately deductible. Probably the best news for mining is that, from 1 July 2001, deductibility for so-called black hole expenditures like export market development, mine closures and defending native title claims will be immediately deductible, which the mining industry has been seeking for years. As the Treasurer said, we will be retaining and enhancing for major, long-life capital intensive projects the strategic investment incentive process, with particular regard to investment allowances, on a case by case basis.

Eighty per cent of mining companies in this country have an annual turnover of less than $1 million. That 80 per cent will still retain the benefits of accelerated depreciation and will also get the new simplified tax system. Of course, mining loses the costs of the WST, fuel taxes and other taxes. The reaction from both sectors has been positive. John Conomos of Toyota said:
It is a good result for the automotive industry.
I previously quoted Tony Cutcliff of the Institute of Engineers of Australia. He says:

. . . a rush of foreign money into high technology, more local R&D, more jobs for engineers, a halt to the brain drain and a healthier, more certain climate for domestic investment in start-up companies.

talk.start.para: âYou read this out of your brief!

âYes, but you were not listening. The Minerals Council of Australia has welcomed the government's pragmatic approach. David Stewart, the Managing Director of Pasminco, said that when you look at it in totality it is a very balanced outcome. The Financial Review was very accurate when it said today:

answer.para: Mr Costello can rightly claim that the package will help make Australia a place for investment, business growth and particularly jobs.

talk.start.para: âMy question is to Senator Newman, representing the Minister for Defence. Given that the ADF is now undertaking its greatest operation since the Vietnam War, what action has the government taken to ensure that Australian troops in East Timor will have the appropriate level of medical support for their operation? Can the minister inform the Senate how many more specialist medical officers have been recruited to cover this huge deployment of troops?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âI thank Senator Hogg. I know that he has a continuing interest in these matters. In relation to the question that was asked of me before by Senator Collins, of course the Defence Force has long relied on the reservistsâ

âMadam Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. We are well aware that Senator Newman could not answer the question asked by Senator Collins. She is not entitled to answer a question she could not answer previously. I would ask you to direct her to answer the question asked by Senator Hogg.

âMadam Deputy President, on the point of order: Senator Newman was less than 30 seconds into her answer. She had virtually only said that she thanked Senator Hogg for asking the question, and here is Senator Faulkner again on his feet trying to do everything possible to disrupt the process, not wanting to give Senator Newman any serious opportunity to answer the question and trying to reduce question time to the rubble that it would be under the Labor Party.
âThere is no point of order. The minister is only 20 seconds into answering the question.
âHow did I rate a mention?
âSenator Collins, I do not need your assistance, thank you. I am sure Senator Newman will be getting to the medical support area shortly.

âMadam Deputy President, you are interested in medical care for Defence Force personnel from a long time back. You would know that reservists, as Senator Hogg knows, are very honourably represented amongst the ranks of the medical corps. In fact, specialists in particular come almost exclusively from the reservists. That has been the case for a long time, too. We currently have reservists in the medical corps serving on Bougainville, but the longstanding call-out legislation, which allows for a reserve to be called out in the defence of Australia or in a declared defence emergency, does not apply in East Timor.
