Reservists are able to serve on deployment in other positions within the ADF after volunteering for full-time service. That is how we have reservists in Bougainville at the moment. The health support to the Australian members is integral to the operation, and the processes that have been put in place are good to ensure optimum health preparedness for the deploying ADF personnel.

answer.para: Pre-deployment briefings on current health intelligence, specifically on the environmental and situational health threats that are, or may be, present in Timor have been given to all deploying ADF personnel. Pre-deployment medical and fitness screening is mandatory. Only those persons who are fully vaccinated and operationally fit have been deployed. All deploying ADF personnel have been given antimalarial medication, which will be resupplied as required by the ADF medical facility deployed to East Timor. All deployed ADF personnel have received basic first aid training, and all units have ready access to advanced life support trained medical personnel. To minimise disease and injury threats, preventative medicine trained personnel are being deployed to East Timor. They will provide environmental health support to the deployment and environmental and occupational health advice to the deploying personnel and to their commanders.

All personnel have been dentally checked and any dental problems rectified prior to deployment, and deploying health elements will provide basic dental support in East Timor. Psychological briefings have taken place prior to deployment, and procedures are in place to ensure psychological debriefing of all personnel once they return from this operation. Medical resupply and logistics processes are in place. Air transport will usually be utilised for all medical material. Only blood and blood products sourced from the Australian Red Cross will be used for the treatment of ADF members, and 30 units of blood have been deployed with other stock being kept on hand in Darwin for rapid resupply.

talk.start.para: âMadam Deputy President, I have a supplementary question. Minister, you failed to address the question that I asked, which is: how many more specialist medical officers have been recruited to cover this huge deployment of troops? Secondly, does the minister recall the warning from Australia's Army Land Commander, General Hartley, earlier this year about the critical shortage of medical specialist personnel in the ADF? Why didn't the government respond to that warning instead of denying the shortage, as the Minister for Defence did in parliament last month? Finally, will the minister now give a guarantee that ADF personnel serving in East Timor will have the medical support they are entitled to?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the question is yes. As for the answer to the detail about medical specialists, I think Senator Hogg is under a misapprehension. Medical specialists rarely deploy to a battlefield or an active war zone, which is the situation that could be presented here.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âIt may not be a battlefield, but people may be getting shot at. It is rare for specialists to be deployed in those circumstances. You will get emergency first aid in your unit. You will get a GP type service from the medical officer in your unit. Then, if the matter is more serious than that, you will be evacuated to Australia for specialist service. That is the way you will be treated. Some of those specialists may be Army, Navy or Air Force reservists specialists or civilians in our hospitals in Australia.

âMy question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, Senator Ian Macdonald. Is the minister aware that the draft report of the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation into the class G airspace trial finds that the Civil Aviation Safety Authority board and director failed to act on two critical recommendations: that the trial be reconsidered and that the draft BASI report states that both the Australian Air Transport Association representing the major commercial airlines and CASA's own Airspace Standards Branch believe the model for the G airspace trial was flawed? Does the government know why the CASA board chose to ignore these two very high level recommendations?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: âNo, I do not know. I will ask Mr Anderson if he is aware of it. This question follows on from a matter that Senator Woodley raised with me a couple of days ago when he asked me if I was concerned about the fact that BASI had not released its final report into the G airspace demonstration. As I indicated then, we are not concerned as a government. The G airspace report is a very important one on a very complex matter and it has required a great deal of investigation and analysis. It will be released towards the end of this year. So it will be finished within about a year of when the investigation actually started. That time frame, I am told, Senator Woodley, is entirely normal. You might recall that BASI's investigation into the Monarch Airlines crash in 1993 took just over 12 months and the investigation into a near miss at Sydney airport in 1991 took some 18 months. So the length of time that it has taken for BASI to complete its report into the G airspace demonstration is not unusual.

answer.para: I am sure that Senator Woodley, as someone who follows these things, will appreciate that it takes some time to put together a detailed, professional and definitive air safety report. Specifically, in response to your question, I would expect that a lot of the allegations that you are making, and a lot of the comments that you have made, will be addressed in more detail when the final BASI investigation is released towards the end of this year.

talk.start.para: âMadam Deputy President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for that answer. I wonder, however, Minister, in talking further with the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, whether or not you would seek from him an assurance that what BASI describes as `systematic weaknesses' in CASA will be fixed?

âMadam Deputy President, I raise a point of order. This is a matter that, as Senator Woodley well knows, is before a committee that he chairs and a committee that I chair. Standing order 73(l) states quite clearly that questions shall not contain `proceedings in committee not reported to the Senate'. I ask whether or not this question is in order in view of the fact that there is a reference to both of these committees.

âI understand that it is in order. The standing order that you read out relates to the committee of the whole. As long as Senator Woodley is not anticipating something that is in a report, he is within order.

âCan I get a further clarification of this point of order? This matter that is being examined is directly related to the BASI report and substance from it, as I understand it. I would question whether or not, in view of the fact that it is related to thatâ

âThe rule refers to the committee of the wholeâas in, this particular chamber when it is in the committee of the whole. Provided that Senator Woodley does not reflect upon something that is in the report of the committee that is being developed, he is within order.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: âI am sure that, if the BASI report does make recommendations to improve the Civil Aviation Safety Authority, they will be followed up, particularly if these recommendations are serious or have arisen out of serious incidents. I would mention to Senator Woodley, although I am sure that he does not need to be reminded, that there is an estimates round towards the end of November or early December. Without being definitive, I would expect that the BASI report would be released and available by that time. Senator Woodley will no doubt, in his normal way, very perceptively question the relevant officers at those estimates hearings. It is refreshing at timesâand I do not want to praise Senator Woodleyâto have Senator Woodley at those estimates hearings because he does ask serious questions of policy, unlike the Labor members present at those hearings.
âMadam Deputy President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âLast Monday, Senator Faulkner asked me a series of questions in relation to US military personnel involvement in the East Timor crisis. I seek leave to incorporate a supplementary answer.

speech.para: Leave granted.
The answer read as followsâ
On Monday, 20 September 1999, Hansard page 8359, Senator Faulkner asked me, as acting Leader of the Government in the Senate;
(1) Can the Minister confirm that up to 6,500 US military personnel will be in Australia over coming weeks to participate in exercise Crocodile 99?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âI seek leave to incorporate an additional response to a question from Senator Crowley in the last sitting.

speech.para: Leave granted.
The answer read as followsâ
Response for Senator Crowley
"Child Care in Australia" provided an annual time series of place numbers from June 1991 to June 1998 that is year by year.
- Part year figures would not be comparable in an annual time series due to seasonal influences.
- The Department did not have full year 1998-99 figures to put in the July report.

The figures for December 1998 were available at the time of publication of "Child Care in Australia" but the Department did not consider it appropriate to use them in a table representing annual time series data and my office was not consulted about this issue.
The December 1998 figures, including numbers of services, were released by the Department on 31 August in its Departmental Journal "Australian Social Policy" (1999.1).
- This clearly indicates that neither the Department nor the Government is trying to hide the facts. June 1999 data will be available as usual in the Department's Annual Report.

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp) and the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts (Senator Alston), to questions without notice asked by Senators Gibson, Cook, Mason, Sherry and Murray today, relating to changes in the business taxation system.

There were a number of questions asked of government ministers today on the government's business tax package. It was released yesterday with a lot of hoopla. We thought the government would be able to answer questions of detail on their own measures. What we were faced with was a series of platitudes that led nowhere and certainly shed little light on the detail of a 1,000-page document that the government put down yesterday. It seems once again that the Senate is being ill-served by government ministers. We had this during the GST debate in which matters of detail on tax changes were not able to be answered directly in this chamber. It seems that we are facing the same situation again.

The Labor Party, through the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and shadow Treasurer, Simon Crean, yesterday responded to the government's Review of Business Taxation by saying that there are a number of initiatives that Labor could support. These include a lower company tax rate; the simplification of tax arrangements for small business; measures to encourage greater investment in venture capital in Australia, particularly by foreign pension funds; the issue of rollover relief for scrip for scrip takeovers; and tighter anti-avoidance measures. Indeed, many of those things were matters in our tax program that we put to the electors at the last election and that have now been taken up by the governmentâwe are pleased to seeâin these changes. So it is no wonder we could support them.
In today's Australian Financial Review in the opinion pages, the distinguished economic columnist Alan Kohler had this to say about the government's tax package:
Treasurer Peter Costello has pioneered a new technique in tax policy announcement: you defer the nasty measures for "further consideration" but still count the proceeds from them.

That is indeed a view that could easily be formed. When we look at the measures that have been deferred, we find that, to meet the need of this package to be self-funding, there is a $3.8 billion shortfall. Between the measures being offered in the package and the measures taken to fund the changes being made there is a $3.8 billion shortfall.

This is a serious matter of great consequence because, if business pays $3.8 billion less in tax, who makes up the difference? Ordinary taxpayers on wages and salaries in Australia make up the difference. If this difference is not made up from within business tax, who pays the burden? Ordinary Australians do, and there is a massive shift from the business sector to ordinary PAYE taxpayers. That is why it is very important that the government answer questions about who will pay, where the money will come from and whether they can assure us that ordinary taxpayers will not be slugged again in order to compensate for cuts in business taxation.

My question was about the Ralph report's estimate of a $500 million loss to revenue because of personal income taxes being taxed higher than the income through capital gains, and I referred to attachment T of the government's own document. The Assistant Treasurer could not tell us today or, if he did know the answer, declined to tell the Senate whether or not the figure of $500 million identified in the Ralph report is included in that attachment to the government's own report. Now, $500 million is not a trifling amount. Surely the minister can tell us that. He did not even take it on notice. He should come back and tell Australia, through this chamber, what the facts are on that matter.

But, worse still, the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Alston, did not explain whether the Prime Minister endorses massive tax avoidance by the wealthyâthe top one per cent of income earners in Australiaâbecause in this package they are let off. If there is one way of paying for tax changes, it is by slugging tax avoiders. Because the government remains quiet on this pointâit will not say what it is prepared to doâa huge question mark is left that maybe ordinary wage and salary earners are going to have to make up the difference, because the government does not have the courage or the desire to take on tax avoidance in Australia. They are significant issues that require an answer. Because the government knows its own package and declines to answer, the only conclusion one can come to is that it is hiding here. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âAs usual, we get nothing but criticism from the Labor Party when any reform is undertaken or initiated by this government. We heard some encouraging noises from Senator Cook's colleague in the other placeâthe shadow Treasurer, Mr Creanâlast night following the announcement of this much needed business tax reform package. But, in a sense, it is faint praise because as soon as they acknowledge the need, to a degree, and acknowledge some of the benefits that will accrue from this tax reform package, they are back to their old carping criticism.

speech.para: What is the essence of the criticisms we have heard from Senator Cook? One of the claims he made is that this package is not revenue neutral. I think the Treasurer himself has acknowledged that there might be an approximately $1 billion shortfall in terms of the revenue raised by the current tax system in the business sector as against the proposed reforms. When you are talking about a budget of some $150 billion or moreâas in the current federal budgetâ$1 billion in relative terms is neither here nor there. As was pointed out by economic experts yesterday, it is also well within any margin of error in terms of doing calculations on reforms of this nature.

For the Treasurer to acknowledge the possibility of a $1 billion shortfall is, in reality, neither here nor there. It does not take into account the incentive effects of this new tax structure for business. The Treasurer in his assessments has not taken any account of the incentive effects of the change to business taxation because you cannot measure those in this situation. But, of course, there will be incentive effects from business tax reform: there will be more growth and there will be more employment which, in itself, has beneficial revenue effects.

The reality is that over timeânotwithstanding these changes to taxation in relation to business: lower tax rates for business, reducing the company tax rate from 36 cents in the dollar down to 30 cents in the dollar and halving the capital gains tax rateâit is highly likely that more revenue rather than less revenue will be raised. So that really obliterates the point Senator Cook is trying to make on the revenue issue.

He also raised the issue as to the tax rate for capital gains tax. He claims that because capital gains tax will now be effectively taxed at half the rate that income is taxed, that is somehow unfair. What Senator Cook firstly ignores is that, in the main, capital gains are achieved from assets that are purchased from after tax income, by and large, particularly by individuals. What often happens is that individuals save their after tax income, purchase assets of one form or another with that after tax income and then at some later date may realise a profit on those assets. So to relate the tax rate that you might apply to those assets to the income tax rate is a fallacious argument because, as I have already pointed out, it is after tax dollars in the main that contribute to the accumulation of those assets.

But the more important point is that, in terms of the overall welfare of Australians, it is important that our capital gains tax regime be equivalent to that applied by other similar countries around the world. Even with this great cut to capital gains taxâit has been cut in halfâour rate will still be higher than that of some of our competitors. But at least we are now competitive. The cut will, I think, mean that our rate is only one or two per cent, on average, higher than that of the United States, for instance. That is an important factor when we talk about attracting development capital to this country, because one of the main disincentives to development capital coming into Australia has been our punitive rate of capital gains tax. Unless we urgently implement reforms in that area, capital which is much needed for development in Australia will stay away.

Senator Cook has raised this issue of the relative rate of tax between capital gains and income, but it is not relevant because of the after tax savings that go into capital gains. But, more importantly, in terms of the welfare of all Australians and in terms of the capacity for our economy to expand and create more jobs and create higher incomes for Australians, it is absolutely essential that we have a much lower rate of capital gains tax to encourage that investment and growth in development. That is exactly what the government is doing here. If any criticism could be made of these changes, it is that they do not go far enough, not that they go too far, as Senator Cook would have us believe. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI also rise to take note of the answers given by ministers about the government's proposal for business tax reform. As someone who comes from a manufacturing baseâI spent all my life in the manufacturing industry and the manufacturing sectorâI, like the shadow treasurer, welcome the proposals for reform in the areas of capital gains tax and provision of funds for venture capital. They are long overdue. There is, however, nothing new about the proposals for reforming this area. It is not something that John Ralph suddenly discovered over the past 12 months, it is not something that the Treasurer suddenly discovered over the past 12 months, and it is not something that this government suddenly discovered over the past 12 months; it is an issue that has been on the table in the forefront of debate on manufactur ing, mining and the development of our economy for several years.

speech.para: I recall tabling a report in this chamber in September 1997, a report called Rebuilding Australian Industry, produced by my old union, which contained several similar recommendations on this area. I recall, in the very early stages after my election to the Senate, participating in the production of a report by the Senate Economic References Committee. Creating opportunities: promoting Australian industry was the title of the report. It carried a number of recommendations which went to capital gains tax reform, provision of venture capital funds and a range of other mechanisms to encourage and develop our industrial base. So there is nothing new about these issues.

Senator Alston is, I notice, still in the chamber. He keeps talking about the ALP being a policy free zone. But Senator Alston and his colleagues had no difficulty picking up the 1998 ALP policy platform and ripping out the provisions for changes to capital gains tax to encourage investment in this country and ripping out the proposals for changing the rules facilitating investment of American industry funds in our venture capital industry. Those proposals were there in the early part of 1998; they were adopted by the party in 1997. You do not have any difficulty, Senator Alston, taking those policies from the ALP that you think are useful to you and your government. I presume if you look at a number of your other reforms you will see that some of them are contained within ALP policy.

But I specifically want to raise a couple of issues arising out of the report yesterday. The first one is capital gains tax reform. One of the concerns that I have is that there has been no modelling done by the Treasury or by anyone else of the changes that are being proposed to capital gains tax to see whether or not, at the end of the day, they will result in productive investment in the Australian economy. There has been no modelling to see whether or not the reforms that are being put in place will result in funds finding their way through to investment in industriesânew industries, new production lines, new forms of manufacturing or new goods and ser vicesâwhether they will find their way back into bricks and mortar or whether they will find their way into further investment, more rapid investment or more rapid turnover of shares on the stock market, which only inflates the value of companies that currently exist. That has not been modelled. That has not been put to the test. The umpire is still out on that issue. In terms of revenue neutrality I just want to quote briefly what the Treasurer himself said in his press release. He said:

It is expected that the second stage measures recommended by the Report (and not ruled out today) will be adopted to reduce the cost of the package in the outyears in accordance with the goal of revenue neutrality.
He has conceded in his own press release that the package will not be revenue neutral, except in the year 2000. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI offer my good friend and colleague Senator George Campbell congratulations for at least sticking to the subject. It looked as though he had done a bit of preparation before he came here. But I wonder how long Senator Cook's staff spent trying to find the one comment in this morning's newspapers which made some slight criticism. It seems to be a new Labor Party tactic to quote commentators or newspapers. We heard Mr Beazley and Senator Faulkner yesterday quoting ad nauseam from commentary in the newspapers in relation to the motion on East Timor. While Senator Cook's staff were wading through volumes of paper this morning in order to find the one comment that might suit his argument, I wonder how on earth they went past the media release from the Certified Practising Accountants, where Angela Ryan said:

speech.para: "The government appears to have heeded the call from small business who are drowning in red tape,"

Taken together, these capital gains tax reforms will make investment in small business a much more attractive proposition, and should assist in the growth and employment generating capacity of the economy as a wholeâthe sort of efficiency gains the Ralph review was aiming for.
I wonder why Senator Cook's staff went straight past that press release.
Then there was the press release from the Investment and Financial Services Association, entitled `Good news for saving and investment'. Their CEO, Lynn Ralph, said:
Overall, the Review has produced a set of proposals that will greatly enhance the capacity of the economy to produce improved savings and investment results.

I wonder how Senator Cook's staff went past that media release. Then there was the voice of superannuation, ASFAâwho have not always been that complimentary towards the government, I can promise youâwhich said that the Ralph outcome was largely `balanced and positive'. That is the greatest endorsement you could ever get from ASFA. They said:
. . . the government's response to it has been hailed as positive and balanced . . .
I wonder how Senator Cook's staff went straight past that press release or the one from the National Farmers Federation, which said:
Farmers relieved over Ralph CGT decision.
In fact, the National Farmers Federation in their press release are totally positive and support the government's position.
I wonder how Senator Cook's staff happened to go past the press release of the Taxation Institute of Australia. What do they have to say? They said:
Ralph's Revolution creates a brave new world for Australian business.

I have never heard Senator Conroy commenting on, or giving any credit to, all of these people who have put out press releases yesterday, all in support of the positive moves that have been made by the government in relation to the Ralph report. I just do not know how Senator Cook's staff can retain their jobs if they walked past that press release. Then we have one from the Australian council of university presidents:
Ralph creates the climate for stronger venture capital investment in R&D.

What did Senator Cookâand Senator Conroy in his questionâhave to say about research and development? Here the Australian council of university presidents claim that the Ralph report and the government's decision will create a climate for stronger venture capital investment and R&D. I am sure that Senator Conroy's staff would have gone straight past that press release too, because it would have not have suited his argument. Senator Cook's staff, once again, went straight past that one.

I have not got time to go through them all, but let me say that the Australian Industry Group, one of the major bodies, also welcomed the Ralph report. The Taxation Institute again talks about small business being a `big winner under business tax reforms'. I wonder whether I should post all of these press releases around to Senator Cook's office, because it is obvious that they were not received by his staff. When they searched through to find Alan Kohler's comment, they must have gone straight past that press release. The Certified Practising Accountants again said:
Small business and small investors the winners . . .
We are looking after small businesses and small investors, because they are so important to Australia's economy. Then we have the media release from IFSA, which said:
Good news for savings and investment.

We have Senator Cook coming into this place and providing us with one quote from one commentator. If he is going to be consistent, the way the Leader of the Opposition and Senator Faulkner were yesterday, he should quote the lot. They were prepared to quote the lot yesterday; how about quoting the lot today? I hope Senator Conroy is going to be the next speaker. I am not sure whether he is on or not but, if he is, I am quite sure that he will want to pick up on those endorsements from practically every commentator in Australia in relation to this important report that was released yesterday. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI am hoping that Senator Ferguson will stay, because selective quoting is something he has been guilty of before, and I am afraid he has been at it again today. I invite Senator Ferguson to come and visit Gisborne and Seymour in Victoria. You go on the road out there and you start touting your tax reform package, and you will see exactly how quickly you pull them back into the coalition seats. I have to tell youânotwithstanding Senator Alston's capacity to perhaps run now in Gisborne or Ballarat, where there is a lot of spare presel ections on for the Liberal Party in Victoriaâthat there is plenty in this package to criticise.

speech.para: We have opinion from Alan Kohler in today's Financial Review. Did you miss it? It said that the new business tax system unveiled yesterday is a:
. . . triumph of smoke, mirrors and . . . political tap dancing.
Then you go to Tom Allard in the Sydney Morning Herald . The headline reads "`Heroic' hope for revenue balance". Here is where the deceit in this package is. Mr Allard says:
The Federal Government has relied on . . . an "heroic" assumption that halving capital gains tax (CGT) will cost little in lost revenue to achieve in part its aim of revenue neutrality.

The government wants to say there is a dividend: `When we cut the capital gains tax, there will be a spurt of activity and all of this extra revenue will come in.' Those of you who have followed economics for a while may have heard of Mr Laffer and the Laffer curve in supply-side economics. They ran a huge deficit in America and it is largely discredited.

On the one hand, the government is prepared to argue that it will gain revenue because of this which will offset the losses from the lower rate so that it is a neutral thing. But what it will not acknowledgeâand what Mr Costello yesterday in his press conference refused to acknowledgeâis that there is now a massive incentive to set yourself up so that you can minimise your tax and have your income in the form of assets, so that when you make capital gains on it you then pay less tax. The revenue neutrality argument on the GST makes the assumption that there is no behavioural change on the income tax side.

If you are prepared to believe in that, you believe in the tooth fairy, because the whole reason capital gains tax was introduced in 1985 was the rorts that the wealthy in this country were pulling to avoid income tax. You cannot have it both ways. You cannot say there is a positive behavioural impact from lowering the rates and no negative impact from the income tax revenue collections. These are two conflicting assumptions. You know they are conflicting and you do not care. These figures are as others have described themârubbery.

Brian Toohey is another one that perhaps Senator Ferguson did not bother to read this morning as he quoted ad nauseam from all of the Liberal stooges out there. Chris Murphyâfair dinkum! Senator Ferguson and I have both met Mr Murphy, and Senator Ferguson is fully aware that Chris Murphy and Econtech are the Prime Minister's preferred modellers.

talk.start.para: âHave you rung up Lateline to complain about John Edwards not being identified as a former adviser?

âSenator Alston wants to talk about the fact that John Edwards may have been an adviser to a previous government. Who is Chris Murphy's wife? Guess what, she works in the Prime Minister's office. If you want to start throwing that stuff around, that is fine. But you cannot have it both ways. Let us make it perfectly clear that this bloke is a Liberal Party stooge and has been for years. He rorted and put rubbery figures out during the last election to support your GST packageâand he is doing it again.

speech.para: Do Treasury work for a living nowadays? Treasury were not allowed to model the GST package because they did not show that it was going to be good for you. You have done it again with Senator Minchin today. Has the Department of Industry, Science and Resources modelled the impact on industry? No. What do the public servants down in these departments do now? You just hire your private sector mates, who will produce reports that say exactly what you want. That is the game involved here. That is what is going on. Where are Treasury? Where is the rigour? Treasury should be embarrassed by this performance yet again. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThis is the third limb of the government's taxation reform. We had a GST and personal income tax cuts, and now we have business tax reform. One of the great achievements of this government has been its capacity to invigorate the economy, enhance investment, promote growth and create jobs. To attract business and investment, and to do so in an equitable fashion, has been this government's great performance. The ALP often make the mistakeâand Senator Conroy perhaps typified thisâthat if business succeeds it must somehow be detracting from the average Australian; that somehow if business wins the average Australian loses.

speech.para: It is a paradox born of Labor Party historyâsitting under the tree at Barcaldine during the shearers' strike. It is a paradox that is wrong. That is the talk of last century. That is the talk of a Labor Party still glibly talking of class warfare. The only way this country can progress is if business continues to work. All of those things your party fought for for a hundred years can only be paid for if business works. Socialism is dead. They will only be paid for if business worksâand you know it.

One of the great things about the Hawke-Keating governments was the fact that they recognised that, with social welfare, the cake gets bigger if business wins. It was one of the great achievements of your government.

talk.start.para: âMr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I was just concerned that Senator Mason was not addressing the Senate through the chair. It is a very interesting contribution he is making but I would like him to conform with the standing orders, and I am sure you would too.
âSenator Mason, I would ask you to take note of the point of order.

âThe paradox that Senator Conroy pointed out today is, of course, wrong. It is wrong because the workers own the capital. They own the companies. That is the problem. It does not matter what company it is, ordinary Australians own the big companies. That is what hurts. It is no longer a battle between the owners of capital and the workers. That debate is won and, with globalisation, the ideology that says as a worker you are not an owner of capital, well, that debate is finished.

speech.para: The great thing this government has done is to provide the best economic outcomes in the last 30 years. It has done so on the back of great taxation reform. The current unem ployment rate of 7.1 per cent is the lowest since 1990. These reforms will create more jobs for average Australians. That is another great achievement of this government. In 1998 economic growth in Australia was 4.3 per cent, more than double the OECD average for growth. Why? It was partly on the back of taxation reform. This is the third leg.

We have also experienced low inflation during the last years. More importantly for a party that say they represent the workers, over the last years of this government, wage earners, particularly the low paid, have experienced significant real wage increases. That is one of the great achievements of this government. These are excellent results and it has been a marvellous outcome for average Australians. Those caught in the time warp of believing benefits for business are contrary to the benefits of average Australians are speaking the language of a century ago.

talk.start.para: âYou believe all this, do you?
âI remember hearing Senator Faulkner on the radio talking about how it was marvellous that the Blair government was elected in Great Britain.
âWas it a good speech I made?

âIt was a marvellous speech. The interesting thing was that he welcomed the election of Mr Blair. It was the end of the awful Thatcher regime. The marvellous thing about it was that Mr Blair endorsed the Thatcher compact and wanted nothing to do with the unions. He endorsed the economic proposals of the Thatcher government. There is nothing that Mr Blair would agree with Senator Faulkner on. That is the marvellous thing about the ALP today: they are not relevant to the debate. That is finished. They are irrelevant.

speech.para: The endorsements that Senator Ferguson spoke about say much more about the truth of where this country is going than old, irrelevant socialist rhetoric. The marvellous thing about Mr Blair is that he recognises the irrelevance of the socialist ideal. That is the great thing about him, and that is why I suspect he will continue to be elected. That is why he is so strong. Both parties in Britainâall parties throughout the Western worldâagree with that. The last people who agreed with that old socialist stuff were some members of the Australian Labor Party. I want to just talk about small business. Small business employs most Australians. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: âI ask that business of the Senate notice of motion No. 1 standing in my name for today, relating to the reference of matters to a committee, be taken as a formal motion.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: âI amend the motion as follows:

speech.para: Omit paragraph (2), substitute:
(2) The committee inquire into matters pertaining to superannuation and financial services referred to it by the Senate and inquire initially into:
(a) prudential supervision and consumer protection for superannuation, banking and financial services;
(b) the opportunities and constraints for Australia to become a centre for the provision of global financial services; and
(c) enforcement of the Superannuation Guarantee Charge;
and report on paragraphs (a), (b) and (c) by the last day of sitting in June 2000.
I ask that the motion as amended be taken as formal.

talk.start.para: âIs there any objection to this motion being made formal?

âby leaveâIt is with regret that the opposition has been forced to move an amendment to the Democrat motion to establish a Senate Select Committee on Superannuation and Financial Services. However, it is indeed very necessary and will serve to highlight the hypocrisy the Australian Democrats have displayed on this issue and many others to do with superannuation recently. Labor's amendment is essentially the same motion which Senator Allison gave notice of in this place on 9 March this yearâthat is, the original Democrat motion.

speech.para: Since that time, much has happened. Many hours have been spent negotiating the terms of reference for the establishment of this fine committeeâterms of reference which could be accepted by all political parties. Senator Allison's original motion to re-establish the superannuation committee was broad ranging but contained a number of elements which the opposition was eager to see examined by the committee. The motion stated:
(a) the adequacy of the tax system and related policy to address the retirement income and health care needs of Australians into the new millennium;
(b) strategies for building more effective national retirement income and long-term saving outcomes;
(c) reforms that could be implemented following the completion of the Superannuation Guarantee Charge phase-in to 9 per cent;
(d) the taxation of superannuation, particularly the Superannuation High Income Earners Tax Surcharge legislation and alternative payment mechanism;

These issues are of vital importance to all Australians. The time is right to examine them through a committee that Senator Lees described in a speech to the Investment and Financial Services Association last night as `among the most influential of any Senate committee'.

However, as senators will notice in the motion amended by Senator Allison, the critical issues mentioned above have been excised from the committee's terms of reference. They are completely gone. Gone is the examination of the adequacy of retirement incomes and health. Gone is the examination of the taxation of superannuation, particularly the superannuation surcharge tax. Gone is the national savings focus.

There are two new issues that the committee is being encouraged to examine in Senator Allison's amended motion. They are the prudential supervision and consumer protection of superannuation, banking and financial services and the opportunities and constraints on Australia becoming a centre for global financial services. These issues are important and should be dealt with in an appropriate way. In fact, they are Labor's issues which I sought to have included in Senator Allison's original motion and which she agreed to.

Why is Senator Allison gutting her own motion by removing the references for the committee to examine the critical issues of the adequacy of health care and retirement incomes, the effectiveness and efficiency of the taxation of superannuation and the importance of developing strategies for boosting national savings? The only reason I can think of is that the government has asked Senator Allison not to include these items in her motion for reference to the committee.

I can understand that. After all, why would the government want to have the superannuation surcharge re-examined by a specialist committee which would rake over the fact that it is a policy that is considered a joke? Why would the government want a specialist committee to examine its record on national savings and to point out how it has gutted Labor's co-contribution policy which would have seen billions of dollars flow into savings and point out how it has introduced a raft of policies designed to undermine the confidence of superannuation and savings? Why would the government want a committee to examine its record on the damage it has caused to retirement incomes? The answer is that it would not want these issues examined. It has clearly made this point to Senator Allison.

talk.start.para: âMr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. We gave the honourable senator opposite leave to make a brief statement. I think he has actually picked up the wrong statement because this is not a brief statement, it is a debate.
âThere is no point of order.

âThank you for your contribution, Senator Campbell. It was as insightful as ever. As I was saying, the an swer is that the government does not want these issues examined. It has clearly made this point to Senator Allison who has acted accordingly by gutting her own notice of motion. We are not prepared to let that happen, hence our action in denying this motion formality. Labor is happy to support Senator Allison's original motion. That is the amendment we will seek to move to Senator Allison's amended motion. We want to see how Senator Allison and the other Democrat senators will vote on what is essentially their own motion. If they vote against it, they are sending a clear message that they will do whatever the government asks them to do.

speech.para: We all heard the Treasurer say yesterday that the fairies at the bottom of the garden are in the lounge room and taking tea. This motion is absolute proof of that. We have seen the Democrats recently flip-flop around on a choice of funds. Now they are doing it with the establishment of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation and Financial Services. We want to make it clear to the superannuation industry and the business world who may be thinking that the Australian Democrats are a serious political party that they are quite willing to try to take the applause for re-establishing the Senate committee but have baulked at the hard decisions and slip and slide around at the begging of the government. Perhaps that is what makes the Democrats so attractive to big businessâall you have to do is apply a bit of pressure and they will bend over backwards to assist the government to get its program through, no matter what the cost.

We have always indicated that we would support Senator Allison's motion, albeit we asked that the committee not be established until after 30 June this year to allow for a full and open debate on the GST package. That was always our position and still is our position. We did have a couple of issues relating to the financial services part of the committee that we wanted included and they have been. Labor has been negotiating with the Democrats on the terms of reference.

talk.start.para: âMr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I draw your attention to standing order 187 which says that a senator shall not read a speech. This senator is clearly in breach of that standing order. I ask you to call him to order.
âOn the point of order: I think it is a silly point of order that Senator Campbell has taken.

interjection.para: Senator Ian Campbell interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âIt may well be valid, I do not know. On the point of order, I make this point. In the chamber at 2 o'clock yesterday, Senator Alston, I think appropriately, read a speech for well in excess of 20 minutes, as did I. He did it as Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate and I did it as Leader of the Opposition. It happens often in this place. I do not know whether Senator Conroy is reading a speech.
âHe sought leave to make a brief statement. He is reading word for word from a speech.
âOrder! Senator Campbell.
âI do not know whether or not he is using copious notes. I am listening to the substance of what he is saying.

interjection.para: Senator Ian Campbell interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âSenator Campbell, I have called you to order a number of times now. I shall not call you to order again.
âI was just making the point that it is an easy point of order.

interjection.para: Senator Ian Campbell interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âDo you want to challenge me?
âMr Acting Deputy Presidentâ
âThat remark was made to the Manager of Government Business in the Senate.
âAs I say, it is normally made when senators become frustrated with other senators, sometimes when they have been given leave to make a statementâ
âA brief statement.

âOr sometimes when they have been given leave to make a brief statement. As you would be aware, Mr Acting Deputy President, this has always been generously interpreted by the chair. It is often the case that speeches are read in here. It is often appropriate that speeches are read in here. It is often appropriate that copious notes are used.

interjection.para: Mr Acting Deputy President, I think it would be sensible for you to treat that point of order in the way that many others who have occupied the chair have treated such a point of order when it is made out of frustration, as clearly appears to be the motivation of the Manager of Government Business at this time. He is possibly a little out of control and I think we can forgive him for that. I really do think you should not rule in favour of that point of order and you should ask him to seek some counsel from wiser heads in the government before he takes that sort of point of order again.

talk.start.para: âIn accordance with the precedents established by previous presidents and previous acting deputy presidents, I will rule that Senator Conroy is reading from copious notes. I will, however, remind Senator Conroy that he did ask leave of the Senate to make a brief statement, and I think he is testing the bounds of the definition of `brief'.

âI take your point, Mr Acting Deputy President. I can assure you I have almost finished making all the points I wish to make on this issue. If I can continue uninterrupted, it will be over in a moment.

speech.para: Labor has been negotiating with the Democrats on the terms of reference for the committee for some time. I was under the impression that just over two weeks ago we had an agreement on a terms of reference which we were confident the Senate would support. However, we now find out that the Australian Democrats have changed their mind on the committee's terms of reference and have removed the substantive elements on the government's bidding. That is the key point: on the government's bidding.

That sort of policy slip-sliding is not good enough. Senator Lees claimed in her IFSA speech last night, `Like every political party, we have aspirations to eventually govern.' Serious political parties who have aspirations to govern do not give notices of motion then substantially change them without good reason. No such reason exists for the amendments moved by Senator Allison, and this issue has done little to assist people treat the Democrats as a serious political party. Our amendment will restore the major terms of reference to this motion and I ask the Senate to support it. Senator Murray recently commented, `We're no longer the fairies at the bottom of the garden. We're a bunch of trolls.' I can only agree.

talk.start.para: âby leaveâI need to respond to the remarks of Senator Conroy. This reference to a new select committee for superannuation to reconvene in fact the previous one has been around since 6 October. I do not think any terms of reference for anything at all in this chamber has taken as many drafts, as much consultation and as much time as this one.

speech.para: Let me just go through the ways in which the Democrats have accommodated the ALP in respect of the details of the terms of reference. The ALP requested that looking into the question of Australia becoming the centre for the provision of global financial services should be addressed by this committee. We agreed, although strictly speaking that has very little to do with superannuation.

The starting date of 11 October was simply to accommodate the ALP's need for staffing this committeeâagain, we went along with it. That the chair would be appointed by the Senate is, again, another concession to the ALP. It is one which I think is quite reasonable, but it was again part of our consultation which accommodated the ALP's concerns about timing for themselves and their own staffing. The question of the enforcement of the super guarantee legislation was another important issue brought in in the last couple of weeks to accommodate people in the union movement and also the ALP. Again, it was another accommodation.

Senator Conroy also said that we have been, I think the words were, `slip-sliding' on this issue of the question of the adequacy of the tax system and related policy to address the retirement income and health care needs of Australians into the new millennium. This is the term of reference which he complains about having disappeared.

The ALP over the last few weeks has agreed that we would start with those three issuesâthe prudential supervision and consumer protection for superannuation, the centre for provision of global financial services and SGC. It was always agreed between our parties that that would be the work the Senate committee would embark on initially and that it would report by the last day of sitting in June next year on those issues. They are all very substantial. They will take that amount of time. They are complex. They are difficult.

We accommodated the government, who did not want us to spell out exactly what the next round of inquiry would be about. But we do have in the terms of reference the words which make it quite clear that this Senate committee will look at superannuation and financial services issues. Senator Conroy, Senator Sherry and others in the ALP have had my commitment that, by agreement of the Senate, we will proceed down that path when these other matters are dealt with. But there are a number of superannuation bills which I would like to think this Senate committee could deal with as well.

So it is not appropriate for us at this time to be spelling out in great detail an inquiry which we will not likely get to at least until the latter part of next year and maybe not at that time either. I agree with the government. It is not appropriate for us to be providing at this early stage such detail on an inquiry which may not take place until well into the future. I would be happy if it started quickly, but the Senate can only manage so many terms of reference at any time, and I do not think this committee could deal with more than the terms of reference that are already up.

I think the ALP is just procrastinating. I think it has just offered up another opportunity to bash the Democrats, as the ALP has been so fond of doing lately. Really we are talking about semantics; we are talking about two or three words being in or out. It does not matter one way or the other. It is not to be dealt with by this committee. The terms of reference in my motion make that very clear indeed. I really think it is time that the ALP simply got on with this whole questionâor perhaps it does not want this committee to be set up; perhaps it is not interested in superannuation issues at all.
