talk.start.para: âby leaveâI want to briefly respond to aspects of Senator Conroy's remarks which I felt were particularly offensive. The Democrats are more than able to defend themselves, and they have done so very successfully. One reason why people find it impossible to deal with the Labor Party, to reach agreement with the Labor Party, is the sheer level of abuse which occurs in dealings with your party.

speech.para: There were three parties to the negotiations. Each of us had particular interests. As Senator Allison has pointed out, the terms of reference which this committee is looking at are essentially those which Labor strongly support, and some of which Labor initiated. What a joke for Senator Conroy to get up and attack the superannuation surcharge. As far as I am aware, the Labor Party now supports the superannuation surcharge. Maybe it does not; maybe we are due for another backflipâour third or fourth. In noting that the advisers are in the box, I do wish the Labor Party could get their lines straight on this. They are all over the place. I may well make a longer speech on this in due course.

Senator Conroy got up and spoke about the co-contribution. What a joke: it was not Labor's policy. Labor dropped that policy at the last election. Senator Conroy never listens to anybody, but maybe his advisers in the box will point out to him that this was not Labor Party policy. So to stand up and read this trite nonsense is pathetic.

We had negotiations over a very long period of time. I felt in the end that the various particular preferences of all parties were met. The motion, from our point of view, is not idealâthat is the truth. But we had to note the numbers in this chamber and we had to reach accommodations. That is precisely what happened.

For those that read Hansard on these matters, I would note for their information that we have seen another relentlessly abusive speech from Senator Conroy; it is the very aspect of the Labor Party which I think a lot of people absolutely detestâand quite rightly so. Senator Conroy, you will remain on that side of the chamber for as long as it takes for the Labor Party to learn its lessons and learn to sit down and talk with people, not try to browbeat people in the way in which you have done this afternoon.

talk.start.para: âIs there any objection to this motion being taken as formal?
âYes.

subdebate.2.para: Contingent motion (by Senator Allison, at the request of Senator Lees) proposed:

That so much of standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Lees moving a motion relating to the conduct of the business of the Senate, namely a motion to give precedence to general business notice of motion No. 136.

talk.start.para: âThe unfortunate situation that we have before the chair is that arrangements that have been come to by parties in the chamber appear to have been breached. That is always a difficulty and often the Senate debates similar issues. In any chamber of any parliament where no one party or coalition of parties has a majority, there often need to be situations where there is discussion and consultation and negotiation on issues that come before us.

speech.para: The situation which we face in this instance is that there has been consultation and negotiation and, as a result of that level of discussion and involvement, agreements have been reachedâand that is often the caseâbut unfortunately those agreements and understandings have been dishonoured. That is why we have now had three senators seeking leave to discuss the substantive issue before the chair. I would be as disappointed as Senator Conroy, or my other colleagues who have carriage of these sorts of issues, if I had been intimately and directly involved in negotiations and come to understandings and found that they did not stand after a little bit of arm twisting from the government.

I put seriously to the Australian Democrats that it is just simply no way to do business in this chamber. I would acknowledge that it is not normally the caseâin relation to the way this chamber works, the procedures of the place, the processes that we haveâthat understandings reached outside the chamber are not honoured when we come to finalise matters actually in the parliament itself. It is an unusual circumstance; it is not the norm. It normally does not occur. I think most senators in this place would acknowledge that that is a fair comment.

It leaves us all in a very difficult situation when we face this unfortunate set of circumstances. I certainly understand the very great disappointment and anger that my colleague Mr Kelvin Thomson in the House of Representatives feels, given the amount of time and effort that has been involved in coming to understandings with Senator Allison on such an important issue.

This has meant that the opposition is going to progress the agreement it properly reached with the Australian Democrats. We have no alternative in that circumstance but to declare this motion not formal. We will support the suspension of standing orders to allow Senator Allison to put her motion. We will not continue to debate the suspension of standing orders now. Other senators may care to engage in that debate. But we want a capacity to put before the chamber an amendment which will allow the arrangements that were come to between senators, in good faith, so the chamber itself can determine this particular issue.

I say very seriously to the Australian Democrats, but it is as well directed to anyone in the chamber including members of the government as well as members of the opposition: if you come to these sorts of arrangements, as you must do in a chamber like this where no party has a majority, where this place works best if we come to understandings and conduct negotiations in the lobbies, in the margin, and then they are breached, unfortunately this place is simply not going to work. We will support the suspension of standing orders on the basis and for the reasons I have outlined. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âAs the Australian Green watching in on this debate, I will also be supporting the suspension of standing orders. The best I can do in this situation is ask: what is in the public interest? Well, superannuation affects every Australian. What I am hearing here is that the Labor Party wanted to at least consolidate, if not expand, the terms of reference of this committee to make sure that important items were not left out of the purview of the committee that is going to do the investigation and had reached an agreement with the Democrats on that matter. What I also hear is that, through negotiations with the government, the reverse has occurred: the government wants to constrict some very important matters that this inquiry might look at as far as the interests of Australians going into the next millennium are concernedâin particular, to hold off the impact of tax policy, for example, on superannuation.

speech.para: It is a simple matter for me to arbitrate as far as the public interest is concerned here. You have one side putting pressure on the Democrats and the Democrats acceding to narrow the matters that the inquiry might look at. You have the other side, the Labor Party in this case, saying, `Let's make sure that nothing is left out.' In those circumstances, I believe the Democrats are doing a disservice to their own initial approach to this matter and to the public to have caved in to the government.

Senator Allison herself has said, `Well, some matters we will put off to a later inquiry,' and indicated that that inquiry might not even occur. It might disappear into the wide blue yonder. I am not going to support that. I think the Labor Party is correct here. If I hear the amendment correctly, I will also be supporting that. I would ask the Democrats to reconsider what is in the public interest here. I think if they do that they will also be supporting the arrangement that was touted apparently outside this place with the Labor Party and now that it is here in the chamber.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

subdebate.2.para: Motion (by Senator Allison, at the request of Senator Lees) proposed:
That general business notice of motion no. 136 may be moved immediately and have precedence over all other business today till determined.

talk.start.para: âThe question is that the motion be agreed to. Those of that opinion say aye; those against say no. Senator Conroy, you don't speak to this motion.

âMr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. I hear your ruling from the chair that you do not speak to this motion. This of course is a matter of opinion, and I do recall on one or two occasionsâon a very few occasionsâwhen the opposition has chosen to speak. I think we have all accepted that it is not the norm. It is an unusual circumstance.
âYou are getting a bit unctuous, John.

âNo, no. But it has occurred, so I would not want the Hansard record to show that it is not competent for senators to speak on the procedural motion. I think it would be fair for you to make the point that it would be an unusual circumstance. I think it has occurred in the past and it has been a matter of some discussion, as you may be aware, at the Procedure Committee about the appropriateness or otherwise. On this occasion the opposition will not be exercising its rights to speak, but I do draw your attention to a capacity to speak to the motion if senators so require, albeit a comparatively unusual circumstance in this chamber.
âThank you, Senator Faulkner. It is not the substantive motion.

interjection.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.

subdebate.2.para: Motion (by Senator Allison) proposed:
Thatâ

(1) A Select Committee on Superannuation and Financial Services be appointed with effect on and from 11 October 1999, with the same functions and powers as the Select Committee on Superannuation appointed by resolution of the Senate on 5 June 1991, and reappointed on 13 May 1993 and 29 May 1996, except as otherwise provided in this resolution.
(2) The committee inquire into matters pertaining to superannuation and financial services referred to it by the Senate and inquire initially into:
(a) prudential supervision and consumer protection for superannuation, banking and financial services;
(b) the opportunities and constraints for Australia to become a centre for the provision of global financial services; and
(c) enforcement of the Superannuation Guarantee Charge;
and report on paragraphs (a), (b) and (c) by the last day of sitting in June 2000.
(3) The committee have power to consider and use for its purposes the minutes of evidence and records of the Select Committee on Superannuation appointed in the previous three Parliaments.

(4) The committee consist of 7 senators, 3 nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, 3 nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate and 1 nominated by other parties or independent senators.

(5) The nomination of the final member to be determined by agreement between the other parties and independent senators and, in the absence of agreement, duly notified to the President, the question of representation on the committee of other parties or independent senators be determined by the Senate.
(6) The Senate, by subsequent resolution, appoint a member of the committee as its chair.

talk.start.para: âThank you, Mr Acting Deputy President.
âDo we really need Faulkner in here?
âI appreciate Senator Kemp's assistance, as always. We have the peanut gallery over there. I welcome their contribution.
âSenator Conroy, address the chair.

âI have amendments. I rise to speak again. I have already spoken, briefly, on this issue, so I do not intend to take up too much time in the chamber. I have made a number of points. Senator Brown is absolutely right, and Senator Brown was party to the agreement. I spoke with both Senator Brown and Senator Harradine on this issue, and I obtained their support. As Senator Allison is not denying, I also had an agreement with Senator Allison. The key point Senator Allison made herself was that, following pressure from the government, she agreed to amend the motion without consultation or referral back to the Labor Party. She came to us and said, `We're taking this out because the government don't want it.' The question for good practice is whether every single motion that is now to be passed through this chamber has to have the agreement of the government.

speech.para: That is the implication that Senator Allison has given us in her speech. It is the implication we have been getting from Senator Lees. Whatever happened to expression, democracy and Senate inquiries that are not subject to veto by the government? That appears to be where we are today. The Democrats will say, `We don't want any terms of reference to go forward in this chamber unless the government agree to it.'

It is not good enough. This is an independent chamber. It is not part of the executive of government. It is not here to rubber-stamp what the government wants. It is here to look at issues. It is here to look at the issues, in particular, that the government does not want it to look at. We spent six months on the GST inquiry, and we came up with a whole host of information that the government had sought to hide from the people of Australia during the last federal election. Some have even gone as far as arguing that this GST committee proved the need for the independence of the Senate. Independent commentators like Laurie Oakes said that the information that flowed from the GST inquiryâwhich, at that time, the Democrats were prepared to stand up forâproved the need for the independence of the Senate.

We now see the trolls, as they were described by Senator Murray, cuddling up into the kitchen. This is your leader, Senator Kemp. He said, `The fairies have come into the kitchen.' They are taking tea. The government have invited them into the cabinet room with a bit of Earl Grey and a few chocolate biscuits and, all of a sudden, the Democrats have abandoned every principle they ever had about the independence of the Senate.

talk.start.para: âNever had any!

âThank you. I will take that interjection. What is at stake today is that, if the government put pressure on the Democrats about an inquiry into something the government do not want inquired into, the Democrats will fold. This will not serve them well, because this is the model of Victoria, and we have just seen what happened on the weekend in Victoria. Secret government saw the government over there destroyed. Where is Jeff Kennett today? He is crawling to the Independents and to the bloke that he referred to in somewhat unflattering terms. He has had to give them a ring and say, `Mate, I didn't really mean it. I didn't really call you that.' Where are the honesty and the openness? Where are the government in Victoria's members in Gisborne, Seymour, Ballarat, Bendigo and Ripon? What happened to all of them?
âMr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order which goes to relevance. We do not mind the honourable senator talking at length, but will he please return to the subject?
âI am concerned that the honourable senator is responding to a lot of interjections. I would ask him to address his comments to the chair.

âI thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President, for that. I am making a point about openness and democracy, and that is what this chamber is meant to be about. That is what the Democrats have championed for years. They want a vibrant Senate that will examine parts of government that the executiveâthe Prime Minister, the Treasurer and, in particular, the Assistant Treasurerâdo not want us to examine. We know what happens. This committee has been an embarrassment to Senator Kemp. This committee has humiliated the Assistant Treasurer. It has consistently brought forward sound policy positions that the Assistant Treasurer has been humiliated over. He has shown to be not across the details. He has been shown to be incompetent on the issues that have been raised and incapable of defending himself when the committee has brought its reports down.

speech.para: That is the nub of this debate. This debate is about the Democrats getting into bed with Senator Kemp to protect Senator Kemp. The Democrats have nothing to fear from this committee. The Democrats have no reason to give in to the government. The only reason they have to give in to the government is to protect Senator Kemp. You, Mr Acting Deputy President Watson, know more about this topic than the Assistant Treasurer. That is the constant embarrassment to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. Day in and day out the committee comes up with coherent, responsible public policy. The Assistant Treasurer sits here and mumbles his way through question time. He has not a clue. He can barely manage his brief, and he is exposed consistently.

Why would the Democrats want to stop good public policy discussion? That is the question. That is why we are moving this amendment. Why wouldn't you want the committee to talk about the adequacy of the tax system and related policy to address the retirement income and health care needs of Australians into the new millennium? Why wouldn't you want a committee to look at that? That is a significant public policy issue. The health care needs of the baby boomer generation are going to be hitting. If you wait until 2015, you will suddenly go, `Oh, all of a sudden we've got this health care crisis.' We need this committee to look at it now. We need to know about the retirement income needs of Australians in the next 10 years.

If you wait 10 years and spend your time now pretending it is not a problem and sabotaging the retirement incomes of Austral iansâlike this government has been doing for the last 3Â½ yearsâyou will not be able to respond when the time comes. Why wouldn't you want terms of reference that look at the strategies for building more effective national retirement income and long-term savings outcomes? How could you possibly want not to examine that? Senator Kemp has consistently tried to confound the establishment of this committee and demanded that the terms of reference be acceptable to the government or it will vote against it. That is what has been going on. They do not want terms of reference that look at the effective national retirement income and long-term savings outcomes.

The original terms of reference also included a reference to reforms that could be implemented following the completion of the superannuation guarantee charge phase-in to nine per cent. We all know that in this country we have a looming crisis in this area. The government abandoned the former government's co-contribution and abolished its own contribution.

talk.start.para: âYou abandoned it, too!

âYou abandoned it and have done nothing. We got the savings rebate. Remember that, Senator Allison? It was a joke. Treasury admitted publicly, again to the humiliation of the government and of the Assistant Treasurer, that the so-called savings rebate would, in actual fact, lead to a reduction in national savings. The savings rebate saw money being taken from ordinary battling Australians and given to people who already had wealth and savings. You did not have to create any new savings to qualify for the savings rebate. All you had to do to qualify for the rebate was already have some money or savings. Not only was there no incentive for increased savings but you got the rebates by doing nothing.

speech.para: This parliament knows and has acknowledged consistently for 10 years that we need to look at what we are going to do after the superannuation guarantee phase-in to nine per cent is finished. Nine per cent is not enough for the majority of Australians to live on. It is acknowledged that somewhere between 15 per cent and 23 per cent of your annual income needs to be put into long-term savings so that you have enough money to live on when you retire. The former government had a policy to get it up to 15 per cent. This government chose not to pursue it. It was its right to do so. I think it is bad policy, but it is its right to. We now have many hundreds of thousands of ordinary Australians who will be retiring with just nine per cent and will still require access to the social security system.

The whole point when it was designed with bipartisan supportâI believe the Democrats also supported it, so there was unanimous support in the chamberâwas for the co-contributions. Senator Kemp, I know you did not have responsibility in this area, but leading into 1996 the government said, `We will keep that, but we choose to vary the means of delivery.' Four billion dollars worth of tax cuts would have been put into people's long-term retirement incomes that you said in your 1996 election platform you would support. Then, like a number of other core commitments, it suddenly became non-core. This government abandoned it. That was the first part of the destruction of people's retirement incomes. Hundreds of thousands of dollars of retirement income were tossed out by this government so that they could give money to people who already had money.

Even the government became embarrassed by the savings rebate. Last year when the ANTS package came, what happened to the savings rebate that was there to fix this problem? They abandoned it. They knew the savings rebate was a dog. They knew it would lead to lower national savings and yet they did not care. They cared about looking after their mates. Like in the Ralph package yesterday, where again they have not addressed this issue, they are giving money to their mates. We are seeing huge gains for the people on higher incomes.

I noted that in question time today Senator Murray even had a question for Senator Kemp on this issue. He said that 70 per cent of capital gains at the moment go to the top 20 per cent. He did not mind voting for a tax package a few months before which saw 50 per cent of the gains from the ANTS package going to the top 20 per cent. They shaved $1 billion off it. All of a sudden, he has a conscience about the 70 per cent of capital gains revenue that will be given away to the top 20 per cent. No doubt if he is able to knock a couple of hundred million dollars off that, he will be voting to give the top 20 per cent all the big benefits in the business tax reform package as well.

Many good things are in the business tax reform package, as the shadow Treasurer has said. If this government was actually prepared to talk to the Labor Party rather than just being insulting and abusive as the Treasurer was yesterday, it might be able to get a decent bipartisan package. The Treasurer might be prepared to do so. You can sit there on the other side of the chamber and say, `What did he call you?' Then, when it is pointed out that all the Treasurer was doing is abusing us, the Assistant Treasurer just laughs. He wants it both ways in this debate.

But what is wrong with having a look at the taxation superannuation, particularly in light of the Ralph report? What is wrong with looking at the taxation of superannuation, particularly the superannuation high income earners tax surcharge legislation and alternative payment mechanisms? Why don't the government want to look at that and, more importantly, Senator Allison, why don't the Democrats?

What we are moving today may seem very familiar to you because it was originally listed as `Notice given on 9 March 1999, 136, Senator Allison: to move'. This is your original motion. You have let the government bully you and force you into abandoning your own position, and you have caved in to Senator Kemp and Treasury. That is what has happened. Caving in to Senator Kemp! It is almost too frightening for words. Wait until they turn up the pressure and wheel out Senator Alston and Senator Hill on you again, and wait until the Treasurer and the Prime Minister start on you on Ralph. You have caved in on something that is simple and fundamental to this chamber and, if the government are not prepared to support a terms of reference for a select committee, you say, `Well, we will not do it; we will give them what they want.'

How on earth can opposition parties stand back and not say anything when we reach a deal with youâwhen we think we have an agreement? We have taken responsibility for the fact that two weeks ago you stood up and sought to move the original motion and, due to confusion on our side, it was denied formality. Within two weeks and after a couple of phone calls from Senator Kemp and his office, you have caved in. What sort of serious political party do you try to portray yourselves as? A bit of pressure from Senator Kemp! I would not mind if it was from Senator Alston. I would not mind if at least a few of the heavyweights had been brought in to put the weights on youâthen, at least, it would have been, `Well, you know, we were called in.' I would not have minded if it had been Senator Hill or Senator Alstonâone of the bovver boys from over there. I know Senator Alston has called you a lot of names over the years in the chamber. I would not have minded himâbut Senator Kemp! It is an insult to all Democrat members. It is an insult to Senator Brown, who was party to the agreement, and it is an insult to Senator Bartlett that you caved in to Senator Kemp.

The substantive issue that we are debating in these amendments, which are now circulating, is what is wrong with those issues. I am looking forward to your contribution. Do not just stand up and say that the government did not like them. Stand up and argue why you do not want to look at retirement incomes and health care needs, why you do not want to look at the national retirement income and long-term savings outcomes, why you do not want to look at what we should do after the nine per cent phase in has finished, and why you do not want to look at the taxation surcharge. I know why Senator Kemp does not want to talk about the surcharge. It is called a tax, for a start. It represented the big lie in their first budget and it represented dishonesty to Australian people when the government said that they would not put in any new taxes. They called it something else fancy and then they turned around and put in a surcharge, and it has been a disaster. They have not been able to get as much money from it as they projected and it has caused enormous cost to ordinary, battling superannuation earners. But Senator Kemp is forever trying to pretend that it is a great measure.
Why don't we look at another mechanism? You have suggested other mechanisms in the past, Senator Allison, and we have suggested other mechanisms in the past.
Senator Kemp interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âWhat we are seeing is Senator Kemp, over on the other side, flapping his gums as he always doesâthe waffle will come out. I hope that he is going to make a contribution. Why don't you stand up and tell us why you do not want these things, Senator Kemp? Let us hear even a minute. That is an invitation, a standing invitation, for you to give us the government's reasons why you do not want these investigated, why you do not want the Senate to look at these. Because you do not understand themâthat is the answer.

speech.para: Senator Alston interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âSenator Alston, I invite you to join the debate. You are at least a heavy hitter, someone with a bit of political experience. As I said, the preselections in Frankston East or Ballarat are now available, Senator Alston. I know that you have run for Ballarat before. I know that you have had a go and lost. I know that you have been up there wandering around in the past, but here is your big chance. You can get on that white charger that Jeff rode off on and ride back into town. They need someone to save them down there. They have absolutely collapsed.

speech.para: Senator Alston interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âIt is important that this chamber has independence, Senator Alston. It is important for the future of Australians' retirement incomes that they know what faces them. Your contribution today, Senator Allison, by caving in to the government, is letting down hundreds of thousands of Australians who want to know the sort of information that this very high quality committeeâ
âOrder! Senator Conroy, you have referred to your amendments, but I do not think you have moved them.
âI seek leave to move my amendments together.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: âI move the following amendments to Senator Allison's motion:

speech.para: (1) Paragraph (2), omit "matters pertaining to superannuation and financial services referred to it by the Senate and inquire initially into".
(2) Before paragraph (2)(a), insert:

(aa) the adequacy, effectiveness and efficiency of the current superannuation tax arrangements and related public policies to address the retirement income, aged and health care needs of Australians into the new millennium;
(3) Omit paragraph (2)(c), substitute:
(c) the administration of small amounts, including enforcement of the Superannuation Guarantee Charge, portability and access to the Lost Members' Register.
(4) At the end of paragraph (2), add "and on other matters on a date to be determined by subsequent resolution".

talk.start.para: âVery briefly, I concur with the thrust of Senator Conroy's remarks because this is a very important inquiry and it should be taken seriously. I was amenable to the wider terms of reference of the inquiry but, apparently, due to government pressure, Senator Allison and the Democrats have taken these key issues of the retirement income and health care needs of Australians off the agenda of that inquiry. We have two questions to ask there. The first is: why don't these matters relate to the other terms of reference of the inquiry into the superannuation welfare of Australians? The second is: why did the Democrats agree to government pressure to narrow the terms of reference of the inquiry when they did not have to? The mathematics of the Senate is such that, had the Democrats proceeded, they had both the Australian Greens' support and the Labor Party's support, and therefore they had the numbers in the Senate to ensure that their original terms of reference got through. They did not have to bow to the dictates of the government.

speech.para: As a political party that has always supported transparency in the public interest, we need to hear much more from Senator Allison about the negotiations that took place between the government and the Democrats. Every Australian is aware that there is a new configuration of power in this place. But when you see an important issue like this being altered when it does not need to beâin other words, the Democrats are doing this as a favour to the government because, had they stood their ground, they would have prevailed and the inquiry would have proceeded as originally put forward by themâyou have to ask: what is the quid pro quo? What are the other factors that have been brought in to the discussions with the government? The public has a right to know this.

Otherwise, and I say this to the Democrat members present, the public will begin to gain the impression that the Democrats not only are moving closer to the government but also are in a working relationship with the government for mutual advantage which is not in the public interest. Changing these terms of reference is not in the public interestâit is in the government's interest but it is not in the public interest. We have the Democrats unnecessarily working against the public interest by narrowing these terms of reference.

Senator Allison may not even know what is being traded here. It may be that other members of the Democrats such as the Leader of the Australian Democrats or senior staffers are negotiating with the government on a range of other matters and have agreed, for the convenience of the government, to accede to narrowing the terms of reference of this inquiry. We need to knowâthe Senate ought to be putting pressure on the Democrats now and that is what I am doing hereâwhat those other matters are. What is going on behind closed doors in the mutual self-interest of the Democrats and the government against the wider interests of the public of Australia?

The Democrats have been sticklers for transparency in government. What has happened here is they are now becoming part of the government. So they have to be consistent and transparent about this when they are affecting government outcomes. This is a government outcome that we are dealing with here.

I say to Senator Allison, because I know she is going to follow me in this debate, that a lot of people will be listening carefully to what she says in answer to this question: what are the other issues that have come into play to break an agreement that the majority of the Senate had arrived at and to unnecessarily narrow the terms of reference of this inquiry because the government wanted it? You just do not do that off the cuff; you just do not do that to be nice because the public interest is here. Something else is being traded. The Senate has a rightâbecause the public has a rightâto know what that something else is.

I say to Senator Allison: be straight with us; tell us what the other matters are and tell us what the other advantage to the public is that the Democrats see in agreeing with this arrangement unnecessarily with the government. Then both the public and I can understand. Only thenâif necessary and if it is important enoughâwould I change my voting intention here, which is to vote with the opposition. There is the challenge: it is not to simply get up and say, `We have an arrangement with the government and we have agreed to change an agreement made with the rest of the Senate'; the challenge is to get up and say what is being traded here. That is what I want to hear.

talk.start.para: âI am closing the debate, I hope. What we have seen this afternoon is political opportunism at its worst in this chamber in the last three years since I have been here.
âWhat is your price?

âSenator Bolkus, if you wanted to say something, perhaps you could raise the matter of the EPBC Bill. Why not? Let us open the debate altogether. You had your chance; you should have got up a little earlier.

speech.para: We can always expect Senator Brown to jump on the bandwagonâSenator Brown who has had little involvement in the committees in this place; Senator Brown who has not come along to any of the committees that I have been involved in, and that is a consider able number; Senator Brown who has moved in his place his own terms of reference to the environment references committee which I chair and who has never even bothered to consult me about this matter individually. For Senator Brown to come into this place and complain about breaches of agreement and lack of consultation, openness and transparency is the height of hypocrisy, and I could not believe I was hearing it.

Let us just look at exactly what we are talking about here so that we see the absurdity of the ALP proceeding down this path. We are talking about terms of reference which have changed very slightly in their wording. I am going to go through those terms because those people who are listening to this debate would have no idea. They would imagine that the Democrats have agreed to some amazing arrangement with the government that is beyond the scope of this place or beyond anything the ALP might have imagined, so let me just go through the wording. The ALP amendments state:
The committee inquire into matters pertaining to superannuation and financial services referred to it by the Senate and inquire initially into . . .

Then there are three matters: prudential supervision and consumer protection for superannuation, banking and financial services; opportunities and constraints for Australia to become a centre for the provision of global financial services; and enforcement of the superannuation guarantee charge. At every point in the discussions over these terms of reference, the ALP has agreed that this committee will look at those three matters initially and that it will report back in June next year.

Senator Conroy and Senator Faulkner talk about breaches of agreement. This was always the agreement, such as it was, in terms of consultation and drafts going from one office to the other trying to reach some agreement, some accommodation, on this issue. It was always understood that those would be the matters this inquiry would look into initially. The adequacy of the tax system and related policy to address retirement incomes et cetera are fine things for the Senate to look into, and have my support, but we always agreed not to deal with those matters until we had dealt with these other matters. I am quite happy to entertain terms of reference which go to the wording of the ALP, but we all agreed that this was not the right time to do that.

It has been fairly obvious to me since coming into the Senate three years ago that the best outcomes from the work of the committees in this place come from reaching consensus, reaching accommodation, with each of the parties in this place. That is what I have attempted to do for the last seven monthsâsince 6 March this year. Senator Conroy says there has been no discussion with his office. That simply is not true. The emails just in the last week between my office and his and between my office and Senator Kemp's office are almost too numerous to count. So for Senator Conroy to now have the gall to stand up here in this place and say that the Democrats have breached some agreement is an outrage and an absolute fabrication of the truth. Senator Conroy would happily have the Democrats and the ALP agree to something with which the government did not agree and proceed down that pathâhe would be very happy to do that. But to reach accommodation is apparently out of the question for the ALP and the opposition. I do not operate that way.

If there is a possibility on a committee such as this of us reaching agreement then I will seek to do that because I think that you have the best kind of cooperation in, and the best outcome from, committee inquiry processes if all parties are happy with what they are doing. In the case of setting up this committee, it seemed to me to be a very opportune thing to proceed down that path and to reach agreement. Down the track, once we have finished these inquiriesâthat is entirely up to the ALP and ourselves, and possibly it will not include the government; I do not know about thatâit is entirely up to the Senate to determine when we move to the next stage of the inquiry. I am happy with that; the Democrats have said all along that is what they are interested in. But it is a question of staging, of timing. This committee cannot take on board broad terms of reference that go into so many different areas. These three matters will occupy the time of the committee very substantially between now and then.

It is all very well for Senator Brown to stand up and say, `The committee should do it all,' but he does not have to be on these committees. He does not turn up to these committee hearings. He is not part of the process. I really think he should mind his own business because, quite frankly, these three matters that are before us today, that are part of these terms of reference, will occupy a great deal of the time of this committee. They are very substantial and do not need to be added to by the further broad terms of reference that Senator Conroy has proposed in the amendments he has moved. It is totally disingenuous for him to stand up and say we are now rejecting something which was agreed previously and that we are somehow caving in to what the government wants us to do.

I am really disappointed in this whole debate, Mr Acting Deputy President. I have proceeded on good faith. I have attempted to reach consensus and an accommodation with the parties involved. Clearly the ALP simply see this as an opportunity for them to stand up and bash the Democrats yet again. Senator Conroy brings into the debate the question of the GST. I ask him: what has that got to do with this particular debate? Again, this is nothing to do with the real matters: what is appropriate for this committee to deal with and what sort of staging we should adopt to get sensible reporting out of this committee when it has looked at very important issues. This is about the ALP again taking the opportunity to attack the Democrats. I for one am very disappointed because I worked with the previous superannuation committee and found it to be one whose members could cooperate across political parties. It was, in my view, a very effective committee. But clearly Senator Conroy does not want that in the future. He sees this as an opportunity for political point scoring. Quite frankly, I am disappointed with that. I have, as a result, some fairly low expectations of what this committee will be able to do if that is the attitude which prevails. If it is not, fineâwe will proceed to do some good work. But if Senator Conroy proceeds with this kind of political point scoring there is not much to be gained by that committee.
Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Conroy's ) be agreed to.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

interjection.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.

subdebateinfo.title: Environment, Communications, Information Technology and the Arts References Committee

subdebate.2.para: Motion (by Senator Bartlett)âby leaveânot agreed to:
That the following matters be referred to the Environment, Communications, Information Technology and the Arts References Committee for inquiry and report by 1 December 1999:
(a) an examination of fisheries in the Great Barrier Reef World Heritage Area, including:
(i) the impacts of fisheries on the world heritage values of the Great Barrier Reef,
(ii) an assessment of whether the fisheries in the reef are ecologically sustainable,
(iii) the reforms needed to ensure ecological sustainability in fishing practices and management,
(iv) state and federal fisheries management, policies and practices,
(v) an assessment of the adequacy of legislative framework regulating fisheries,
(vi) an identification of the various Commonwealth and state agencies with responsibility for managing fisheries in the reef,
(vii) an evaluation of the adequacy of management of fisheries by those agencies and whether they are discharging their responsibilities properly,
(viii) whether those agencies are properly resourced, and
(ix) the best way of achieving structural adjustment for fisheries in the reef;
(b) the adequacy of the areas of protection for biodiversity found in the World Heritage Area, with particular reference to:
(i) current zoning including green zones (`no take zones'),
(ii) the comprehensive, adequate and representative areas program,
(iii) whether those areas should be increased, and
(iv) the timeline for increasing those areas; and
(c) the potential impacts on the World Heritage Area and associated intertidal zones from all coastal oil shale mines, including:
(i) increased sediment pollution of sea grass and mangrove systems due to land clearing, construction and mining,
(ii) disturbance of acid sulphate soils,
(iii) disturbance of clay material in the marine environment,
(iv) offsite water and air pollution from the project sites,
(v) future increases in oil tanker traffic, including oil spills from accidents during transport and oil loading and transfer, and
(vi) the impact of open cut mining in the World Heritage Area and associated intertidal zones.

talk.start.para: âOn behalf of Senator Cooney, I present the 14th report of 1999 of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. I also lay on the table Scrutiny of Bills Alert Digest No. 14 of 1999, dated 22 September 1999.

speech.para: Ordered that the report be printed.

talk.start.para: âOn behalf of Senator Eggleston, I present additional information received by the Environment, Communications, Information Technology and the Arts Legislation Committee relating to the budget estimates hearings for 1999-2000.

âOn behalf of Senator Knowles, I present further additional information received by the Community Affairs Legislation Committee in response to its inquiry into the provisions of the National Health Amendment (Lifetime Health Cover) Bill 1999 .

âOn behalf of the Joint Committee on Public Works, I present the following reports: No. 6 of 1999âRAAF Base Townsville Redevelopment, Stage 1; and No. 7 of 1999âDarwin Naval Base Redevelopment. I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the reports.
I seek leave to incorporate my tabling statement in Hansard .
Leave granted.
The statement read as followsâ
Madam President, the reports which I have just tabled concern the proposals to redevelop RAAF Base Townsville and to upgrade existing facilities and construct new facilities at the Darwin Naval Base.
The estimated out turn cost of both proposals is $99.45 million.
The Public Works Committee has approved the redevelopment works.
The first report, the Committee's sixth of 1999, involves the Stage 1 redevelopment of RAAF Base, Townsville.
For this inquiry, the Committee held a public hearing into the proposal in Townsville on 16 June 1999 and received a number of written submissions.

RAAF Base Townsville is located approximately 5 kilometres west of the Townsville city centre, within the suburb of Garbutt. The Base is a joint user airfield, supporting both military and civil aircraft operations.

RAAF Base Townsville was developed during the Second World War and many of the existing facilities have been only slightly modified since this period. The Base forms part of a chain of military airfields across northern Australia to Learmonth in the west. It provides for the air defence of northern Queensland and its approaches. The Base's primary function is as a deployment base for combat aircraft during a contingency and as an air head for the 3rd Brigade's Ready Deployment Force.
The proposal examined by the Committee aims to provide new operational facilities and upgrade or replace current Base facilities, including:
. a purpose built Ordnance Loading Apron complex;
. a Quick Reaction Alert Facility;
. a dedicated Fighter/Strike Operational and Technical Support Facility;
. light tactical aircraft facilities;
. consolidated vehicle and battery maintenance facility; and
. replacement of existing perimeter road with a sealed all-weather surface.

An Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) for the redevelopment has been undertaken. The findings of the EIA have led to a determination that there will be no significant environmental impact resulting from the proposed Redevelopment Stage 1. Concurrent with the EIA process, substantial consultation was undertaken with special interest groups and environmental agencies to assist in determining the environmental issues associated with the proposed project. An Environmental Management Plan for the Stage 1 Redevelopment construction activities is to be developed and approved before construction commences.

The Committee is satisfied that the Department of Defence appears to have undertaken sufficient consultation with the relevant authorities and interest groups in the consideration of environmental and heritage issues associated with the redevelopment.

When referred to the Committee, the estimated cost of the project was $95 million. However, the approved budget figure is $87.05 million. Defence indicated to the Committee that attempts will be made to make some savings throughout the project, allowing funding of the full scope of the works outlined in the proposal. However, budgetary restraints may result in some lower priority elements of the project being moved to a subsequent stage.

para.inline: Redevelopment of Darwin Naval Base Project

speech.para: The second report I have just tabled, the Committee's seventh of 1999, relates to the redevelopment of Darwin Naval Base.

For this inquiry, the Committee inspected existing facilities and sites for the proposed works. The Committee also held a public hearing into the proposal in Darwin on 6 July 1999 and received a number of written submissions.

Darwin Naval Base is located within Larrakeyah Barracks two kilometres from the Darwin Central Business District and was constructed between 1980 and 1982 at a cost of $17.7 million. The Base provides support for vessels undertaking patrol activities, the Commander Northern Command, major fleet units, submarines and visiting warships from foreign navies exercising or operating in northern Australian waters.

The operational tempo in Australia's north has increased significantly over the past few years. Defence has advised the Committee that the proposed facilities are necessary to overcome existing occupational health and safety (OH&S) issues and operational deficiencies.
The proposal examined by the Committee involves the:
. construction of a new 146 metre wharf to accommodate up to nine patrol boats;
. improvement and extension of the existing wharf;
. realignment of the boat ramp to be parallel with the existing wharf;
. construction of three new hardstands;
. provision of an additional fuel storage and reconditioning facility;
. provision of an under cover naval stores receipt and dispatch area; and
. relocation of 36 Water Transport Troop to the main Base complex.

The proposal will relocate approximately 130 personnel and 120 dependents to Darwin, but the total number of Navy personnel will remain basically the same, due to the effects of the Defence Reform Program.

The development provides an opportunity for locally-based businesses to benefit through contracting, sub-contracting and the supply of goods and services. Increased expenditure in the Territory is expected through provisioning and maintenance contracts for the additional ships. It is anticipated that the redevelopment will result in greater opportunities for companies supporting patrol boat maintenance in Darwin.

The Committee is satisfied that the Department of Defence has adequately addressed environmental and heritage concerns. Defence has completed a flora, fauna and aquatic survey of the area and forwarded the resulting report to Environment Australia and the Northern Territory Department of Lands, Planning and Environment. Both authorities have agreed to the project proceeding. An issues identification study will also be used as a basis for detailed consultation. Factors to alleviate community concerns will be built into Defence's plans for the project, for example, relevant concerns will be incorporated into the project environmental management plans.

Concern was expressed by local residents that the works may result in an increase in the flow of traffic, particularly heavy vehicles on local roads. The Committee has recommended that in order to alleviate excessive traffic noise related to the operations of the Base, the Department of Defence should continue to consult with Darwin City Council and local residents. This should include consideration of existing guidelines governing the level of noise permitted from construction activities, particularly those carried out outside normal working hours and on weekends.

The Committee also heard safety concerns from local residents that the project may result in an increase in the transportation of weapons along residential roads. The Committee was satisfied that the movement of ordnance is not an environmental or safety risk due to the limited quantities transported, the nature of the ordnance being transported and Defence's compliance with transportation rules and regulations.
When referred to the Committee, the estimated cost of the project was $12.4 million.
Madam President, I commend the reports to the Senate.

talk.start.para: âAt question time today, Senator Newman was criticised by the opposition about the government's non-activity in defence matters and the fact that not enough money was being spent on defence. I think these two reports put the lie to that. These reports put forward two proposals amounting to almost $100 million. One of them is the RAAF Base Townsville. Part of the activity there and money being spent there is on the development of the Air Force base which, as everybody who is interested in the matter would know, particularly Senator Ian Macdonald, is an airhead for the 3rd Brigade's ready deployment force, which of course is in East Timor at the moment. It just shows that the government is supporting the 3rd Brigade. The other relates to the Darwin naval base redevelopment, as Senator Patterson would know, and approves facilities to enable more patrol boats to be stationed in Darwin to carry out patrol work to avert the further incursion of illegal immigrants and others into Australia.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âI seek leave to incorporate a ministerial statement on Australia's readiness for the year 2000 in Hansard , together with a background information paper, and to make a brief statement.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: âThe only thing I wanted to add to this ministerial statement, under the heading of `government leadership', is an acknowledgment of the efforts of Senator Ian Campbell, the parliamentary secretary with particular responsibility for year 2000 issues. Senator Ian Campbell has been assiduous in speaking to all elements of industry and government with a particular interest in this matter. It is often a difficult and technical task, and it is one that he has conquered and pursued with great enthusiasm. I am particularly indebted to him for that.

speech.para: From the growing amount of information available, Australia is extremely well prepared to deal with the Year 2000 date change.

The Year 2000 issue has a simple cause. Until recently, there was a need to use as little computer memory as possible because of its very high price, and so dates were stored without reference to the century. The solution is far more complex.
But what began as a computer problem has become a national opportunity.
In the process of fixing the bug, we have created better systems and stronger networks, building a solid foundation for the 21st century.

The Government is confident that the community will be able to enjoy the holiday season and New Year's Eve celebrations, and that industry can look ahead to a new year full of expanding business opportunities.
Today, I will outline Australia's preparations and provide a national picture of our Year 2000 readiness.
Since 1996 the Commonwealth Government has:
. provided leadership in preparing and reporting on its own systems;
. monitored preparations in sectors it's responsible forâin particular banking and finance, aviation and communications;
. helped raise awareness in industry through the Year 2000 National Steering Committee;
. provided legislative and taxation support for business efforts; and
. informed the wider community of the preparedness of key sectors.

The Commonwealth Government has been actively monitoring progress towards Year 2000 compliance of over 3 500 business critical systems across 124 Departments and agencies, and has released results publicly since December 1998. The level of detail in these reports places Australia at the forefront of public reporting by governments around the world.

I am pleased to announce that according to the most recent public report released today, as at August this year, 97 per cent of the business-critical systems identified in Commonwealth agencies had been fixed. All the available evidence suggests that the community can have confidence that key Commonwealth Government services will be able to be delivered seamlessly into the year 2000.

The Government will now receive monthly reports on the small number of outstanding systems until all work is complete. Less than 1 per cent of systems (or 21 systems) are likely to be non-compliant by the end of this month. The majority do not have a role in the delivery of key services. Half of them relate to building systems.

The Government also monitors the progress of 51 government business entities (GBEs). These include Telstra, Australia Post and the Sydney Airport Corporation. At August 1999, Commonwealth GBEs reported they had achieved average compliance levels of 93 per cent. Full compliance for all GBEs is scheduled for end October 1999.

The Commonwealth Government's remediation work is substantially complete. Agencies are required to develop contingency plans aimed at delivering services as usual in the event of any unforseen problemsâwhether Year 2000-related or not. This latest report shows 78 per cent of contingency planning is now complete.

The Commonwealth Government is responsible for the delivery, or regulating the delivery, of three key national infrastructure sectorsâbanking and finance, aviation and communications. Since April 1999 we have reported publicly on preparedness in these critical sectors.

The Australian banking and financial sector is well prepared for the Year 2000 and is internationally recognised as exhibiting world's best practice. Australia's banks and other financial institutions have completed the vast majority of remediation and testing of all critical systems. This should ensure that it will be `business as usual' in the financial sector.

Institutions are also finalising their contingency plans to deal with unexpected problems or prob lems outside of their control. The Australian Prudential Regulation Authority (APRA) is continuing to closely monitor the Year 2000 preparations of financial institutions.

A comprehensive program to test the Year 2000 readiness of the Australian payments system was successfully completed by 30 June 1999. No Year 2000 problems were reported by test participants and payments mechanisms, such as ATMs, EFTPOS and credit cards, are Year 2000 ready. Contingency plans for the payments system are also nearing completion.

The public can be reassured that their deposits are safe and that their records are not at risk from Year 2000 related problems. There is no need for people to withdraw more money over the New Year period than they normally would for a long weekend. However, the Reserve Bank has built up ample stocks of currency notes to meet any extra demand should it occur.

Since July 1998 the Department of Transport and Regional Services has chaired a Year 2000 Aviation Committee of government, industry and consumer representatives which meets monthly to monitor and report to Government on the preparedness of the various players in the aviation industry.

Airservices Australia is confident there will be no disruption to the services it provides the aviation industry as a result of the impact of the millennium bug on its own systems. To the extent Airservices relies on others, it has determined they are compliant or where appropriate has developed extensive contingency plans.

The Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) has called on all licensed air operators, aviation maintenance organisations and licensed aerodromes to provide information on their Year 2000 readiness and contingency planning by 30 September 1999. CASA has sent a comprehensive Operator's Guide to Year 2000 Readiness and Contingency Planning to all licence holders.
Major Australian airports have advised they are progressing well towards full compliance and have programs in place to ensure business continuity during the year 2000 period.

Qantas and Ansett, their subsidiaries and regional partners, have been working on the Year 2000 problem for a number of years. The manufacturers of aircraft used by Qantas and Ansett (Boeing, Airbus Industrie and Bombardier) have advised that there are no safety or airworthiness issues relating to the Year 2000 compliance of their aircraft.

The International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) has developed contingency plans which will be used to manage air services during the transition period. AirServices Australia was actively involved in the development of the plan for the Asia Pacific region.
Given our dependence on telecommunications, it's imperative this sector be fully prepared for the Year 2000.

In recent reporting to Government, the four major carriers (Telstra, Cable and Wireless Optus, Vodafone and AAPT) have indicated that preparations are well advanced. More than 90 percent of remediation work on critical network and IT systems has been completed by these carriers, with full remediation of critical systems scheduled for October 1999 or earlier. Their current focus is on contingency planning. In general, the smaller carriers and carriage service providers report that they are also well advanced in their Year 2000 preparations.
The Government, through the Australian Communications Authority (ACA), will be continuing to monitor further developments closely.

In August 1999 the industry body, the Australian Communications Industry Forum (ACIF) reported that telecommunications carriers and service providers had successfully completed a range of cross-network service continuity tests for the Year 2000. Successful call connections were made across different carrier networks and between different services such as fixed-line and mobile.

The tests confirmed that dates do not pass between networks, which greatly limits potential for any Year 2000 impacts that one particular operator experiences to be passed on from that network to another.
The major Australian carriers are also testing interconnectivity with international carriers through the International Telecommunication Union and other carrier-specific international relationships.
Following a program of evaluation and testing, Telstra reports that it expects its 000 emergency service to operate without the Year 2000 date change having any impact on its functionality.
Reports from the industry regulator, the Australian Broadcasting Authority (ABA), indicate that licensees are generally well advanced in their Year 2000 preparations.

The Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) reported that 97 per cent of its business critical systems were compliant at the beginning of August, with the one outstanding item expected to be compliant by the end of September 1999. The Special Broadcasting Service Corporation (SBS) reported 84 per cent compliance, with the remaining 16 per cent awaiting compliance certificates.
Surveys conducted prior to the recent sale of the national transmission network found no critical Year 2000 compliance issues within network equipment or systems.

One key national forum for addressing the Year 2000 issue is the Year 2000 National Steering Committee (NSC). The Government established the NSC in 1997 under the chairmanship of Mr Maurice Newman AM, with funding of nearly $10 million. The NSC comprises members of Commonwealth and State and Territory Governments, Local Government and industry associations.

Major NSC initiatives include national television, radio and print advertising campaigns, a national telephone hotline (1800 11 2000) seminars and workshops, and a round of national infrastructure forums.
The forums provided a platform for businesses to brief each other and the community on their Year 2000 readiness.
The very high levels of awareness of the Year 2000 issue demonstrated in surveys of Australian business significantly reflect the outstanding efforts of Mr Newman and his committee.

The Australian Stock Exchange (ASX) has used its role effectively in encouraging the remediation efforts of our major companies. The ASX has twice now requested its 1 200 listed companiesâprimarily larger organisationsâto provide detailed reports about their Year 2000 readiness and compliance efforts. The third and final disclosure date is 30 September 1999.
The ASX, itself a listed company, has released comprehensive reports in relation to its own preparations to demonstrate best practice.

In a further initiative to assess the level of readiness of the finance industry, the ASX coordinated a Year 2000 Equities Industry Test during April 1999. The 15 day test involved 10 brokers, five institutions, six banks, Australia's largest share registry processor and the ASX. Testing involved trading and settling equity transactions around key dates. The ASX has announced that no date related problems were found.
To determine the levels of Year 2000 preparedness of Australian business, the NSC has commissioned nation-wide surveys of Australian business by the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS).

Preliminary results of the latest survey confirm that by June 1999, Australian business had made considerable progress in dealing with the Year 2000 issue. A total of 35 per cent of businesses surveyed reported that they had completed their preparations. Encouragingly, virtually all businesses which haven't already completed their Year 2000 work report they expect to achieve completion by December 1999.

While 44 percent of businesses do not intend to undertake Year 2000 work, the overwhelming majority of these businesses are very small and report that they are not significantly dependent on technology.

All States and Territories are collecting information about government Year 2000 readiness and contingency planning, using reporting frameworks tailored to each jurisdiction's requirements. All have released this information publicly. Based on the most recent information available, State and Territory Governments are typically more than 80 per cent ready, and most are more that 90 per cent.
Contingency planning is also well advancedâthe State and Territory averages range from 52 to 97 per cent, with half being above 80 per cent.
Australia's Federal system poses particular challenges for ensuring a coordinated national response to the Year 2000 problem.
The States and Territories have responsibility for a range of services including the key utilitiesâelectricity, gas and waterâand local services such as public transport systems and hospitals.
Reporting by States and Territories together with reports by private utilities and infrastructure providers, combine to provide the following picture on local key services and utilities.

Statements from State and Territory Governments, the National Electricity Market Management Company (NEMMCO) and the Electricity Supply Association of Australia (ESAA) indicate that the industry as a whole has nearly completed analysis, assessment, and testing of business critical systems, and is well advanced in contingency planning. The industry advises that extensive testing to date has not revealed any problems associated with the Year 2000 that would affect current supply reliability. Remediation activities have reached the 90 per cent mark and are scheduled for completion by September 1999.

Contingency planning in the electricity industry is normal practice. The industry already has extensive contingency plans to deal with disruptions to electricity supply that can occur at any time through events such as storms, unplanned outages at power stations and damage to power poles and lines. State and Territory Governments reports indicate that contingency plans are increasingly in place and complete in some jurisdictions.

State and Territory Government Year 2000 reports indicate that the Year 2000 readiness of water supply across the majority of States and Territories is above 90 per cent, and contingency plans range from 75 to 100 per cent complete. Information on the readiness of water supply in some areas of Queensland is not yet complete. Some jurisdictionsâfor example Victoria, Tasmania and the ACTâreport a heavy reliance on gravity-fed water systems that make little or no use of date dependent technology.
Water suppliers report that they are developing additional contingency plans to cope with any unexpected problems arising from the Year 2000 issue.
In Australia gas is supplied primarily by the private sector.
Based on current information available from the gas industry, the sector is confident gas will continue to flow on and after 1 January 2000.

State and Territory Government Year 2000 reporting on road transport covers road infrastructure, including signalling and traffic management systems. Where reported, readiness levels are generally above 90 per cent.

The rail transport sector is predominantly State and Territory Government controlled and Year 2000 progress is reflected in their public reports. Year 2000 readiness levels of rail transport reported by States and Territories tend to be 90 per cent or above. The reported level of contingency planning is variable.

Australia's major port facilities are owned and operated by State and Territory Governments. Many are reporting levels of Year 2000 readiness above 90 per cent, and some at 100 per cent. The Commonwealth Government's Australian Maritime Safety Authority (AMSA) has embraced the International Maritime Organisation's (IMO) Code of Good Practice on the Year 2000, aimed at producing a safe environment for normal business in ports and navigation during 2000.

From 1 July 1999 AMSA surveyors stepped up their program of checking that ships have addressed the Year 2000 issue in accordance with the Code. Ships entering Australian ports are required to demonstrate Year 2000 compliance or readiness and a satisfactory management strategy.

The Australian Institute of Petroleum (AIP) formed a joint Year 2000 Committee with the Australian Petroleum Production and Exploration Association (APPEA) in 1997 to assist member companies on the Year 2000 issue. The committee is discussing contingency plans with the emergency services authorities in States and Territories.

The Australian petroleum industry has examined its systems and, where necessary, remediated and tested them. The industry is reporting that remediation activity is almost complete. Supply chains have been checked. Business continuity plans are being finalised. Contingency plans are a normal part of business in the fuel industry for safety purposesâfuel is a volatile product and the safety of the public and workforce is of paramount importance.
The industry is ensuring all parts of the supply chain are prepared and is confident there is at least two weeks of stock within the system.

The Australian health and aged care sector includes the public hospital system, private hospitals, community health services, aged care facilities, doctors' surgeries, medical services such as X-rays and pathology and blood services.

The Commonwealth Government and each State and Territory have been checking equipment and systems likely to be affected by the Year 2000 problem. Equipment and systems identified as having a problem are either being repaired or replaced and contingency plans developed to ensure services can be provided if unexpected incidents occur.

The Commonwealth Government, in partnership with general practitioners through the profession's peak national body for computing, the General Practice Computing Group, has developed a guide to assist individual general practitioners address Year 2000 issues.
The Commonwealth and the States and Territories have provided information to the nursing home and hostel sectors on preparing for the Year 2000.

Hospitals and other health care facilities are putting in place plans to allow them to switch from normal operations to contingency mode with minimal disruption to the care provided to patients in the event of a Year 2000 issue arising.

Reporting on the Year 2000 readiness of medical devices has been required by the Therapeutic Goods Administration, and the State and Territory Health Departments have been undertaking and/or advocating the thorough testing of medical equipment.

Pharmaceutical manufacturers and wholesalers have indicated that they have undertaken thorough Year 2000 compliance reviews underpinned by appropriate testing and remediation programs, and are planning to operate normally throughout the Christmas/New Year period.
The key service supplied by some local governments is water and sewerage services where, as noted already, good progress is being made.
The State and Territory Governments have the primary role of managing Local Government within their jurisdictions.

New South Wales, Victoria and Tasmania report on the Year 2000 preparedness of Local Government as part of their government reporting framework. Year 2000 progress is variedâalthough in all three jurisdictions there are increasing numbers of Local Governments reporting 100 per cent Year 2000 readiness and high levels of completed contingency plans.

The Commonwealth Government will distribute information to ensure that Australians are kept informed of the progress being made on Year 2000 work. State and Territory Governments are providing the community with complementary local information.

The Commonwealth Government is about to distribute information for the community on Australia's Year 2000 preparations through a series of press ads outlining Australia's preparedness and providing a comprehensive community booklet (via a telephone hotline); radio messages about preparations in key service areas; and a Commonwealth Government Year 2000 website (www.year2000.gov.au).

Commonwealth, State and Territory Governments are working together in preparing to monitor and manage any consequences in the unlikely event of a Year 2000 failure over New Year's Eve and the following period.

A network of Year 2000 National Coordination Centres (NCCs) is being established in each capital city including Canberra, to monitor events regionally and nationally. The Commonwealth NCC will build on existing Emergency Management Australia (EMA) facilities.

NCCs will be monitoring event management activities within their own jurisdictions, will coordinate assistance if required and provide high level policy advice to governments. In addition, the centres will collect and consolidate key information to provide a State and Territory and national picture for Australian and international audiences.

The Commonwealth centre will have responsibility for monitoring and providing a national picture. It will also participate in a UN-sponsored exercise to deliver early advice to other countries on Australia's progress through the date rollover.
All centres will keep the community informed by issuing regular updates to the media.
The Australian Government continues to attach a high priority to ensuring it meets the significant challenges posed by the international dimensions of the Year 2000 issue.

The Australian Government is working with other governments and Australian industry on coordinated approaches to these challenges, including through APEC, the United Nations and its International Y2K Cooperation Centre, the Year 2000 National Steering Committee, and other relevant international organisations.
Australian industry, often in conjunction with government, has been particularly active in cooperation in international aviation, telecommunications and banking and finance.

Through the aid program, Australia is providing substantial technical assistance to Papua New Guinea and other South Pacific countries to help them prepare for the Year 2000 transition. Australia has also provided some assistance in Asia in key areas such as aviation and telecommunications.
The Government has been monitoring Year 2000 preparations overseas, and working closely with other governments on information sharing and risk reduction strategies, including contingency planning.

A roundtable meeting was held this month with a group of Australian manufacturing and services exporters and importers to share information on preparing for the Year 2000. The roundtable provided the Government with valuable, additional perspectives concerning the nature of any international Year 2000 effects on business and the implications for Australia.

The Government has an ongoing duty of care to inform the travelling public where the potential exists for Australians to experience difficultiesâparticularly where personal safely, health considerations or other restrictions are of concern.

From early 1999 the Government has been providing information to the Australian community on the international dimensions of the Year 2000 issue, particularly through the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade website and through regular consular travel advisories.
The Government proposes to continue to closely monitor international Year 2000 preparations throughout 1999 and into the year 2000 and to make any necessary amendments to our public advice.
Madam President

As the countdown to the end of the year rapidly approaches, this last quarter of 1999 marks the critical stage in Australia's Year 2000 preparations. The cooperation and hard work on Year 2000 issues across the country means we can expect to have good reason to celebrate when the clock ticks over on midnight 31st December 1999.

No single government or sector is responsible for the Year 2000 issue. The solution is a shared one. And because all sectors have responded to the challenge, Australia is extremely well placed for the transition to the Year 2000. Governments and industry have worked together to ensure that key services are ready. Publicly available information on these preparations suggests strongly that we can expect business as usual for essential infrastructure such as electric power, telecommunications, banking and transportâwith little or no disruptions.

All the evidence suggests that Australia is one of the best-prepared countries in the world. Indeed, just last week the BBC, reporting on advice from the British Foreign Office, said that `Australia is thought to be the best place to beat the millennium bugIt was one of the first to take the bug seriously and as a result it's better prepared than almost anyone.'

The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts delivered a statement to Parliament on 22 September 1999, outlining Australia's preparations for the Year 2000 issue. This document provides further detail and should be read in conjunction with the statement.

The Commonwealth Government of Australia recognised early that the implications of the Year 2000 issue for Australians, and for the economy generally, were potentially significant. Since 1996 the Commonwealth has:
. provided leadership in preparing and reporting on the Government's own systems for the Year 2000;
. through its various regulatory bodies, overseen the Year 2000 preparations in the sectors for which it is responsible, in particular banking and finance, aviation and communications;
. raised awareness of the need for business to be prepared, with a particular focus on small-to-medium sized enterprises;
. provided appropriate legislative and taxation support for business efforts; and
. informed the wider community of the state of preparedness of key sectors.
Similarly, the State and Territory Governments have:
. remediated and reported on their own systems in preparation for the Year 2000 issue;

. overseen the preparations of key infrastructure and services for which they are responsibleâsuch as the energy, transport, health, water and sewerage, and emergency services sectors, including through cooperative arrangements with the private sector;
