. worked with the Commonwealth to raise industry awareness of the Year 2000 issue;
. supported the Commonwealth by passing complementary information disclosure legislation where necessary; and
. complemented national awareness messages for the community with local information.
In relation to listed Australian companies, the Australian Stock Exchange (ASX) has required a series of disclosures regarding Year 2000 preparedness.

In addition to these formal frameworks for awareness raising, cooperation and reporting, a stocktake commissioned by governments of national activities to address Year 2000 issues found that a range of supplementary informal mechanisms exist in addition to formal monitoring. These include:
. functional area forums set up by State governments for sectors such as health and emergency services, promoting information exchange in areas of common interest;
. industry working groups to ensure that key areas of common interest are addressed effectively, such as the Interbank Working Group (IWG) and the Aviation Year 2000 Committee;
. issue-driven working groups, for example health sector groups addressing business continuity planning and prescription drug logistics management; and
. bilateral contacts such as those between the major food retailers and their suppliers, or transport and logistic companies and the owner drivers who work for them.

In addition, the stocktake identified widespread use of the Internet, public and private seminars and conferences, published material, information packs and helplines to raise awareness of Year 2000 issues and how they are being addressed. A copy of the stocktake, undertaken by Admiral Management Services, can be found at www.year2000.gov.au.

A key national forum for addressing the Year 2000 issue is the Year 2000 National Steering Committee (NSC). The Government established the NSC in 1997 under the chairmanship of Mr Maurice Newman AM, with funding of nearly $10 million. The NSC comprises members of Commonwealth, State and Territory Governments, and local government and industry associations, and was charged with developing and implementing a national awareness raising strategy to encourage business and industry to prepare for the Year 2000. The NSC has targeted its messages particularly at small and medium enterprises.

Major NSC initiatives include national television, radio and print advertising campaigns, a national telephone hotline (1800 11 2000), seminars and workshops, and a round of national infrastructure forums. The forums focused on providing a platform for business to brief industry and the community on their Year 2000 readiness, and to engender a spirit of cooperation. The very high levels of awareness of the Year 2000 issue demonstrated in surveys of Australian business must significantly reflect the outstanding efforts of Mr Newman and his committee.
The level of detail of reporting on public sector Year 2000 progress in Australia has placed this country at the forefront of public reporting by governments around the world.

Commonwealth, State and Territory Governments are all working towards the common goal of maintaining business as usual for the delivery of key services in 2000, and all are developing contingency plans to cope with any unexpected problems that may arise. Each jurisdiction has developed an approach to addressing and reporting on Year 2000 progress that best serves its particular circumstances and requirements.

Governments around Australia are also working cooperatively. Commonwealth, State and Territory Ministers responsible for Year 2000 issues have met on a number of occasions to exchange information and to support the development of a national approach to Year 2000 issues. Year 2000 Project Directors from Commonwealth, State and Territory Governments meet more regularly to support this process.

Australian governments are now entering the final phases of their Year 2000 projects and are on target to have them completed ahead of the critical date change period. This means that the Commonwealth, States and Territories are well on track to deliver services normally on and beyond 1 January 2000.

The Commonwealth Government has been actively monitoring the progress towards Year 2000 compliance of over 3 500 business critical systems across 124 budget dependant Departments and agencies. Agencies include, for example, Centrelink, the Australian Taxation Office and the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.

The Government has compiled quarterly reports on the Year 2000 readiness of portfolios since 1997, and released results publicly since December 1998. Public reports are now being issued at agency level, placing the Commonwealth at the forefront of public sector reporting.

The most recent Commonwealth report released today (22 September 1999) reveals that as at August this year, 97 per cent of the business-critical systems identified in Commonwealth agencies are now fixed. This means they are either fully compliant, or have been remediated and brought back into service, awaiting the executive sign-off necessary to achieve full compliance. All the available evidence suggests that the community can have confidence that key Commonwealth Government services will be able to be delivered seamlessly into the year 2000.
The Government will now receive monthly reports on the small number of outstanding systems across all agencies until all work is complete.

The Government also monitors the progress of 51 government business entities (GBEs). These include Telstra, Australia Post and the Sydney Airport Corporation. As at August 1999, Commonwealth GBEs report that they have achieved average compliance levels of 93 per cent. Full compliance for all GBEs is scheduled for end October 1999.

The Commonwealth Government's remediation work is substantially complete. However, like any other organisations, Government agencies are dependent on supply chains, distribution systems and basic infrastructure such as electricity and telecommunications to operate normally. Even though no major disruptions to key national infrastructure services are expected, agencies are required to develop contingency plans aimed at delivering services as usual in the event of any unforseen problemsâwhether they be Year 2000 related or not. The most recent quarterly report also shows 78 per cent of contingency planning is complete, and the report is available online at http://www.year2000.gov.au or by calling 02 6271 1252.

The Commonwealth Government is responsible either for the delivery, or for regulating the delivery, of three key national infrastructure sectorsâbanking and finance, aviation and communications. Since April 1999 the Commonwealth Government has reported publicly on the preparedness of these three critical sectors in an effort to provide Australians with as much detail as possible about Year 2000 progress.
It has encouraged other governments and industry to follow the Commonwealth lead and make public statements on those key services and products for whose delivery they are responsible.

The Australian banking and financial sector is well advanced in its Year 2000 preparations and is internationally recognised as exhibiting world's best practice. Australia's financial institutions have devoted substantial effort and resources to testing and remediation and, as such, have virtually completed the remediation and testing of critical systems.

The vast majority of banks have completed the remediation and testing of all critical systems. In those exceptional cases where testing is yet to be completed, the industry regulator, the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority (APRA) is satisfied that there are adequate fallback arrangements in place to ensure that it will be business as usual.

Banks have almost completed their contingency plans to deal with unexpected problems or problems outside their control. Similarly, other financial institutions (namely, building societies, credit unions, life and general insurance companies, superannuation funds and friendly societies) have also completed the vast majority of remediation and testing of critical systems, and are now well into the contingency planning phase.
A comprehensive program to test the Year 2000 readiness of the Australian payments system was successfully completed, on time, by 30 June 1999. No Year 2000 issues were reported by test participants.

APRA is continuing to closely monitor the Year 2000 preparations of financial institutions. It is now focusing its attention on the development and implementation of contingency plans by regulated entities. Planning is now well underway, with contingency plans for all clearing arrangements scheduled to be ready by end-September 1999.
The public can be assured that electronic payments mechanisms, such as ATMs, EFTPOS and credit cards, are already, and will continue to be, Year 2000 ready.

The public can also be assured that their deposits are safe and that their records are not at risk from Year 2000 related issues. As such, there is no need for people to withdraw more money over the New Year period than they normally would for a long weekend.

However, if they wish to do so, the Reserve Bank has built up ample stocks of currency notes to meet that demand. The Governor of the Reserve Bank attested to this in his statements to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Economics, Finance and Public Administration in June 1999.

Australia has two principal air transport operatorsâQantas, a publicly listed company, and Ansett Australia, a private company. Both operate international and domestic flights and have regional airline subsidiaries or affiliate partnerships. Major airports in Australia are owned by the private sector, with the exception of airports in the Sydney Basin, which remain in Commonwealth ownership. The Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) is the statutory authority responsible for aviation safety. Airservices Australia (ASA), a Government-owned commercial authority, is responsible for air traffic management.

Since July 1998 the Department of Transport and Regional Services (DoTRS) has chaired a Year 2000 Aviation Committee which meets monthly to monitor and report to Government on the preparedness of the various sectors in the aviation industry. The Committee consists of representatives from the Commonwealth Government, the aviation industry and consumers of aviation services and reports on a regular basis to the Minister for Transport and Regional Services.

ASA has been working since 1996 to ensure its services are maintained normally during the Year 2000 transition. ASA has advised that the majority of its internal systems are Year 2000 ready. ASA is confident that there will be no disruption to the services it provides to the aviation industry as a result of the impact of the Year 2000 issues on its own systems. To the extent that ASA relies on others, it has determined they are compliant and, where appropriate, has developed extensive contingency plans.

The Department of Defence is undertaking a comprehensive remediation program to ensure that all relevant military aviation systems are Year 2000 compliant before 1 January 2000. Already 100 per cent of critical systems and airfield technical equipment are certified as Year 2000 compliant.

CASA has called on all licensed air operators, aviation maintenance organisations and licensed aerodromes to provide it with information on their Year 2000 readiness and contingency planning by 30 September 1999. To assist this, CASA has sent a comprehensive Operator's Guide to Y2K Readiness and Contingency Planning to all licence holders.

Major Australian airports have advised that they are progressing well towards full compliance and have programs in place to ensure business continuity during the Year 2000 period. As part of its Year 2000 Project, the International Air Transport Association (IATA) has conducted site visits to 70 major international airports worldwide, including Brisbane, Melbourne and Sydney.

The Australian Airports Association has been working closely with other airport operators, particularly those in regional Australia, to ensure they are aware of Year 2000 issues, and to provide advice and guidance on compliance issues.
Qantas and Ansett, and their subsidiaries and country regional alliance partners, have been working on the Year 2000 issue for a number of years.

The airlines are significant contributors to industry initiatives on addressing the millennium bug. The manufacturers of aircraft used by Qantas and Ansett (Boeing, Airbus Industrie and Bombardier) have advised the industry there are no safety or airworthiness issues relating to the Year 2000 compliance of their aircraft.

Through its membership of the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) and APEC, its contacts with other countries on a bilateral basis, and international assistance projects, Australia has taken a leading role internationally in raising awareness of the Year 2000 issue and its implications for aviation. ICAO has developed regional contingency plans, and the Asia Pacific regional contingency plan, which will be used to manage air services during the transition period, was approved by the ICAO President in August 1999. Airservices Australia had an active involvement in the development and finalisation of this plan.
Given the dependence of contemporary society on telecommunications it is imperative that this sector is Year 2000 ready.

The Australian telecommunications industry includes around 50 major service providers, including some 30 carriers, and around 800 Internet service providers. Together they use wire, cable, radio and information technologies to provide a vast range and number of telecommunications services from simple telephony to sophisticated broadband services.

The industry regulator, the Australian Communications Authority (ACA), has a significant role in relation to technical regulation and consumer protection. Together with the industry body the Australian Communications Industry Forum (ACIF), both have played a key role in coordinating Year 2000 preparations in an industry highly dependent on network linkages.

In recent reporting to Government, the four major carriers (Telstra, Cable and Wireless Optus, Vodafone and AAPT) have indicated that their Year 2000 preparations are well advanced. More than 90 percent of remediation work on critical network and IT systems has been completed by these carriers, with full remediation of critical systems scheduled for October or earlier. Their current focus is now on contingency planning. The four major carriers anticipate that by the end of June 2000 their expenditure on Year 2000 preparations and remediation will be in the vicinity of $540 million.

In general, the smaller carriers and carriage service providers report that they are also well advanced in their Year 2000 preparations. Many are advantaged by their comparatively recent entry into the market. Their equipment is already compliant, and they also rely on the services of the major carriers.
The Government, through the ACA, will be continuing to monitor further developments closely.

In August 1999, ACIF reported that telecommunications carriers and service providers had successfully completed a range of cross-network service continuity tests for the Year 2000. The three-month test program involved a range of carriers and various call types. Successful call connections were made across different carrier networks from fixed-line services to mobile services, fixed-line services to fixed-line services, mobile services to mobile services, and mobile services to fixed-line services. The tests confirmed that dates do not pass between networks, which greatly limits potential for Year 2000 impacts in the highly interdependent cross networks. With the cross-network testing program complete, ACIF is increasing its focus on intercarrier and industry contingency planning activities.

The major Australian carriers are conducting interconnectivity testing with international carriers through the International Telecommunication Union (ITU) and other carrier specific international relationships.
Telstra is playing a key leadership role in supporting the regional Year 2000 initiatives of the ITU.

Telstra has reported that it completed its program of evaluation and testing of individual elements of the 000 emergency service in 1998. Telstra has indicated that it expects its 000 emergency service to operate (before, during and after 31/12/99) without negative impact on its functionality from the date change to the Year 2000. Operation of emergency services depends upon the effective workings of the network and functioning interconnectivity between carriers. ACIF has been working methodically for a number of months on this area, including testing, and on contingency planning.

The Australian broadcasting system is made up of two national radio and television broadcasters and some 247 commercial radio broadcasters, of whom 240â245 are currently broadcasting. There are also about 320 community radio broadcasters, which includes those broadcasting to remote aboriginal communities. There are 54 television broadcasters, comprising 48 commercial, 3 principal subscription and three community broadcasters. Reports from the industry regulator, the Australian Broadcasting Authority (ABA), indicate that licensees are generally well advanced in their Year 2000 preparations. Responses from commercial licensees were better than those from community licensees.

The Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) has reported that 97 per cent of its business critical systems were compliant at the beginning of August 1999, with the main outstanding system expected to be compliant by the end of September 1999. Special Broadcasting Service Corporation (SBS) reported 84 per cent compliance, with the remaining 16 per cent awaiting compliance certificates.
Surveys conducted prior to the recent sale of the national transmission network found no critical Year 2000 compliance issues within network equipment or systems.

The Australian Stock Exchange (ASX) has used its role effectively to encourage the remediation efforts of our major companies. The ASX has twice now requested its 1200 listed companiesâprimarily larger organisationsâto provide detailed reports about their Year 2000 readiness and compliance efforts. The first disclosure was due by 30 June 1998 and the second by 31 March 1999. The ASX is requiring a third and final disclosure by 30 September 1999.
The ASX, itself a listed company, has released comprehensive reports in relation to its own preparations as a means of demonstrating best practice.

In a further initiative to assess the level of readiness of the finance industry, the ASX coordinated a Year 2000 Equities Industry Test during April 1999. The 15 working days test involved 10 brokers, five institutions, six banks, Australia's largest share registry processor and the ASX. Testing involved trading and settling equity transactions around key dates. The ASX has announced that no date related problems were found.

To determine the levels of Year 2000 preparedness more generally among Australian business, the NSC has commissioned the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) to undertake nation-wide surveys of Australian business.
The first survey of some 8 000 businesses conducted in October 1998 found that levels of awareness of the problem were already extremely high at 92 per cent.

In June 1999 the ABS repeated the survey, this time involving over 13 000 businesses, of which 74 per cent responded. Preliminary survey results released on 31 August 1999 confirm that Australian business has made considerable progress in dealing with the Year 2000 issue. 35 per cent of businesses surveyed report that they had completed their preparations. Encouragingly, virtually all businesses who haven't already completed their Year 2000 work report that they expect to be completed by December 1999.

The survey reinforced the electricity, gas and water supply sectors as those where the highest proportion of businesses were undertaking, or had completed, Year 2000 work. The finance and insurance industry reported the highest rate of completion of Year 2000 work and testing.

The proportion of businesses not intending to undertake work has remained constant at around 40 per cent. Nearly 80 per cent of these are micro businesses with less than 20 employees, and low levels of technology dependence. They are found across all industry sectors. The majority of businesses not intending to undertake any Year 2000 work reported that they either don't have any technology that will be affected, or they don't believe their businesses will be affected. The proportion and general characteristics of business not undertaking Year 2000 work in Australia is broadly consistent with experiences in the US and other well prepared countries.
The survey suggested, however, that there is no room for complacency, with many businesses identifying the need to complete contingency planning in the remaining months ahead.

Based on the latest data, the ABS has revised downwards its estimate of the costs to Australian business of addressing the Year 2000 issue to around $10 billion. When public sector remediation costs are added, total estimated expenditure in Australia on Year 2000 is around $12 billion.

As more information becomes available on the preparedness of individual organisations, business and governments will be better placed to make informed decisions about the level of contingency planning required. This may further reduce the total cost estimate of Year 2000 expenditure in Australia.

In providing support for businesses efforts, the Government announced in the May 1998 Budget that most Year 2000 software expenditure incurred up to 31 December 1999 would be immediately deductible for taxation purposes. This includes initial diagnosis, software modification and upgrades, and remediation and testing.

If organisations are to target their contingency planning effectively, they require an understanding of the preparedness of their customers, suppliers and utilities. The Year 2000 Information Disclosure Act1999 (the "Good Samaritan" legislation) was enacted by the Federal Parliament in February 1999. The legislation is designed to encourage public disclosure and sharing of information on the state of Year 2000 preparations between organisations. Complementary legislation has been passed by the States and the Northern Territory to provide national coverage (the Australian Capital Territory is covered by the Commonwealth Act).

The States and Territories commenced public reporting on Year 2000 preparedness earlier this year, following an agreement by Commonwealth, State and Territory Year 2000 Ministers in December 1998. All States and Territories are collecting information about government Year 2000 readiness and contingency planning using reporting frameworks tailored to suit jurisdictional requirements. They release this information publicly. All States and Territories have Year 2000 websites containing the public reports, general Year 2000 information and contact details for obtaining additional information.
Based on the most recent information available, States and Territory Governments are typically more than 80 per cent ready, and most are more than 90 per cent ready.
Contingency planning is also well advancedâthe State and Territory averages range from 52 to 97 per cent, with half being above 80 per cent.

Australia's Federal system of Government poses particular challenges in ensuring a coordinated national response to the Year 2000 problem. While sectors such as banking and telecommunications are the province of the Commonwealth Government, the States and Territories have responsibility for a range of other services including the key utilitiesâelectricity, gas and waterâand local services such as public transport systems and hospitals.

As well as reporting publicly on the progress of their own government agencies, State and Territory Year 2000 Ministers have undertaken to report on key services under their responsibility, including electricity, water and gas. Local Government was added in April 1999.
The reporting by States and Territory Governments together with that of private utility and infrastructure providers combine to provide the following picture on local key services and utilities.

A reliable supply of electricity is fundamental to the maintenance of normal business and community services. The electricity industry in Australia is organised according to four regions: Tasmania; Western Australia; Northern Territory; and the National Electricity Market, which supplies the Eastern Seaboard (covering all other States/Territories). Single, vertically integrated companies supply both Western Australia and the Northern Territory. In Tasmania the industry is divided into three companies: one each for generation, transmission and retail.

On the Eastern Seaboard the National Electricity Market Management Company (NEMMCO) manages the wholesale market for the supply and purchase of electricity. Participants in the Eastern Seaboard market include generators, distributors, retailers and wholesale customers.

Information on the Year 2000 readiness of all organisations involved in the delivery of electricity is contained in State and Territory Government Year 2000 reports, except in Queensland where reports on private sector participants are published by the Queensland Electricity Supply Industry (QESI) Year 2000 committee.

The two peak electricity industry bodiesâNEMMCO and the Electricity Supply Association of Australia (ESAA)âhave established a number of forums on Year 2000 issues to facilitate information sharing, cooperative approaches to issues and coordination of activities.

The industry as a whole has reported it has nearly completed analysis, assessment, and testing of business critical systems, and is well advanced in contingency planning. The industry advises that extensive testing to date has not revealed any problems associated with Year 2000 that would affect current supply reliability. Remediation activities have reached the 90 per cent mark and are scheduled for completion by September 1999. State and Territory Governments report that contingency plans are increasingly in place and complete in some jurisdictions.

Contingency planning in the electricity industry is normal practice. The industry already has in place extensive contingency plans to deal with disruptions to electricity supply that can occur at any time through events such as storms, unplanned outages at power stations and damage to power poles and lines. NEMMCO chairs an industry group that examines contingency planning, including for the Year 2000. Those plans are being reviewed in light of the Year 2000 issue.

States such as Western Australia, Queensland and the Northern Territory are used to dealing with electricity outages during the summer months, which are cyclone and storm seasons. In these areas end users who have a reliance on electricity generally have alternative arrangements in place (e.g. diesel powered generators) should the service fail. Similarly, those organisations with greatest dependency on electricity generally have contingency plans in place to continue operations over the short term.

Local water authorities are responsible for the collection and distribution of water and the environmentally safe collection, treatment and disposal of sewage. The water sector is owned and operated by State, Territory and Local Governments, except in South Australia where it is supplied by a government-owned and private sector operated entity. The number of entities varies by State and region.

State and Territory Government Year 2000 reports indicate that the Year 2000 readiness of water supply across the majority of States and Territories is above 90 per cent, and contingency plans range from 75 to 100 per cent complete Information on the readiness of water supply in some areas of Queensland is not yet complete. Some jurisdictions, for example Victoria, Australian Capital Territory and Tasmania report a heavy reliance on gravity fed water systems that make little or no use of date dependent technology.

Disruptions to water supply, such as a burst pipe, can occur without warning. As with the electricity sector, contingency planning is part of normal business planning for water suppliers, but they report that they are also developing additional contingency plans to cope with any unexpected problems arising from Year 2000.

In Australia gas is supplied primarily by the private sector. Western Australia is the exception, where gas is distributed by the State-owned AlintaGas corporation. In New South Wales and the Australian Capital Territory the gas sector is almost entirely owned and operated by the Australian Gas Light Corporation (AGL). In all other States and Territories there are a number of large and small organisations involved in the supply, distribution, transmission, retail and wholesale of gas. In the Northern Territory, 99 per cent of gas is used in electricity generation, and 95 per cent of electricity is generated by gas. Tasmania does not currently have natural gas. The main activity of the Gas Corporation of Tasmania is the supply of bulk LPG to thousands of consumers throughout the state.

In Western Australia the major gas producers, users and pipeline owners have formed a Gas Industry Group to facilitate industry exchange and cooperation on Year 2000 issues. A similar group has been formed in South Australia, which includes representatives from Western Australia and Queensland.

While gas has wide domestic use, especially for heating systems, the Year 2000 critical date period is considered to be a low usage period in Australia as it will be summer. For industry also it will be a low usage or close down period of the year. Gas is also used to power electricity generators. In the main, gas fired generators are used to manage peak demand. In the Northern Territory, however, its five major electricity power stations are powered by gas.

Most gas companies in Australia report their Year 2000 status through the ASX, and in one case to the New York Stock Exchange. A number of States report on the preparedness of the gas sector as part of their reporting framework. Victoria has brought the entire sectorâgas distribution, retail and transmissionâinto its standard state government reporting framework. By July 1999, it reported that its gas industry was 98 per cent ready for the Year 2000, and that 88 per cent of contingency plans were in place. Western Australia reports that by June 1999 gas distribution was 92 per cent Year 2000 ready, with 90 per cent of contingency plans in place. The Queensland government is monitoring the gas industry in its jurisdiction, reporting that by August 1999 all but one of the major operators was more than 80 per cent ready.
Based on current information available through extensive reports by the gas industry, the sector is confident that gas will continue to flow on and after 1 January 2000.

States and Territory Governments are generally responsible for passenger and freight road transport, passenger and freight rail services, and shipping and port facilities. Where transport activities are government-owned or controlled, advice on Year 2000 progress is contained in State and Territory Government Year 2000 Reports. Larger private entities generally report through the Australian, London or New York stock exchanges.

The Australian road transport industry consists of commercial companies that operate fleets or provide logistics services to others; independent owner-operators; and bus and coach fleets, about one third of which are government operated. The road infrastructure itself is a State and Territory Government responsibility, with the provision and maintenance of services delegated to State and Territory agencies or local government. State and Territory Government Year 2000 reporting on road transport covers road infrastructure, including signalling and traffic management systems. Where reported, readiness levels are generally above 90 per cent.

The rail operating businesses of Australian National (SA Freight, Tasrail and AN Passenger) were sold to three privately operated consortia in 1997. The interstate freight operator National Rail is owned jointly by the Commonwealth and the New South Wales and Victorian Governments. It has reported that it is scheduled to be compliant by the end of October 1999. Otherwise, the rail transport sector is predominantly State and Territory Government controlled and is part of their Year 2000 reporting frameworks. Year 2000 readiness levels of rail transport where reported by States and Territories tend to be 90 per cent or above. The reported level of contingency planning is variable.

Australia's major port facilities are owned and operated by State and Territory Governments, and are therefore part of the State and Territory Year 2000 reporting framework. Many States and Territories are reporting levels of Year 2000 readiness above 90 per cent, and some at 100 per cent. The Commonwealth Government's Australian Maritime Safety Authority (AMSA) has embraced the International Maritime Organisation (IMO) Code of Good Practice on Y2K . The Code of Good Practice is aimed at producing a safe environment for normal business in ports and navigation during 2000.

From 1 July 1999, AMSA surveyors stepped up their program of checking that ships have addressed the Year 2000 issue in accordance with the Code. Ships entering Australian ports are required to demonstrate Year 2000 compliance or readiness and a satisfactory management strategy. Ship owners have been warned that from 1 November 1999 ships may be detained on a visit to an Australian port unless and until they can demonstrate adequate levels of Year 2000 preparedness. State and Territory marine authorities and/or port authorities may take action in addition to that of AMSA, depending on their legislative responsibilities.

Formal reporting on Year 2000 preparedness in the fuel sector occurs through Australian and international (New York and London) stock exchanges or the United States Securities and Exchange Commission. The Australian Institute of Petroleum (AIP) formed a joint Year 2000 Committee with the Australian Petroleum Production and Exploration Association (APPEA) in 1997 to assist member companies on the Year 2000 issue. The committee is discussing contingency plans with the emergency services authorities in States/Territories. The Committee has also met with ESAA, the New South Wales and Victorian Electricity Supply Associations and Telstra.

Along with electricity, fuel is critical to enabling normal business and community activity. Contingency plans for a range of businesses which involve backup electricity generation units generally rely on fuel for operation.

The Australian petroleum industry has examined its systems and, where necessary, remediated and tested them. The industry is reporting that remediation activity is almost complete. Supply chains have been checked. Business continuity plans are being finalised. Contingency plans are a normal part of business in the fuel industry for safety purposesâfuel is a volatile product and the safety of the public and workforce is of paramount importance. The fuel industry is IT-dependent but it also has manual back up systemsâsuch as turning valves by hand, and trucks with their own power and pumping ability to enable fuel to be moved wherever it is required.

The industry is ensuring that all parts of the supply chain are prepared and is confident that there is at least two weeks of stock within the system. This gives a very large margin of time to get the refineries operating again in the unlikely event of any disruption.
There is no need, therefore, for business or the community to stockpile fuel which could endanger public safety.

The Australian health care system involves a diversity of arrangements for planning, funding and delivering health services. The sector includes the public hospital system, private hospitals, community health services, aged care facilities, doctors' surgeries, and medical services such as X-rays, pathology and blood services.

Commonwealth health policy is administered through its portfolio agencies under the Minister for Health and Aged Care. The Commonwealth contributes to funding for hospital services and some community-based health care and aged care services, and administers the Medicare Benefits Scheme and the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.

Each State and Territory Government is responsible for the administration and funding of its public health authorities. Local governments and private, non-government organisations (including not-for-profit organisations) also provide health services. Most medical and dental care services are provided by private practitioners.

The Commonwealth Government and each State and Territory Government have been checking equipment and systems likely to be affected by the Year 2000 issue. Equipment and systems identified as having a problem are either being repaired or replaced and contingency plans developed to ensure services can be provided if unexpected incidents occur.

The Commonwealth Government, in partnership with general practitioners through the profession's peak national body for computing, the General Practice Computing Group, has developed a guide to assist individual general practitioners address Year 2000 issues. The guide gives doctors resources to put strategies in place which will allow them to continue to run their practices throughout this period.

The Commonwealth and the States and Territories have provided information to the nursing home and hostel sectors on preparing for the Year 2000. These aged care facilities have been encouraged to identify date sensitive electronic systems and equipment, take reasonable and necessary steps to manage risks, and prepare contingency plans.

The Health Departments of each State and Territory are already well-versed in dealing with critical incidents such as loss of power and communications or other events that could be caused by the Year 2000 issue. To deal with these incidents, hospitals and other health care facilities are putting in place plans to allow them to switch from normal operations to contingency mode with minimal disruption to the care provided to patients.

Reporting on the Year 2000 readiness of medical devices has been required by the Therapeutic Goods Administration, and State and Territory Health Departments have been undertaking and/or advocating the thorough testing of medical equipment.

Pharmaceutical manufacturers and wholesalers have indicated that they have undertaken thorough Year 2000 compliance reviews underpinned by appropriate testing and remediation programs, and are planning to operate normally throughout the Christmas/New Year period.

Local government provides services and infrastructure, plays a major role in environmental management, and provides leadership and governance to local communities. The key service supplied by local governments is water supply where, as noted above, good progress is being made.

Constitutional responsibility for local government rests with the States and Territories, which has resulted in development of different State and Territory systems for overseeing local government and delivering local government services. State and Territory Governments have the primary role of managing local government within their jurisdictions, legislating for and regulating local government, setting new policy directions and distributing Commonwealth funding to local government.

New South Wales, Victoria and Tasmania report on the Year 2000 preparedness of local government in their State as part of their government reporting framework. Year 2000 progress is variedâalthough in all three jurisdictions there are increasing numbers of local governments reporting 100 per cent Year 2000 readiness and high levels of contingency plans complete.

The Commonwealth Government will distribute information to ensure Australians are kept informed of the progress being made on Year 2000 work. Information material is being developed and disseminated in consultation with State and Territory Governments, which are providing the community with complementary local information.
The Commonwealth Government will keep people informed through:
. the distribution of a community booklet via telephone hotline numbers and on request;
. radio messages about preparations in key service areas;
. messages in the print media providing information about Australia's preparedness and contact details for more information;
. the distribution of Commonwealth Government Information Bulletins;
. a Commonwealth Government Year 2000 website (www.year2000.gov.au ) providing information for the community, business and governments, as well as links to other sources of information.

The Commonwealth and State and Territory Governments are working together in making preparations to monitor and manage any consequences in the unlikely event of a Year 2000 failure over New Year's Eve and the following period.

A network of Year 2000 National Coordination Centres (NCCs) is being established in each capital city, including Canberra. NCCs will be responsible for monitoring event management activities within their own jurisdictions, coordinating the provision of assistance and providing high level policy advice to Governments. The Commonwealth NCC will build on existing Emergency Management Australia (EMA) facilities.

In addition, NCCs will collect and consolidate key information to provide a State and Territory and national picture for both national and international audiences. Recognising that the community and industry will want to be kept aware of any developments, regular media bulletins will be issued by the NCCs. The Commonwealth NCC will have responsibility for providing a national picture. It will also participate in a UN-sponsored exercise to deliver early advice to other countries on Australia's progress through the date rollover.
The Australian Government continues to attach high priority to ensuring that it meets the significant challenges posed by the international dimension of the Year 2000 issue.

The Government is working with other governments and with Australian industry on coordinated approaches to these challenges, including through APEC, the United Nations and its International Y2K Cooperation Centre, the Year 2000 National Steering Committee, and other relevant international organisations. Ministers are taking every opportunity to raise Year 2000 issues with their counterparts overseas.

Australian industry, often in conjunction with government, has been particularly active in cooperation in international aviation, telecommunications and banking and finance. Australia hosted the International Telecommunication Union (ITU) Asia Pacific Telecommunications Year 2000 conference in March this year. Government and industry worked very closely on this conference, which was attended by 154 delegates from 45 countries. Another example was the APEC Y2K Symposium in Singapore, which focused on cross-border impacts of the Year 2000 issue on critical economic infrastructure and on contingency planning. Australia fielded an expert delegation to this symposium, including speakers on banking and finance and electricity.

Through the aid program, Australia is providing substantial technical assistance to Papua New Guinea and other South Pacific countries to help them prepare for the year 2000 transition. Australia has also provided some assistance in Asia in key areas such as aviation and telecommunications.

Australia is widely regarded as one of the best-prepared countries to meet the challenges posed by the Year 2000 issue. Australia, along with the United Kingdom, North American and Scandinavian countries is recognised as leading the world in its Year 2000 preparations.

The Government has been monitoring Year 2000 preparations overseas very closely, particularly over the last year, including in discussion with overseas governments, local service providers, the Australian telecommunications, aviation and power sectors, relevant United Nations specialised agencies and other international Year 2000 experts. We have also been working closely with other governments on information sharing and broadly coordinated approaches to public information and risk reduction, including contingency planning.

A roundtable meeting was held this month with a group of Australian manufacturing and services exporters and importers representing a range of industries to share information on their experiences in preparing for the Year 2000. The roundtable provided the Government with valuable, additional perspectives concerning the nature of any international Year 2000 effects on business and the implications for Australia.

The Government has an ongoing duty of care to inform the travelling public where the potential exists for Australians to experience difficultiesâparticularly where personal safely, health considerations or other restrictions are of concern. The Australian Government takes this responsibility very seriously.

From early 1999 the Government has been providing information to the Australian community on the international dimensions of the Year 2000 issue, particularly through the Foreign Affairs and Trade website on international perspectives and through regular consular travel advices. The advice is reviewed regularly and is carried on the Department's website (http://www.dfat.gov.au/year2000/ ) or by calling 02 6261 3305 or 1300 555 135.

Several countries have recently released consular advice on Year 2000 preparedness in a wide range of other countries. Australia is also making a serious effort to identify and select the most credible information available on Year 2000 preparedness in essential service sectors overseas. Australia has discussed assessments of overseas Year 2000 preparedness with authorities in those countries and territories where Australia has diplomatic missions.
The Government proposes to continue to closely monitor international Year 2000 preparations throughout 1999 and into 2000 and to make any necessary amendments to public advice.

debateinfo.title: STATES GRANTS (PRIMARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1999

subdebate.1.para: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Patterson) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

talk.start.para: âI table a revised explanatory memorandum relating to the bill and move:

speech.para: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard .
Leave granted.
The speech read as followsâ
The bill amends the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Act 1996 to give effect to initiatives announced in the 1999-2000 Budget. These initiatives will provide:

. $36.3 million in 2000 to increase funding under the Literacy and Numeracy Program to help schools measurably improve the literacy and numeracy skills of students in the early and middle years of schooling. This funding will support two initiatives:
. Support for the National Literacy and Numeracy Plan, and
. Strategies to improve literacy and numeracy in the middle years of schooling; and
. $26.4 million to extend funding for the National Asian Languages and Studies in Australian Schools (NALSAS) Strategy in 2000.
The bill also contains provisions which:

. provide an additional $10.1 million for each of the program years 2000 up to, and including, 2003 for the non-government component of the Capital Grants Program to maintain funding at the same real level as for the period 1997 to 1999;

. provide an additional $1.9 million for Short Term Emergency Assistance (STEA) in 2000 to allow schools experiencing severe financial hardship or facing problems of viability to apply for STEA during the transitional period to the new SES funding model for non-government schools; and
. make a minor technical amendment to the headings in the act to change the name of the Literacy Program to the Literacy and Numeracy Program.

The government's continuing support for improvements in school students' literacy and numeracy skills is a key aspect of the government's overall strategy to improve literacy and numeracy skills of young Australians.

The Commonwealth makes a very significant financial contribution to support the work of schools and teachers in improving the literacy and numeracy skills of young Australians. The 1999-2000 Budget provides an additional $131 million under the Literacy and Numeracy Program for disadvantaged school students, making a total of almost $869 million for literacy and numeracy in the next four years to 2002-03.

Research has shown that, for young Australians, the consequences of poor literacy and numeracy achievement at school include an increased likelihood of leaving school early, poor access to further education and training and a much higher risk of unemployment. If students receive support in acquiring literacy and numeracy skills at school, it will reduce their risk of unemployment by increasing their ability to participate in education and improving their ability to successfully participate in the workforce.
The Commonwealth is working with States and Territories to ensure that all children achieve an acceptable standard of literacy and numeracy skills.

The additional funding will help schools measurably improve the literacy and numeracy skills of students in the early and middle years of schooling. Funding will be provided under the Literacy and Numeracy Program and will commence on 1 January 2000.
The National Asian Languages and Studies in Australian Schools (NALSAS) Strategy is a cooperative initiative between Commonwealth, State and Territory governments.

The Strategy assists government and non-government schools to improve participation and proficiency levels in language learning in four targeted Asian languagesâJapanese, Chinese (Mandarin), Indonesian and Koreanâand to introduce or increase Asian studies content across the curriculum.

The Commonwealth initially agreed to fund the program for four years, with further funding subject to an evaluation of the program. The evaluation informed the discussions which resulted in the continuation of the Taskforce established by the Ministerial Council on Education, Employment, Training and Youth Affairs (MCEETYA) to monitor the implementation of the NALSAS Strategy.

This bill provides $26.4 million to continue funding for the National Asian Languages and Studies in Australian Schools (NALSAS) Strategy in 2000 to support enhanced and expanded Asian languages and Asian studies provision through all school systems in order to improve Australia's capacity and preparedness to interact internationally, particularly with key Asian economies.
This extra funding for the NALSAS strategy will be used to provide continued support to teachers and students.

The government's funding policies for schools will assist in ensuring quality educational outcomes for students in government and non-government schools. Total direct Commonwealth schools funding will amount to more than $17 billion over the period 1997 to 2000.
This funding affirms the Commonwealth's commitment to schooling in Australia.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator O'Brien) adjourned.

debateinfo.title: INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY LAWS AMENDMENT (BORDER INTERCEPTION) BILL 1999

subdebate.1.para: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Patterson) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard .
Leave granted.
The speech read as followsâ

The objective of this bill is to enhance the protection available to the Sydney Organising Committee for the Olympic Games and the Sydney Paralympic Organising Committee (the organising Committees) against imported goods that seek to ambush their marketing activities. The bill will also enhance the protection available to owners of registered trade marks against imported goods that bear infringing trade marks.

In 1996 the Parliament enacted legislation, the Sydney 2000 Games (Indicia and Images) Protection Act 1996, to protect the Sydney 2000 Olympic and Paralympic Games (the Games) against ambush marketing. Ambush marketing is the unauthorised association of businesses with the marketing of an event, such as the Sydney Olympics, without paying for the marketing rights.

The Olympic and Paralympic Games next year are events of great national significance. These events provide unique opportunities to demonstrate to the world this country's skills, talents, environment and achievements. One of the critical factors in making the Games an outstanding success is the ability of the organising Committees to raise the funds necessary to host the Games. It is a massive task. It is also very expensive.

The cost of staging the Games is estimated to be over $2 billion. The costs are being shared between the organising Committees, the Government of New South Wales and, to a minor extent, the Commonwealth Government. In its 1998 Annual Report, the Sydney Organising Committee for the Olympic Games estimated that it needs to raise in the vicinity of $800 million from official sponsor ships and licensing fees to meet its budget for the Games.

The ability of the organising Committees to attract sponsors depends to a large extent on the exclusivity of the licensed indicia and images. If the Parliament had not enacted the Sydney 2000 Games Act to protect the organising Committees against ambush marketing, the official sponsorship revenue for the Games may have been at risk. The Sydney 2000 Games Act vests the rights in the indicia and images specified in the act with the organising Committees. The act enables the organising Committees to use and to license others to use the indicia and images identified in the act for commercial purposes.

To constitute use for commercial purposes, Games indicia or images must generally be used in a manner that falsely suggests a person is a sponsor (or supporter) of the Games. The Sydney 2000 Games Act, however, does not place an absolute fetter on the use of protected Games indicia and images. For example, the act does not effect the community's fundamental right to freedom of expression. This is particularly the case in relation to words that have passed into common usage. It must therefore be emphasised that restrictions on the use of Games indicia and images apply only to unlicensed commercial use of the protected indicia and images.

The Sydney 2000 Games Act provides various remedies to the organising Committees and licensed users to enforce their rights in relation to Games indicia and images. Thus, where an unlicensed user uses Games indicia or images in contravention of the act, an organising Committee (or a relevant licensed user) may bring an action against the unlicensed user. The remedies available include injunctions, damages and corrective advertising. I have been informed that, to date, the organising Committees have not yet needed to take any action to enforce their rights under the Sydney 2000 Games Act through the Courts.

The Sydney 2000 Games Act also includes appropriate Customs measures to limit the possibility of the importation of goods that seek to ambush the Games marketing. These border interception provisions enable the Australian Customs Service to seize imported goods that seek to ambush the Games marketing. Once goods have been seized, Customs is required to advise the relevant organising Committee or licensed user and the designated owner of the goods of the seizure. The organising Committee or licensed user has then 10 days following seizure of the goods to commence infringement proceedings. If proceedings are not commenced within that time, the goods are returned to the owner. However, the designated owner of the goods may forfeit the goods to the Commonwealth at any time before proceedings commence.

Customs has seized a significant number of consignments under the border interception provisions of the Sydney 2000 Games Act and it is likely to encounter an increasing number of these consignments during the lead-up to the Games. In many cases, after Customs has seized goods, the designated owner of the seized goods has forfeited the goods to the Commonwealth thus eliminating, quickly and cheaply, potential threats to the organising Committees' revenue. In the majority of the other cases, the designated owner of the goods has complied with the organising Committees written demands.

It is these border interception provisions in the Sydney 2000 Games Act that this bill is intended to modify. The amendment proposed by this bill to the Sydney 2000 Games Act addresses a discrepancy between the seizure powers of Customs and its obligation to notify the designated owner of the seized goods under the border interception provisions of that act. The seizure power of the Sydney 2000 Games Act is in broad terms; it applies to all infringing goods. However, as I have mentioned, Customs is also obliged to notify the designated owner that the goods have been seized.

Presently, the Sydney 2000 Games Act defines the designated owner as the person identified as the owner of the goods on the `entry' made in relation to the goods under section 68 of the Customs Act 1901. However, section 68 of that act excludes several types of goods from the general requirement to be entered. For example, goods consigned by post worth less than $1000 or goods worth less than $250 consigned by other means do not have to be entered. Therefore, goods that are not entered do not have a designated owner. As a result, Customs cannot seize goods that are not entered because there is no designated owner to notify. As considerable numbers of such consignments can occur, this discrepancy undermines the intent of the border interception provisions of the Sydney 2000 Games Act.

The amendments proposed by this bill will improve the effectiveness of the Sydney 2000 Games Act by enabling Customs to seize all goods that seek to ambush the Games marketing, whether or not the goods require entry under the Customs Act.

As the border interception provisions of the Sydney 2000 Games Act were largely based on the border interception provisions of the Trade Marks Act 1995, both acts share a common definition of designated owner. Therefore, this bill proposes also to make a similar amendment to the Trade Marks Act.

The amendments made by this bill are not intended to apply to all goods imported into Australia and especially not to goods imported for personal use. As I mentioned previously, goods will only infringe the Sydney 2000 Games Act if the goods are used for commercial purposes and that term has a particular meaning under that act. Similarly, goods will only infringe a registered trade mark if the goods bear the trade mark, or are used in connection with the trade mark, in the course of trade.
I commend this bill to the Senate.
Ordered that further consideration of the second reading of this bill be adjourned till the first day of sitting in the summer sittings 1999, in accordance with standing order 111.

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That Schedule 1 of the Migration Amendment Regulations 1999 (No. 8), as contained in Statutory Rules 1999 No. 132 and made under the Migration Act 1958 , be disallowed.

That string of numbers relates to a regulation which has extended the operation of the $1,000 post-decision fee which applies to unsuccessful applicants to the Refugee Review Tribunal. It is a matter that has been raised in this chamber a number of times. It was initially put into operation a couple of years ago. In 1997 in fact, before I came into this place, it was subject to an unsuccessful disallowance motion moved, at that time, by Senator Margetts.

At that time a two-year sunset clause was put on the $1,000 fee, and a number of other measures were introduced which were not subject to a sunset clause and which are still in place. The $1,000 fee for Refugee Review Tribunal applicants did have a sunset clause put in place, which meant that it ran out at 30 June this year. This regulation extends that sunset clause for another three years. The operation and impact of the $1,000 fee was subject to an inquiry by the joint parliamentary migration committee, of which I am a member, and the report from the government members of that committee recommended maintaining the $1,000 fee.

I and the three Labor membersâDr Theophanous, Mr Ripoll and Mrs Irwin, all from the lower houseârecommended that regulation 4.31B cease to operate after 1 July. And that is basically what this disallowance motion aims to do: it is to give effect to that recommendation. I note that Senator McKiernan, who is the other Labor member on that committee and who will be speaking on this motion, did not share the view of his colleagues in that regard, and I am sure he will be outlining his rationale for that shortly.

I would say, as I do try to acknowledge with this area of law, that immigration lawârefugee law, in particularâis not an easy area and that there are a lot of competing issues that need to be addressed. I do recognise that it is appropriate for the government to try to ensure that the operation of the refugee program, the onshore humanitarian program in particular, is not abused and misused by people for inappropriate purposes. My view is that the extent of that misuse has been somewhat exaggerated by the government and the department, but I certainly would not pretend to suggest that no misuse occurs.

It is for that reason that many of the original measures were brought in in 1997, including limiting the right for people seeking protection visas to be able to work whilst they are in Australia. I think that those measures are more likely to have had an impact in stemming misuse than has this particular fee. Either way, in an issue like this, whilst there are competing policy aspects that have to be considered, I and the Democrats believe that priority has to be given to the human rights aspects of this issue and to ensuring that genuine asylum seekersâand that does not necessarily mean successful asylum seekersâare not disadvantaged.

I think the onus has to be on the government and the department to prove that there is no disadvantage being caused to those people. I believe that they certainly failed to prove that during the course of the joint committee inquiry. The government would and did argue that it has not been proven categorically that genuine applicants have been disadvantaged and have suffered as a result of this fee. I would suggest that there is some degree of evidence to the committee that that was the case, from a number of organisations that work in this area and also work with people involved in this area at community level on the ground.

My view is that there was some evidence presented that indicated that it was a potential problem, but my viewâdespite or in addition to thatâis that it really is, in an area like this, up to the department to categorically prove that no disadvantage occurs. I do not think the onus of proof should operate in the other direction in that community organisations and refugee applicants should have to prove categorically that there has been disadvantage.

The inquiry heard from a number of organisations, as I mentioned, who were involved on a daily basis with onshore humanitarian refugee issues. Some were well-known ones, such as Amnesty International, the Refugee Council of Australia and the Federation of Ethnic Community Councils of Australia. There were also a number of other organisations that are not so well known but that are also very heavily involved in this area: the Refugee and Immigration Legal Service Centre, the Immigration Advice and Rights Centre, the Campbelltown Legal Centre and other more community based centres. The very strong view from those associations and organisations was that the $1,000 fee is not appropriate and does provide a potential disincentive and potential hardship for genuine refugee applicants.

It is important to emphasise and clarify in this area again that, to apply for a protection visa in Australia, peopleâif they are not successful at departmental levelâcan appeal to, and have the right of appeal to, the Refugee Review Tribunal, and that is something that the Democrats certainly support. The $1,000 fee applies if they are unsuccessful; yet it has to be emphasised that many people who do not fit the definition of `refugee' apply for a protection visa and appeal to the Refugee Review Tribunal.

But the definition of refugee is a very narrow one. I think it is a lot narrower than many people realise, and many quite genuine humanitarian cases nonetheless do not fit the technical legal definition of a refugee and are then able to seek the operation of ministerial discretionâthat is, apply to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs asking him to exercise discretion to grant them a protection visa on humanitarian grounds. That is successful in a number of cases. I cannot think of the number off the top of my head, but certainly it is more common that people are successful in that regard than they have been previously.

But, to get to that stage, even people that know they are not technically refugees but still believe they have a genuine humanitarian case have to go through the Refugee Review Tribunal anyway. Then, not surprisingly, they fail and have to seek ministerial discretion. If they get ministerial discretion, the $1,000 fee does not apply but, whilst a number of people do get support from the minister and the exercise of ministerial discretion, a number of them do notâa majority of them do not. That ministerial discretion is not compellable; it is not appealable. Regardless of how genuine their claim is and how genuine they feel it is, they have no way of knowing for sure whether or not they are going to be successful, because it is very arbitrary in the technical senseâit is a very arbitrary powerâand it is difficult for people to be certain that they will be successful in appealing to the minister.

But if they are not, regardless of how genuine their claim is, they are then subject to this $1,000 fee. I believe, and the Democrats believe, that that is completely inappropriate. I am not suggesting that the government explicitly says this, although I think sometimes it is implied somewhat. But certainly there is the suggestion out in the community from time to time that anybody who applies for a protection visa and is unsuccessful has therefore been trying to rort the system: they are either accepted and successful or they are unsuccessfulâand that means they are trying to rort the system. I think that is a misconception that we need to completely deny, because it is clearly not the case. Obviously, some people do try to misuse the system but, in my view, the vast majority of people who are unsuccessful in applying for protection visas are nonetheless genuine in their belief about the genuineness of their case and genuine in their attempts to exercise what they believe is their legal entitlement to a protection visa.

So I believe it is important, in terms of our approach to this debate within the community, to make sure that we do not allow that myth to take hold as a community perception. In my view, this $1,000 fee does reinforce that perception. It is clearly a penalty or a fee which people are required to pay. If people are charged a fee for something when they are unsuccessful there is a symbolic inference that they have not been genuine in the application.

There are many other issues in relation to the operation of refugee policy which I will not go into, because I will try to confine this debate specifically to the fee. As the Senate would know, there is a committee inquiry at the moment, with the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee examining the wider operation of our refugee and humanitarian program. That committee inquiry is proving quite constructive and all parties are contributing in a cooperative way. Whilst I am not sure that I am going to be getting support from other parties for this allowance motionâalthough I certainly hope I do, because of the evidence that has been providedâI do again recognise that this is a difficult area of policy.

As I mentioned before, Senator McKiernan disagreed with his Labor colleagues on the Joint Standing Committee on Migration about the best approach with this fee. Obviously I disagreed with him on the conclusion, but I do recognise his very comprehensive understanding of the issues involved in this area and his commitment to them. But I do believe that on this particular issue it is important to come down on the side of emphasising justice and humanitarian assistance.

As I stated in a number of forums in the last couple of weeks, it is my view and the Democrats' view that a humanitarian and compassionate approach has been devalued somewhat in recent years in immigration and refugee policy. I am not in any way suggesting that our approach should be an unthinking, bleeding heartâ`Let everybody who wants to come in come in, just because we feel sorry for them'âtype of approach. I recognise that we have to put particular restrictions in place, but I do believe that the balance has got out of kilter in recent times and that this fee is one example of that. The focus has been so much on preventing rorting and on keeping so-called non-genuine people out that it may be achieving that goal to an extent but it is also penalising innocent people in the process. I believe that when you get to that circumstance it clearly needs some readjustment.

In my view, disallowing this fee will not generate a huge budgetary problem and, inasmuch as it does, I do not believe it is appropriate for measures such as this to be driven by budgetary implications. The rationale for putting it in place was not cost related or for it to be a budgetary assistance measure; it was meant to be a disincentive for misuse. I do not believe it has been proven by the departmentâin fact, I am certain it has not been provenâthat it has operated in that way, that it has had that effect. But I do believe it has had an effect. Many of the organisations that work with asylum seekers in Australia believe it has had a negative effect on those people.

The majority of people that are subject to the $1,000 feeâit is worth emphasising and I am sure other speakers will do soâdo not pay it. They tend to leave the country and not pay the fee. That was an argument the department used to say that there was not much hardship being generated, because people choose not to pay it and just leave the country. Obviously the aim of the policy is to have non-genuine applicants or non-legal residents removed from the country.

The downside is that, until that $1,000 fee is paid, they are not able to return in any way or under any form of visa at all. That presents problems for genuine applicants who have gone through the process in good faith and then have that particular avenue closed off to them unless they pay that extra fee. The costs and hurdles in relation to people trying to enter Australia and trying to settle here are already fairly substantial, in the Democrats' view, and adding an extra hurdle in this regard is, in our view, inappropriate.

In conclusion, the clear evidence provided by a vast number of organisations who work very closely and heavily in this area was that this fee was not proven to be operating in a way that clearly prevented misuse of the protection visa stream, but they were almost unanimously of the view that it clearly provided a disincentive for genuine refugee applicants and seekers of protection visas on humanitarian grounds. In the face of that evidenceâthe fact that it is not appropriate for it to operate as a budgetary measureâI think it is almost impossible to see how it could not impact on some genuine asylum seekers in a negative way.

The Democrats believe that it is appropriate that this disallowance motion be supported. Otherwise, we will be stuck with this for at least another three years. In that case, we certainly believe that the inappropriateness of the measure would become even more clear over that period of time. There are plenty of other measures in place that already make it difficult for people seeking humanitarian visas or protection visas in Australia. I do not believe this extra one is an appropriate one. I do urge the Senate to support the Democrats' move to disallow it.

talk.start.para: âAs the previous speaker, Senator Bartlett, said, regulation 4.31 has been in existence now for some two years and just under three monthsâless than 27 months. It was, when it was first introduced, made subject to a two-year sunset clause. Part of the condition of opposition support for the regulation at that time two years ago was that the regulation be subjected to a review by the Joint Standing Committee on Migration prior to the expiration of the sunset clause.

speech.para: I was a member of that committee which reviewed the regulation and the impact of the regulation. As Senator Bartlett said, I supported the majority decision of the committee which recommended at 3.35 on page 43 of the committee's report that regulation 4.31B be retained and that, to allow for a more thorough assessment of its effectiveness, it be subjected to a three-year sunset clause commencing on 1 July 1999. It is my understanding that the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs has agreed with that recommendation and has gone even further to make it a two-year sunset clause, which is when it will be reviewed again. That is a welcomed action by the minister. It will enable, I would think, intelligence to be gathered about the proper impact of the fee.

It was the general conclusion of the committee that two years was a very short time for it to be in existence to get a proper and thorough analysis of its impact and effect. When one takes into account the fact that the fee came into being on 1 July 1997 and that it did not have an impact on many of the people who were already in the pipeline at that time and that the committee was reviewing it in the first half of this year, effectively we were looking at 12 months worth of figures. So we were not really in a position to look at all of the impact of the fee. With a further two-year sunset clause, it will enable a bodyâand I hope it would be the joint standing committeeâto undertake the review again. It will enable them to review the impact of the fee in a proper atmosphere.

Like Senator Bartlett, the Democrats and many others in this chamber, I too have a great concern about the impact of this fee on genuine refugees and genuine asylum seekers in this country. I was at pains during the inquiry to question the witnesses about the impact. As I said in my additional comment which I included with the report, I was comforted by the fact that nobody was able to point out to me or to the committee that the fee was having a negative impact or was stopping genuine asylum seekers from putting in their application to the Refugee Review Tribunal for a reassessment of their claims for protection in this country.

A person who I hold in very high regard, a person who from time to time can be a great thorn in the side of the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and indeed officers of the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, is Ms Carolyn Graydon from the Refugee and Immigration Legal Centre. In Melbourne she told the committee:

From my own personal knowledge, I am not aware of any cases where I thought a person had very strong prospects of success but had been deterred by applying due to the $1,000 penalty fee. Some people are driven by such strong subjective fear that I do consider it to be unlikely that someone who faces persecution, or has a well-founded fear of persecution, in their home country would be deterred.

Carolyn Graydon cannot be said to be a friend of the department in any shape or form. She is an excellent individual who has moved on to other things other than the Refugee and Immigration Legal Centre. But Carolyn Graydon was not the only person who was questioned on this matter by me and other members of the committee. At the end of our inquiry we were not able to get the hard evidence to say that this $1,000 fee had inhibited or prevented a person who would have likely been granted refugee status in this country or protection in this country from being deterred in continuing their application to the Refugee Review Tribunal.

I wish to draw attention to the status of the people who made submissions to the committee as well as those who appeared before us. We had representatives from the Federation of Ethnic Communities' Council of Australia, the Adelaide Justice Coalition, the Refugee and Immigration Legal Centre, the Refugee Advice and Casework Service, the Refugee Council of Australia and the Australian Section of the International Commission on Jurists. Those who appeared before the committee were quite a representative group of well skilled advocates for refugees and asylum seekers in this country.

There were many others who were invited to appear and give evidence to the committee. Some of those included: the Thai Welfare Association, the Tribal Refugee Welfare of Western Australia, the Kingsford Legal Centre, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, Amnesty International Australia, the Refugee Advice and Casework Service, Campbelltown Legal Centre, the Australian Section of the International Commission of Jurists, the Network for International Protection of Refugees, the Australia Family Party, the Federation of Ethnic Communities' Councils and the Adelaide Justice Coalition. The community was invited to give the committee evidence on this issue. At the conclusion of the inquiry, the weight of evidence did not support the proposition that this fee was preventing or inhibiting genuine asylum seekers from continuing with their applications for protection.

Ms Biok from the International Commission for Jurists gave the committee an example of how she convinced a family from Sri Lanka to continue with their refugee application when they became concerned about their liability to pay a fee in the event of a failed application. Ms Biok said that she encouraged these people to continue with their application despite their worries. The family was granted protection in Australia. When granted protection they are not liable to pay the fee.

Mr Bitel from the International Commission of Jurists gave the committee an example of the inconvenience caused to an applicant from the Philippines. The asylum seeker failed in his application and returned to his homeland. He was later able to return to Australia after the fee had been paid.
