The interesting point is that this individual was returned to his homeland and was then allowed to leave his homeland again and make an application for refugee status in this country.

Another example of inconvenience was given to the committee by Ms Jennifer Burn from the Immigration Advice and Rights Centre. She provided a case study of the inconvenience caused for a failed asylum seeker who later returned to Australia under a different visa class. The committee did not have the opportunity to examine all of the details of the particular example given, but we do know that the individual returned on a spouse visa. Would it not be better to make the application under a spouse visa in the first instance rather than trying to engage Australia's protective mechanisms? That is part of the difficulty we have in this area.

It was admitted by a number of witnesses, including the Adelaide Justice Coalition, that there is a great measure of abuse occurring in the refugee application system in this country. That is a fact. This $1,000 fee is supposed to, in some way, curtail that problem. It has probably had some effect. I do not believe the committee was in a position, given the short time the $1,000 fee was in operation, to reach the conclusion that it was having the effect the government hoped it would have. The fact that, at the time the committee was inquiring, some $370,000 was collected from the fee is an indication that it was having some impact. I understand that figure is now closer to half a million dollars. I do not believe that half a million dollars in the immigration portfolio is seen to be a revenue measure as such. Nonetheless, it would look very nice on the bottom line. As I understand it, it goes into consolidated revenue rather than back into the immigration portfolio budget.

Things were happening far too quickly in the process. Eighteen months was too short a period under which to conduct a proper review of the impact of the regulation. As I said in an earlier part of my speech, I was comforted by the fact that the genuine refugee, the genuine asylum seeker, was still able to continue with his or her application through the review mechanism.

The Joint Standing Committee on Migration had a specific brief which was to look at the impact of the regulation. The committee did not have a brief to look at the operation of the exercise of the ministerial discretion to issue a humanitarian visa as such. We were inhibited in looking at that. I accept what you said, Mr Acting Deputy President Bartlett, in your contribution to the debate that there are people who have to go through the refugee application process in order to reach the minister to get humanitarian consideration. That is not something that the committee made recommendations on because we did not have a brief on that. I think there is a general view in the community that this procedure is somewhat convoluted and messy and does leave the refugee application system open to a form of abuse by some. It is something that has to be addressed and addressed properly by perhaps another parliamentary committee. I will not go into that matter any further at the moment.

I want to conclude my remarks by welcoming the minister's response to the report and the fact that there will be another review within two years. If that review occurs in the first half of 2001, the $1,000 regulation will have then been in existence for some three years plus. I think that would be quite a useful time period to properly analyse its impact and effect. I hope that, during that period, no genuine asylum seeker is removed from this country or is refouled under the terms of the various international conventions that Australia has agreed to be part of and has signed up to.

I am comforted, as I said in my additional comment in the report, by the fact that the minister still has a discretion and that people who are applying through the system for protection in Australia and who are going to the primary stage and the review stage know about the ministerial discretion and are making application to the minister. I am also comforted by the fact that the minister is responding and issuing humanitarian visas after consideration. Whether he is getting each and every one of them right is a matter for conjecture, but the evidence was not given to the Joint Standing Committee on Migration. When we are dealing with matters such as we are dealing with at the moment, we do have to rely on hard evidence. If that hard evidence were there, I am sure the Refugee Council of Australia, the Immigration Advice and Rights Centre, the International Commission of Jurists and other bodies like that would be in the forefront of presenting that evidence to a parliamentary committee such as the Joint Standing Committee on Migration.

I have devoted my remarks to merely a personal sense because of my involvement in the joint standing committee that reviewed the regulation and presented the report to the parliament earlier this year. The matter, however, has been discussed by my party in our caucus, and in that caucus meeting we have determined to oppose the disallowance of the regulation. Whilst I have spoken personally, I am representing the position of the Australian Labor Party in this debate.

talk.start.para: âMr Acting Deputy President, I rise to support your disallowance motionâfor the record, it should be noted that the mover of the disallowance motion, Senator Bartlett, is now in the chair as the Acting Deputy Presidentâand I do so for the very reasons you have advanced. I will not speak long because it is obvious that, if you call that the ayes have it from that exalted position, you might get a call for a division. Senator McKiernan has advised the Senate that the opposition will be voting with the government to defeat the disallowance motion, so there is not much point in my pursuing it further.

speech.para: With respectâand I say that deliberately because those who have preceded me, Senator McKiernan and Senator Bartlett, know far more about this matter than I doâI might take up a point Senator McKiernan raised. Senator McKiernan was emphasising the point that this $1,000 fee was not a deterrent. I think he has a point, frankly; it is not a deterrent as such. But it may be for some who have a really genuine belief that they will be persecuted if returned to their country of origin.

If they have that genuine belief, then it may deter them, bearing in mind they may have been advised by their solicitors that, if the appeal were made to the Refugee Review Tribunal, that tribunal may on balance consider that their genuine belief was not a well-founded fear. They may have that genuine fear, they may believe sincerely, they themselves might feel that is the case, but on balance the Refugee Review Tribunal may say, `No, that is not well-founded fear of persecution on convention grounds'âthat is, the refugee convention grounds. But there again, those individuals may have a well-founded fear on grounds other than the convention grounds. We have been through this in the recent discussions of the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee which is chaired by Senator McKiernan.

I will go to another point. It may not be a deterrent, but it may be a penalty for persons who are very concerned and are genuine applicants. The Australian Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, in its submission, stated:
Migration regulation 4.31Bâ
that is the regulation which we are seeking to disallowâ
is much too blunt an instrument and will deny to many genuine claimants their entitlement to an effective procedure and to non-refoulment. If the government is concernedâ
this is a very important observationâ

that some applicants to the Refugee Review Tribunal are unmeritorious or abusing the system, the appropriate response is not to penalise all unsuccessful applicants, as the present regulation does, but to give the tribunal discretion to impose a fee where it finds that an application is vexatious or an abuse of process.

I have not heard any arguments rejecting that view of the Human Rights and Equal Oppor tunity Commission. The parliamentary secretary may direct our attention to any view of the government with respect to that statement by the commission. But I think that is quite a reasonable approach to take. Why not? Why penalise the genuine people? As I say, they are genuine, because Australia, unlike most countries, just does not have an onshore humanitarian visa. That really is a problem when it comes to questions as to whether refoulement might take place, because of the genuine fear of persecution on grounds other than the refugee convention grounds; so, for example, under the convention on torture and on the ICCPR.

Through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, I ask the minister: what is wrong with taking up the suggestion that was made by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission? Why not allow this regulation to be disallowed, vote for the disallowance, then bring in further regulations which will enable the Refugee Review Tribunal discretion to impose a fee where it finds that an application is vexatious or there is an abuse of process? I will leave it at that. I will be interested to hear the response of the minister. But I think that would surely be the fair way of going about it. As it is, it is more costly to get to the Refugee Review Tribunal, if you are talking as though this $1,000 fee were a sinker, than it is to get to the High Court.

talk.start.para: âI thank honourable senators for their contributions. The government opposes the motion by Senator Bartlett to disallow schedule 1 of the Migration Amendment Regulations 1999 (No. 8) as contained in Statutory Rules 1999 No. 132. I remind senators that only applicants whose review is unsuccessful are liable to pay the fee. What I am saying may be a little disjointed, as I am responding; usually one gives a speech and does not respond, but I asked to speak last so that I could have the opportunity of responding. In response to what Senator Harradine just said, I point out that it is actually not a penalty; it is a fee. If you take the view that it is a penalty, then of course you might look at what Senator Harradine was suggesting.

speech.para: We also have to remember that the people who are in this situation have been through a first process. When Senator Harradine indicates that they may have a fear, it is a well-founded fear. It has been indicated that around 90 per cent of review applicants are unsuccessful at the Refugee Review Tribunal, because they have already been through a first process. There has been one decision made already. If the applicant has strong claims outside the UNHCR convention, then this can be picked up in the minister's public interest powers following the Refugee Review Tribunal. So if the person is reviewed and the review is unfavourable and the minister then intervenes, the fee is no longer liable to be paid or, if it is already paid, it is refunded to the applicant. If the person is a genuine applicant, they have already been through one process, then they go into the Refugee Review Tribunal, and they all then have the chance of the minister intervening.

If a person has a well-founded fear, and they are genuine, they ought to believe that through that process they will be accepted and therefore not liable for the fee. Also the fee can be waived in certain circumstances. It was introduced to minimise abuse of the protection visa system by non-genuine applicants seeking to delay their departure and to access various benefits in Australia. At the time of the introduction, it was agreed that there be a two-year sunset clause ending on 30 June with a review by the joint standing committee to be completed on that date. The majority of the committee concluded that a significant amount of abuse was occurring. I think that is something that needs to be taken into consideration. There was a significant amount of abuse occurring. The fee has not deterred genuine refugees from applying for review. It was not in breach of Australia's international obligations to refugees. The extension of the sunset clause by two years to 1 July 2001, together with a review within that period, is consistent with the majority recommendation of the joint committee.

Supporting the motion that Senator Bartlett has proposed would mean that abuse of the refugee system of review would continue and non-refugees would no longer have a debt recorded against their name if they did not pay the fee. They could reapply to obtain a visa to re-enter Australia, without making any contribution to the costs incurred by the Australian taxpayer in their misuse of the protection visa system.

In response to some of the things that Senator Bartlett said, not one case was identified in the course of the inquiry into the sunset clause where a person who was a refugee or who had good claims was deterred from going to the RRT. As I said before, it is not a penalty; it is a fee. There is no need for presumptions about motives of the individuals. It acts as a general disincentive for those who are not genuine in their motives. Those who depart instead of paying can always be given time to pay off the fee if they want a visa to return, and Senator McKiernan gave an example of that.

I have to say that the more experience I have in this portfolioâand I acknowledge Senator McKiernan's long interest in this portfolio, and I think Senator Harradine said that Senator McKiernan knows more about it than he does, and I am sure he knows a lot more about it than I do; I have been on a steep learning curveâmy great concern is that every person who comes here, who somehow manipulates their way through the system and who is not a genuine refugee takes the place of someone else, many of them languishing in camps with no place to go. I believe it is our responsibility to ensure as far as we humanly can that people apply appropriatelyâand Senator McKiernan gave the example of the fellow who was able to reapply for a spouse visa. Every single one of those people who can come to Australia as a skilled migrant or on a spouse visa but chooses to apply in the refugee category and is not a genuine refugee takes the place of a person who has no homeland to go to or who is at risk of persecution or death on return to their homeland. That is the real balance.

I think any minister for immigration needs to have the wisdom of Solomonâchop the baby into 140 pieces instead of into two. In this process, where an administrative decision is made, they can appeal that administrative decision through the refugee tribunal, and if they are successful there is no fee incurred. They can then appeal to the minister. If the minister intervenes and gives them a favourable outcome, again they pay the money in return or incur no fee.

I would have to concur with Senator McKiernan that we should leave this in place to see its effect, and I am sure we will be told in no uncertain terms by the people in the industry if they believe that people who are genuine refugees are being disadvantaged or there is a disincentive for them to continue in the review process. I believe we will be told very clearly.

I have just been advised by one of the officers that a recent investigation undertaken by the principal migration officer in Manila highlights the extent of the problem. Of 1,500 applicants for spouse visas submitted since January 1998, about 300 had applied for protection while on visits to Australia. The majority had also sought review by the refugee tribunal of primary decisions and requested ministerial intervention. Ninety-seven per cent of the group admitted to making frivolous protection claims solely for the purpose of obtaining permission to work. I repeat: 97 per cent of the group admitted to making frivolous protection claims solely for the purpose of obtaining permission to work.

When I visited Hong Kong a couple of years ago, I was taken by a friend to the central square on Sunday where I saw the ayahs from the Philippines. I do not know whether Senator Harradine has been there on a Sunday. I saw maybe 8,000 to 10,000 Filipino women who were working in Hong Kong having their lunch, chatting, talking and meeting because they cannot invite anybody back to their very small room, maybe off the laundry in the facilities. When I sat on a bus with a woman who was working as an ayah at the Chinese University in Hong Kong, she said to me, `I have been here for 10 years as an ayah. I have a 14-year-old child and a 12-year-old child back in the Philippines and my husband and my parents look after them.' I realised then why some of them may want to come here and have the ability to work: some of them could earn a salary that would take years and years to earn as an ayah in Hong Kong. It is a tragedy that they are in that situation.

talk.start.para: âWhat has that got to do with it?

âThat may explain why some people will make every attempt possible to be here and will make frivolous claims. Senator Harradine asks me what is the point. Well, there are lots of points. Ninety-seven per cent of this group admitted to making frivolous protection claims solely for the purpose of obtaining permission to work. The reason they want to work is that they cannot get employment in their own countries and, if they go to other countries like Hong Kong, they earn so little, but they are prepared to leave their families, their young children, to go to work to send money back to the Philippines. The motivating factors to make a frivolous claim are so strong. I understand that. I feel terrible about it, but that is one of the reasons why. Manila is now receiving about five new cases a week under the spouse category with the same profile: people who admit that they are making frivolous claims.
âWhat has that got to do with this debate?

âI am not going to have a debate with Senator Harradine here. It is more appropriate that we have a debate outside. He has had his chance to speak. I am trying to respond to him reasonably and he is interjecting.
âNo. You have not answered the question: why not give the power to the tribunal? That is what I am saying and you have not answered that question.
âOrder! Senator Patterson has the call.

âAs I was saying, I agree with Senator McKiernan. I commend our point of view to the chamber, that the change in the regulation deserves the support of the Senate, and I ask that all senators vote against the motion.

âIn reply, I thank senators for their contribution and acknowledge, up to a point, the validity of the approach of each of the contributors, but I do disagree with some of the conclusions they have reached. A few points need to be re-emphasised. Suggesting that this $1,000 fee is not a penalty but a fee is perhaps the case in some very narrow legal sense but, like other arguments we have had in this place about the difference between a surcharge and a tax, the impact is still the same. I am not sure that it serves the debate much to try to deny that it has a penalising effect on people who are subject to the $1,000 fee. It is a bit of a spurious distinction that is being made.

speech.para: I have been surrounded by commentary from the parliamentary secretary about abuse of the systemâwidespread rorting and non-genuine claims, et cetera. This highlights the point that I want to make initially: clearly, there is an implication that a black-and-white approach is adopted to people who are not successful through the RRT. They are successful and they wear the white hats, or they are unsuccessful and they wear the black hatsâand there is no problem with such people having a $1,000 penalty, or a $1,000 fee, put upon them.

Clearly, there are people misusing the system; nobody denies that. But, equally clearly, it would be helpful if the government acknowledged just as categorically that there are many genuine people making genuine applications who are unsuccessful. This point was highlighted most clearly by the Refugee Council of Australia in their submission. I will quote from it because it puts the point particularly well and it is worth emphasising. They state:

Official statements about this abuse tend to be very black and whiteâeither a person is a Convention refugee or they are abusing the system. RCOA would argue that the reality is more complex and there are many reasons and motivations behind applications for refugee status. These include:
. people with a well founded fear of returning to their country of origin on grounds consistent with the 1951 Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees;
. people with well founded fears of returning to their country for non-Convention reasons, such as the fact that their country is in a state of civil war and they fear generalised violence;

. people with compelling family or medical (eg a condition for example, a condition for which treatment does not exist in their country) reasons to remain in Australia which properly ought to be brought to the Minister's attention;

. people who have no reason not to return other than a desire to extend their stay and who have sought advice from agents who have promised them a `work visa'. . . Commonly in such cases the applicant had no notion that this hinged on an application for a protection visa or that their conduct was in fact abusiveâ
and evidence has been provided to parliamentary committees about that practiceâ
. people wishing to extend their stay in Australia (for economic or lifestyle reasons) and who apply for a protection visa knowing full well that it is not applicable to them.

Out of all those categories, clearly only the first group has a legitimate so-called refugee based reason to apply. But it is equally legitimate that only the last group is knowingly abusing the system. People in those interim groups are people who believe they have quite genuine humanitarian reasons, as Senator Harradine outlined. They may even be aware that they are not strictly eligible for refugee status and may go through this process to request the minister to give humanitarian consideration to their case.

It is also important to emphasise the evidence provided by people in the community about people who have been poorly or improperly advised by migration agentsânot even necessarily migration agents but people who are not qualified to give advice but who provide them with that adviceâand who act upon that in good faith. That clearly occurs in some circumstances. Evidence was given of people turning up to the refugee tribunal not even being aware until they had got there that what they had applied for was a protection visa. They thought that they had applied for a work visa, because that was what they had been advised. Those sorts of instances need to be acknowledged, and innocent people should not be penalised because of that situation.

It is worth emphasising again that this $1,000 fee was just one of a number of measures designed to stop abuse. I believe a number of those, and particularly the one in relation to people seeking to apply for a protection visa solely so they can work, were addressed by some of the regulations that were brought into place at the same time as this one. Whilst I have concerns about that as well in terms of it impacting on genuine asylum seekers, that would be far more effective in providing a disincentive for people who are deliberately abusing the system.

The fundamental point here is that it seems to me a bit incongruous for such a strong argument to be put forward by the government that this fee is providing a clear disincentive for non-genuine applicants and yet that it is somehow not providing a disincentive for genuine applicants, particularly those who may know they are not necessarily refugees in the strict sense of the word but are going through the channels they have to go through to access the minister's humanitarian consideration, something that has to be a bit of a lotteryâand that is not meant to impugn the minister's motives at all.

It is hard enough to be sure about your chances when you are going through a normal legal process and you have people looking at the legislation and giving you legal opinions. When you have something that is a non-compellable, non-reviewable discretionary power of the minister based on humanitarian considerationsâand I know there are guidelines in relation to thoseâyour chances of predicting your success are much lower than in any normal legal process. Yet people have to go through this channel and have to put themselves at the risk of being subjected to this $1,000 fee to get humanitarian consideration. That, to me, seems to be a significant flaw. To suggest that somehow the risk of a $1,000 fee is a clear disincentive for non-genuine people yet is no disincentive at all for genuine applicants who have no way of knowing whether they going to be successful is a pretty hard argument to follow.

I emphasise again that the Democrats and I believe that when you have issues that have to be weighed upâsuch as the issue of abuse of the system versus ensuring that genuine applicants do not get disadvantagedâyou have to put a very strong emphasis on the human rights obligations of ensuring that disadvantaged people are not further disadvantaged and are not subject to more disincentives or hardship. When you are looking at balancing those arguments, from the Democrats' point of view you have to come down on the side of human rights. I believe you have to come down on ensuring that the department has to prove that there is no hardship rather than the community or others having to prove the contrary. That is a crucial point in terms of how we should approach these issues.

Unfortunately, the disallowance motion is not going to be successful. Despite what I believe are my very telling points, I suspect I am not going to sway the Senate at this late stage, so I will not continue. Another sunset clause will now operate with this regulation. There will be a review, and I will certainly be watching that closely. We may even be revisiting this debate in a couple of years time. One hopes that it is conducted by the Joint Standing Committee on Migration, a committee that I find operates very constructively with difficult issues and works hard to get a consensus approach. I hope some of the arguments that I put forward today get greater acceptance in the committee next time we are reviewing this matter.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Bartlett's ) be agreed to.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 28 June, on motion by Senator Ian Campbell:
That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: âI rise to speak on the Aged Care Amendment (Omnibus) Bill 1999 , which seeks to make a number of amendments to the Aged Care Act 1997. The most significant of these is the inclusion of accommodation charges in the act. We all remember the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, appearing on A Current Affair to announce the backdown on the government's aged care policy, but we are only now seeing the legislation to implement that backdown.

speech.para: Until now the accommodation charges he announced have been implemented through subordinate legislation, without the proper scrutiny of parliament. We are now also told that, because of his ad hoc arrangements, residents paying the charge have been denied basic protections. Labor opposed the introduction of the accommodation charge. We had very serious concerns about the equity of requiring pensioners to pay thousands of dollars a year for nursing home care. Those concerns remain. However, as those charges have been implemented, we support any move to introduce better protection measures for residents paying the $12 a day fee. We do have serious concerns that the protections introduced in this bill do not go far enough, and we will be moving amendments to increase residents' rights in relation to accommodation, bonds and charges. The government abrogated its responsibility two years ago by introducing the charges without those protections.

The bill makes a number of technical amendments to address problems with the act, which include providing for the refund of accommodation charges to residents who were in homes prior to October 1997âhonoured only after Labor pressured the government to fulfil its commitments to those residentsâensuring that people were not liable for fees and charges before they have even agreed to move into a facility, clarifying the situation where a person admitted to a facility has a mental impairment, formalising reduced qualifying periods for co-residents, and broadening the definition of `family'. Labor supports all of these amendments. They are a belated attempt to fix up some of the problems with the Aged Care Actâproblems that the government has been aware of for more than 18 months now.

Unfortunately for older Australians, while the bill does fix up some of the many technical problems associated with the government's Aged Care Act, many significant problems with the act are not addressed by this bill and will remain. These problems include: difficulties with the government's income tested fee, which has caused significant distress to older Australians and their families and is forcing providers to divert resources away from the care of residents; problems over the use of capital funding in the sector; an inability to appropriately deal with poor providers, including the closure of poor providers and provisions for the investigation of residents' complaints; significant difficulties being experienced by providers with the government's new resident classification scale; difficulties in accessing aged care, as the ratio of places to people aged 70 and over has declined over the last three years and waiting times have increased; a blow-out in the budget for aged care, which has occurred alongside the reduced access because of the government's misdirection of taxpayers' dollars; the continued implementation of the government's coalescence policy, which has been described by the Productivity Commission as inappropriate and inequitable; and providers in some states facing very serious problems arising from workers compensation premium increases without any support from the government, which is resulting in a reduction in the quality of care to residents.

These and a number of other problems have emerged as a result of the failure of the government's aged care reforms. The hasty changes introduced in fright in 1997 are now falling apart. They have reduced access to residential aged care, and they have forced providers to compromise on the quality of care delivered to residents. They are failed reforms. These problems are causing distress to older Australians and their families and, in some cases, are forcing providers to reduce the quality of care delivered to residents. What is inexcusable is that the government has known about these problems for some time, yet it has done nothing to address them.

The two peak provider organisations in the sector have raised serious concerns about the minister's inaction in relation to the issues confronting the industry. A recent journal included a headline article from the chief executive officer of one of those organisations, entitled `Government inactivity', that indicated that `issues currently affecting the operation of the aged care facilities are reaching crisis point.' Uniting Community Services has also stated that the minister's inaction in relation to the comprehensive Productivity Commission report into the nursing home sector is a time bomb and that older Australians deserve better.

This bill provided the government with the perfect opportunity to respond to the concerns of residents and their families and to providers and employees in the aged care sector, yet it has merely sought to recycle an 18-month-old bill that does nothing to fix the many problems that have emerged over the last 18 months. Because of the government's inaction, Labor will move amendments to the bill to attempt to address some of the issues facing this sector as a result of the failure of the aged care reforms.

The only reason we are debating this bill today is that Labor put pressure on the government to meet its commitment to residents in nursing homes before 1 October 1997. These residents were promised by the Prime Minister that they would not have to pay the $12 a day accommodation charge, but nothing was done to implement that promise. It was only after pressure from the Labor opposition and questions in the parliament in April that Senator Herron finally committed the government to meeting those commitments to those residents in the 1999-2000 budget.

One and a half years after the government introduced its aged care reforms, the government finally undertook to honour its commitments to them. Unfortunately, many of those residents have since passed away. Because of the government's reluctance to implement its commitments, not one of them has received any refund of the potential millions of dollars they have paid in total in accommodation chargesâcharges that they should never have paid.

Almost two years after the reforms were introduced, these residents are still required to pay the $12 a day charge. They are still facing financial pressureâpressure to sell their homes and somehow come up with the $12 a day charge when the government has promised they would not have to pay the charge. This is a tragic situation caused by the government's reluctance to act. These residents rightly feel cheated by the government, and the government failed to respond by introducing this bill until June 1999. This, of course, is consistent with its reluctance to debate aged care. The government seems desperate to keep aged care off the political agenda, given the history of losing two ministers in trying to implement these reforms.

I have raised the government's inaction in relation to aged care on a number of occasions in the past. The history of this government's failure in aged care was discussed broadly in the house when this bill was debated in June, and I will not seek to repeat some of that debate today. But the earlier bill that the government introduced was then withdrawn by it. Knowing the problems being experienced by residents and providers, the government chose to drop the bill that sought to fix some of the problems. Facing an election, the government put its own political interests ahead of the interests of aged care residents. Eighteen months later, under pressure from Labor, the government finally sought to introduce legislation when it took the opportunity to recycle the 1998 bill.

The provisions to provide for the refund of accommodation charges to pre-October 1997 residents, inserted at our insistence, are the only major changes to the bill tabled in March last year. Given the history of inaction, it is not surprising that the minister has failed to address a number of significant problems within the Aged Care Act that have become apparent over the last 18 months. In the context of this bill, I will be highlighting just three of the problems now facing the aged care sector: the income tested fee, capital funding and how we deal with poor providers.

In terms of the income tested fee, there have been numerous reports in the media recently about the problems with the government's income tested fee. We have heard that aged care residents are receiving a series of letters from the department, sometimes within a matter of days, each indicating a different level of fee. In one case the department sent three letters to a resident in two days, advising of three different levels of fee. Understandably, residents are confused and upset by this inconsistent advice. Residents, many of whom are pensioners, are rightly distressed when they are then hit with bills for thousands of dollars as a result of the department's confusion.

At the same time, providers are complaining about the complexity of the fee which is requiring more and more staff resources to administer. This means more staff filling in forms and less time caring for residents. These problems flow from the government's bungled implementation of the fee, which was criticised in the recent Audit Office report. That report identifies significant problems with the fee's implementation and ongoing complexity in its administration.

In the face of all these problems, it is not surprising that we have also been getting reports that the department is advising people to divorce to avoid the income tested fee. You know a system has failed when the department's officers advise people to divorce to avoid it. These problems were raised by the sector with the government over a year ago, yet the minister has done nothing to relieve the distress of residents and their relatives. She did not take the opportunity provided by this bill to address those problems. It is just not good enough. Residents continue to receive confusing advice and continue to be upset by large bills for backdated fees that they did not even know they had to pay. Labor calls on the government to urgently introduce legislation to resolve the many problems with the income tested fee and thereby relieve the distress of residents and their families.

I turn to the question of capital funding. A few weeks ago I mentioned an example which graphically demonstrates the failure of the government's arrangements to fund capital improvements in the residential aged care sector. A Victorian nursing home provider closed his facility after it appeared he did little or nothing to improve the infrastructure of the facility. Residents at the nursing home had been paying the government's $12 a day accommodation charge. The Commonwealth had been paying on behalf of other residents the equivalent through the concessional resident supplement.

In total up to $200,000 could have been paid to the provider to fix up the nursing home, yet he was under no obligation to spend any of that money on capital works, and it appeared that he did not do so. Instead he chose to leave the industry and pocket the funds. The minister cannot guarantee residents or taxpayers that one dollar of the $200,000 was actually spent on improving the nursing home.

Unfortunately, this is not an isolated case. In Victoria, in particular, there have been a number of recent instances where aged care facilities have closed their doors. In all these recent cases, the provider has been under no obligation to spend the funds collected from residents through an accommodation bond or charge on capital improvements. In all cases, the provider has been under no obligation to spend taxpayers' money collected through the concessional resident supplement on capital improvements. In all cases, the provider can simply pocket the money and walk away with hundreds of thousands of dollars. This bill does nothing to prevent that circumstance recurring.

While the providers who close down their facilities in these circumstances are few and represent the small minority of irresponsible providers in the system, there are other providers who are using the funds raised through the accommodation bonds and charges to cover ongoing costs. Under the current system, they are perfectly entitled to do so. These providers have the interests of residents at heart and are compensating for a lack of recurrent funding by dipping into their capital funding stream. Unfortunately for the provider, this has long-term consequences as these providers will have little or no means of refurbishing their facilities in five or 10 years time.

The current system is disguising the crisis in ongoing funding that many providers are facingâa crisis that the Productivity Commission identified in its recent report into nursing home funding. Some providers are sacrificing future capital reserves to meet current costs. Accommodation charges were introduced to fund capital improvements. We do the residents, the providers or the taxpayers no favours by refusing to quarantine those funds. I think this highlights a significant failing of the current Aged Care Act.

The funds collected from residents are not quarantined specifically for capital improvements. Attempts were made by both Labor and the Democrats at the time the act was passed to tighten accountability for the use of these funds. However, they were resisted by the government and the current arrangements have proved to be ineffective. At the time Labor raised the very possibility of the situa tion that has unfolded with providers simply incorporating the capital funds into their daily budgets. The minister has proudly produced graphs showing the amounts the new user-pays fees raise and claims that this will meet the capital needs of the sector, but she cannot guarantee that one dollar of that money is actually spent on capital improvements.

Nursing home residents have been told they must find $12 a day to fund the capital development of the aged care sector when many of them simply cannot afford it, and the government has not put any accountability arrangements in place to ensure that the money is directed to improving their accommodation. It must be remembered that accommodation bonds and charges are only half the picture. We know that 47 per cent of residents are not paying any accommodation bond or charge. In this case the Commonwealth pays the provider $12.34 a day through the concessional resident supplement. There is no provision in the current Aged Care Act that defines what that money should be used for. Providers are able to simply pocket that money. This year the Commonwealth will spend $142 million on the concessional supplement, next year it will be $169 million and the year after that $181 million, yet we have put no conditions on how that money should be used. Given that the concessional resident supplement is paid when the resident cannot afford an accommodation bond or charge, the clear intention is that the supplement be used for capital improvement. The Aged Care Act does not reflect that intention. We will move amendments to try to ensure that funds raised from residents through their accommodation bonds and charges are used for capital improvements and that taxpayers' dollars spent on the concessional resident supplement are similarly used for that purpose.

Where a provider closes a facility, forcing residents to relocate to other facilities, the provider will have to ensure that the money is used for those purposes or refund it to taxpayers and residents if it has not been used on capital improvements. A provider should not be allowed to accumulate these funds, knowing that they will close down, do no capital improvements and simply walk away with the money. That is a very real issue as accreditation approaches. The current arrangements encourage providers in this situation to do no capital improvement. Our amendments will require providers to refund any moneys collected through the accommodation bonds or charges or the concessional resident supplement when that money has not been or will not be spent on capital improvements. If a resident pays $12 a day to the provider for that purpose and the provider chooses not to spend that money on improving the facility, the resident is entitled to a refund of the money.

The recent cases in Victoria also highlight another significant problem in the government's Aged Care Actâhow to deal with poor providers. The department have indicated to me that there are a small number of providers that they would like to close down but cannot because of difficulties with the act. As a result, the government is now proposing an amendment that will allow for the gradual wind-down of a facility when it wants to revoke a provider's approval to operate. While I can understand the rationale for this amendment, it raises significant issues over the care of residents in a facility that is being wound down and poses real risks to their health. These residents will potentially be left for an extended period in a facility that has been assessed as not providing an adequate level of care. Given the shortage of alternative places in some areas, the resident may have to wait for months as the facility is gradually wound down. In this situation, there is a clear need to ensure that these residents are being appropriately cared for. We should not set up a situation where we leave residents in a facility under the control of a provider who is known to have acted irresponsibly in failing to provide appropriate care to residents.

The problem will only get worse as the January 2001 accreditation deadline approaches and some providers make a decision to leave the industry and make as much money as they can in the process. They will be looking to cut staff hours and reduce the level of care provided to residents. They will be looking to cut back on the quality of food and generally looking to save costs. It has to be remembered that residents are potentially in a very vulnerable position. Some of them may have no relatives within the area to regularly visit them, some may be suffering dementia, all of them are physically frail. I find it appalling that the government is now proposing an amendment to allow a known poor provider to continue to operate for six or 12 months, while the facility is gradually wound down, without providing extensive additional protections for the residents. The provider knows they are being closed down and therefore has every reason to try to extract the most money they can from the facility in the time remaining, which means reducing the quality of care to an intolerable minimum. I have serious concerns about the provisions in the act in relation to the investigation of complaints. Many people have noted the current provisions do not ensure that complaints are promptly and thoroughly investigated. To rely on these provisions in the case where a known poor provider is allowed to continue to operate a facility is inviting disaster. The Labor opposition will move amendments to ensure that the care of residents in this situation is monitored by a departmental officer who will report directly to the minister.

We will also move amendments that seek to protect the interests of employees when a nursing home is closing down. We know of a number of instances where staff have been left owed large amounts of moneyâtermination and leave payâby providers exiting the industry without meeting their obligations. The department has the ability to prevent the sale of the licence if those debts are not met, and we think it is an important reform to provide for those employees. The government has accepted the need to protect employees in these situations in other industries, and we think it should accept its responsibilities in the nursing home industry as well.

I look forward to contributing in the committee stage of the debate to this important legislation. We have tried to highlight that we do not think this legislation goes far enough as a legislative response to the problems confronting aged care. Many of the problems have not been addressed. We think the government should have a much more comprehensive response to the issues confronting the industry. We will attempt at the committee stage to deal with some of those, but we really do require a more comprehensive legislative response, and we require a government commitment to address the issues in the industry rather than delay, defer and hope that somehow they will go away. There are real problems that need to be addressed, and I urge the government to start being accountable and to start addressing those concerns of the industry.

talk.start.para: âThe Aged Care Amendment (Omnibus) Bill 1999 , which we are considering today, introduces a number of amendments to the Aged Care Act 1997 and the Aged Care (Consequential Provisions) Act 1997 to finetune the aged care structural reforms which were introduced in October 1997. In addition, it addresses some administrative and procedural issues which have become evident since that time. It also introduces a number of protection measures for older Australians living in residential aged care facilities, which the Democrats particularly welcome. We are happy to support this bill today.

speech.para: Since the government first announced its sweeping reforms of the funding and operation of residential aged care facilities in 1996, the Democrats have worked very hard to improve the government's policy reform package. Our goal has always been to ensure that the final package was one which would ensure that the needs of those requiring residential aged care both now and in the future would be met. What we have always wanted is a system which is sustainable while offering high quality care to all Australians, regardless of their capacity to pay.

In determining our position in the aged care debate since 1996 we have carefully weighed up each proposal against its likely impact on the ability of elderly Australians to access high quality residential care and the long-term financial viability of the residential aged care sector. The Democrats gave qualified support to the government's initial aged care reform package, because we understood the urgent need to inject funding for capital maintenance and improvements into residential aged care facilities. We negotiated a number of improvements to the original proposal, including an additional $40 million in subsidies for concessional residents. We wanted to ensure that all Australians could continue to access high quality residential aged care, regardless of their ability to pay for it.

Recently, the Democrats also played a crucial role in paving the way for the introduction of an accreditation system for residential aged care facilities, which was proposed as part of the government's 1996 aged care reform package, with funding for all non-accredited aged care facilities to cease from 1 January 2001. While the majority of aged care providers supported an accreditation process, the details of the legislation were not agreed to until the Democrats brokered a roundtable discussion between providers and the minister. As a result of this meeting, the minister has agreed to address the major concerns of the aged care sector, including making a commitment that residential aged care facilities with up to 19 beds will pay no fee for accreditation, and those with 20 to 25 beds will pay only a tapered fee on an ongoing basis.

The Democrats are proud to have been able to play a central role in resolving the impasse between the government and the aged care providers over the accreditation process for aged care facilities. I believe the introduction of accreditation will be a big step forward for those needing residential aged care. It should lead to continuous improvements in the industry and ultimately a higher standard of care and facilities for older Australians.

On reading the House of Representatives Hansard, I notice that the opposition have used the debate surrounding this bill as yet another excuse to beat up the government on aged care. No doubt, they will turn their attack on the Democrats in the Senate as well. Before the senators in the ALP start with the kind of tiresome rhetoric and half-truths we have heard time and time again, let me just take the opportunity today to remind them that the ALP had 13 years in government to address the problems in aged care, and they did not.

The ALP did virtually nothing, despite the findings of the Gregory report, which was commissioned by the Keating government. The ALP did nothing, despite the fact that its own independent report estimated that approximately $1 billion in today's figures was needed just to get the existing nursing home stock up to scratch. Let us not forget that, when it comes to aged care, the opposition has a very poor record indeed. In fact, it has failed dismally.

Let us also not forget that, going into the last election, the only promise the ALP could come up with in relation to aged care was to abolish all nursing home fees and replace them with $500 million of public money to be paid to the sector over three years. I invite ALP senators here tonight to explain to us exactly how this $500 million was going to meet the current and ongoing funding needs of the aged care sector. In fact, I challenge the opposition to change their approach when it comes to aged care. Perhaps just for this bill, rather than resorting to rhetoric and half-truths to bag everything and everyone on what they have tried to do, why not try something different? Why not use this as an opportunity to tell the rest of us what the ALP aged care policies would be if they were in government?

Before the government gets too complacent from all of this criticism of the opposition's approach to aged care, let me take a few minutes to draw attention to one particular shortfall of the government, and that is the government's lack of response to the findings of the Productivity Commission's report into nursing home subsidies. Despite receiving in January of this year the Productivity Commission's findings that the government's funding index in relation to nursing home subsidies is wrong, the government has failed to give any indication as to when it will respond. We find that unacceptable.

Here, yet again, we have an example of a government setting up its own objective independent body to look into what is to be done in the area of aged care, only to ignore its findings. The whole point of this inquiry was to determine whether the proposed coalescence of nursing home subsidies should proceed or be replaced by another funding methodology. The Productivity Commission did not endorse the government's coalescence proposal. Despite this, in setting nursing home subsidy rates from 1 July this year, the government went ahead with its proposal anyway.

The Democrats call on the government to end the current angst in the aged care sector in relation to this matter today by making it very clear exactly when and how the findings of this report will be responded to. It is worth noting that the findings and recommendations of this Productivity Commission inquiry have wide industry support. The Democrats will continue to work with all of those involved in the aged care sectorâboth providers and those who represent the consumers of aged careâto achieve an improved level of care for the residents of aged care facilities. As the measures contained in this bill today are supported by all of those involved in the industry, we are happy to support them today too.

The ALP have a series of amendments to this legislation. While the Democrats have some sympathy with the sentiment which obviously lies behind some of those changes, we will not be able to support them, because neither we nor the industry saw them until just a short time ago. As a result, there has been inadequate time for meaningful consultation. Indeed, those whom I have spoken with in the industry have said that they have not had a chance to look at them or consider them in any depth. In fact, they urged us to reject the amendments and not delay the bill.

We will be seeking clarification from the government on some of the issues raised by the ALP's amendments. However, I say to the opposition that they do themselves absolutely no favours when they hand complicated amendments to usâand to the industryâat the last minute. It leaves the Democrats with no choice but to vote against them, because it would be completely irresponsible for us to support changes which may bring with them negative unintended consequences which nobody has had time to consider.

talk.start.para: âI rise to speak on the Aged Care Amendment (Omnibus) Bill 1999 . I wonder if the government have heard of the International Federation of Ageing and their Declaration on the Rights and Responsibilities of Older Persons. As Ageing International reveals on, page 15 of their fall edition, these include:

speech.para: 12. To obtain health care in order to maintain or regain the optimum level of physical, mental and emotional well being and to prevent or delay the onset of illness.
13. To access social and legal services to enhance capacity for autonomy and provide protection and care.
14. To utilise appropriate levels of institutional care which provide protection, rehabilitation and social and mental stimulation in a humane and secure environment.

15. To exercise human rights and fundamental freedoms when residing in any shelter, care and treatment facility, including full respect for their dignity, beliefs, needs and privacy and for the right to make decisions about their care and quality of life.

One could rightly assume that the government are not listening to the voices of elderly Tasmanians or to the International Federation of Ageing, as a lack of funding in public health and legal aid means that preventable health and legal representation on civil matters are achievable only by the wealthy. Or are they punishing the elderly in Tasmania for the last election result? Nothing else could explain the callous indifference the government is showing to the elderly in need of residential care in my state.

This bill represents inertia on the government's behalf as, after 18 months of representations made, reports given and letters written, it seems that little is getting through. I know numerous letters have been written by Aged Care Tasmania Incorporated outlining the undue pressure any cuts in funding would mean to the Tasmanian aged care industry and, importantly, to those they serve so well.

Reducing the funding to the elderly that need care is not like targeting those on unemployment benefits or other easy targets that make up the daily feeding frenzy on talkback radio. They cannot be labelled as unworthy of assistance or as somehow undeserving. Yet, apart from the minor cosmetic changes, this bill delivers little and, in the case of elderly Tasmanians, does nothing to address the problems raised over the last 1Â½ years.

This bill had a quasi launch on 5 March 1998, when it was tabled as the Aged Care Amendment Bill 1998. The Aged Care Amendment (Omnibus) Bill 1999 that is now being discussed is the old bill with a couple of crisis measures thrown inâand that is about it. What caused the crisis measures, the add-ons, to the original? Was it a result of well set out, planned policy objectivesâother than the reduction of $500 million from the sector in 1996-97? The crisis measures were directly related to the government's own `reforms'âa word they use, but I would notâin slash and burn policies that typify this government.

Remember when they wanted to take the family home and then quickly gave it back? Some people were badly hurt by that. This bill partly compensates them with ex gratia payments. It also seeks to stop those that had to pay for not being there. Confusing, yes, but as a direct result of these glorious reforms the elderly had to pay fees for a service they had not received. The complete stupidity of this oversight is a common occurrence in the government's policies. We get used to it, but the frail and elderly should never have to.

This policy also fixes another huge oversight in previous reforms. Currently the government is unable to act on a fraudulent provider without closing the service. These fraudulent providers are currently still operating as, due to the government's ineptness, shonky operators are still running some of the homes.

âI move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the document.

I would like to make some comments about the Airservices Australia corporate plan document dated July 1998 to June 2003. I and a number of others, both in this place and in the other place, have been critical of the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, Mr Anderson, and before him Mr Vaile, for their failure to properly deal with a number of important transport matters. There is plenty of evidence to draw on to support that charge.

A report of the House of Representatives entitled Planning not patching, by the Communications, Transport and Microeconomic Reform Standing Committee, was tabled in November 1997. We are, as yet, to get a government response to that report. We have still not received a response from Mr Anderson to the Tracking Australia report from the same committee. It was tabled in August of last year. The Revitalisation rail report of the rail projects task force was released in April this year, but we have heard nothing yet from Mr Anderson. A key report from the shipping reform working group was completed in April of this year and provided to Mr Anderson. It still sits on his desk. The Hawke review on air safety responsibilities was completed in December of last yearâon timeâbut we have heard nothing.

We are now told that a final BASI report on the class G airspace trial will not be released until the end of the year. The draft was circulated to interested parties for comment ages ago. These are all very important reports that are of vital interest to key transport sectors in this country, but they have all been simply put to one side, just as the interests of rail, sea and air transport in this country have been put to one side by Mr Anderson.

While we on this side of the chamber are expected to argue publicly on behalf of these key sectors of the economy, it is not often that the chair of a public authority openly and stridently criticises his own minister. Things are clearly very bad when that happens. But that is what I discovered when I read the covering letter to the report we are now considering. Firstly, I draw the attention of the Senate to the date of that letter. It was dated 11 February 1999. One could be forgiven for thinking that this report has been sitting somewhere on Minister Anderson's desk waiting for clearance for eight months. Perhaps he could not find it under the other reports.

In his letter that commences the report, Mr Forsyth says that the corporate plan was originally submitted in May last year. After all, the plan does cover the period commencing June 1998, and today's date is 22 September 1999. So it seems that Airservices clearly met its deadline. Mr Forsyth advised Mr Anderson that the original plan had to be withdrawn because it could not reflect the Department of Transport's structural review. That review was completed and provided to the former minister in March 1998. The department met its deadline with the Airservices review, and so I assume that that report just sat around in Mr Vaile's office and then Mr Anderson's office.
Despite so much time passing, because the report is now more than a year late, Mr Forsyth was forced to tell Mr Anderson that it was still incomplete. Mr Forsyth states:
As you are aware, Airservices is in a state of flux because of the government's indecision on some of the planned reforms.

I must say that that was an extraordinary statement for a chair to make in a report to his minister, a report that he knows will be tabled in parliament. It is a statement usually saved for the privacy of a ministerial office.

The fact that Mr Forsyth has reached such a level of frustration gives an insight into the level of frustration the rest of the transport sector in this country is feeling with this minister and this government. Later in the same letter Mr Forsyth tells the minister:
If the government does not deliver on these aspectsâ
and I interpose here that he is referring to the structural reformsâ
momentum will be lost and the reforms will fail. The financial consequences of such a failure will be significant.
It is clear that the desire of the Airservices chairman is for the organisation to be privatised. That would be the view of the government too, if it thought that it could get away with suchâ

âI seek leave to continue my remarks.

interjection.para: Leave not granted.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: âI was not intending to speak on this report. The report, to a degree, speaks for itself. But some of the things that the previous speaker has mentioned were so outrageous as to require some comment. Of course, Mr Anderson is one of the most efficient ministers of a very large number of very efficient ministers in the government. The work that he does in all aspects of transport is enormous. It is a very complex portfolio and, of course, Mr Anderson has a range of matters to deal with, particularly now with his role as Deputy Prime Minister. But he can be well proud of the work that he has done in the transport area.

speech.para: Rail reform has gone ahead in leaps and bounds since this government took over. The previous government, the Labor Party government, spoke for 13 years about the things they were intending to do, but of course they never got around to doing anything. Roads, under the Labor regime, went backwards; the disastrous state that many of the roads are in around Australia is the result of something that grew up in the 13 sad years that Labor was in power. In aviation, Mr Anderson has introduced a number of initiatives. He has had a number of very difficult problems to look at, not the least of which being the second Sydney airport, an issue that the Labor Party were never quite able to deal with in the 13 years that they were in government. They kept putting it off and putting it off. Senator O'Brien would well know about those things.

Mr Anderson has perhaps not received the credit he should have for the tremendous job that he did to help reduce transport costs to rural and regional Australia. This came about as a result of the tax reform package, which the Labor Party opposedâa package that was going to reduce substantially the cost of transport for those of us who live in the country.

talk.start.para: âI rise on a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. I know that the hour is late and that the minister has felt that he has had to come to the defence of this embattled minister; but the issue here is that we are discussing the Airservices Australia corporate plan for July 1998 to 2003. The minister is now starting to talk about the GST and the tax package and its effect on rural Australia, and I really think that that is a very long way from the document that is supposed to be under discussion.
âIf I may speak on the point of order, I am actually responding to the previous speaker who was speaking on this report, and I assume that he must have been speaking along the correct lines.
âI rule that the minister is in order.

âThe strength of my argument in opposing the point of order was obviously well known to you before I mentioned the words. In response to what Senator O'Brien was saying in suggesting that Mr Anderson was not doing his jobâand he went on with a long list of complaints about Mr AndersonâI point out that Mr Anderson is doing a great job in air services as well as in all other areas of the portfolio.

speech.para: One of the reasons I say Mr Anderson is doing such a good job is the tremendous work he did in getting the tax reform package back on track when the Labor Party opposed it. The Labor Party opposed the proposal we put forward to bring cheaper and better transport to rural and regional Australia, whether it be rail, road or air transport. As a result of their opposition, Mr Anderson has had to spend an enormous amount of time getting a new package together which has, in the end, provided a tremendous outcome for the people of rural and regional Australia. In so many ways, Mr Anderson has done a remarkable job as the Minister for Transport and Regional Services. The good things happening in aviation now and the good things that will occur in times to come are as a significant result of the work done by Mr Anderson.
