interjection.para: That the Senate do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: âTonight I wish to refer to the operations of the EPAS Fundâthat is, the Employees Productive Award Superannuation Fund. The previous Labor government developed a retirement incomes policy to address the problems arising from an ageing population, caused primarily by the baby boom generation moving into the age pension age over the next couple of decades. The superannuation guarantee was central to that policy and the 1992 superannuation guarantee charge legislation has seen all employers contribute the superannuation guarantee to registered superannuation funds on behalf of employees since that time.

speech.para: The charge commenced at three per cent of an employee's pay and has steadily risen to seven per cent today. Award superannuation has also played a significant part in employee savings and, together with the superannuation guarantee, cemented the need for supervision and regulation of the superannuation industry. The Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993, sometimes referred to as the SI(S) Act, substantially increases the level of prudential protection provided to the superannuation industry and represents a substantial strengthening of the security of superannuation savings and the protection of the rights of superannuation fund members.

Since 1 July 1998, APRAâthe Australian Prudential Regulation Authorityâis the Commonwealth agency which is now responsible for prudential regulation of banks, life insurance companies, general insurance companies and superannuation funds, having taken over the functions from the previous Insurance and Superannuation Commission, ISC, for insurance and superannuation, and from the Reserve Bank of Australia for banks. In the case of superannuation funds, the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority aims to ensure that the trustees are aware of their obligations to members and manage the funds in their care prudently in the interests of members. A great responsibility is put on trustees.

I am going to outline tonight that in this particular case the trustees have not acted prudently. APRA does not guarantee the performance of financial institutions but has the power to require them to observe prudential standards and to intercede if it believes the interests of depositors, policy holders or members are at risk. They look at approved deeds and the performance of funds. I am afraid they slipped in this particular case.

Consumer issues, however, such as the information or advice provided about financial products or the resolution of consumer complaints about financial services or charges, are primarily the responsibility of the Australian Securities and Investment Commission, ASIC. Where their responsibilities overlap, APRA cooperates particularly closely with ASIC.

When trustees of superannuation funds invest members' money there should be at least three major objectives. They are: to achieve above average investment performance with an acceptable level of risk; to gain results which compare more favourably than those available on deposit; and to increase the value of member's contributions by achieving a rate of interest, over the long term, exceeding the rate of inflation.

The investment strategy must therefore be based on these objectives. In choosing a range of asset classes, a trustee or trustees should have regard to the advice of professional investment advisers. To keep the fluctuations in any one market to a minimum, the asset classes, for example, could include a mix of cash on deposit, bonds, property and shares. Investing through a range of managers also helps to reduce the risk of fluctuations even further.

You can imagine my absolute despair when I was made aware recently of problems with the EPAS Fundâthe Employees Productive Award Superannuation Fundâan industry fund used by employers in the accommodation industry. When we go to the 1998 annual return, it declared a negative return of 43 per cent. A statement dated 30 December 1998 was mailed to members stating that a negative crediting rate of 43 per cent had been applied to all their contributions, effectively cutting their earnings or their hard earned savings in half. Naturally, this raised concerns from members.

The fund owner, Mr Terry James, had been trustee and chairman until his resignation in October 1998. Investigations reveal that on 1 July 1996 APRA, concerned the fund was too heavily committed in property investment, directed the appointment of Mr Gerald Parker as trustee in order to diversify funds invested. It appears there were at least 20 interrelated companies with directors common to many companies. So the question really does have to be asked: why did APRA approve such an arrangement of 20 interrelated companies? This is just not good enough. This is not good oversight by APRA and it is not good oversight by the trustees in the discharge of their responsibilities to the members.

But worse, members' inquiries to EPAS Ltd are answered with the words, `This is commercially privileged information,' and very little useful information is forthcoming. On 29 July 1998 Gerald Parker notified members that EPAS Ltd now had four trustee directors, bringing diverse experience to the board. Too little too late. On the same day in a notice to all members issued by EPAS Ltd as trustee, the question was asked, `Why did the fund have so much invested in property?' The answer was:

The history of the EPAS Fund saw the Fund invest in loans. Mostly these loans were secured by mortgages over property. In a move to increase the performance of EPAS for its members, the present Trustee Directors, demanded that the loans be repaid.
A fair enough action. It continued:
Those borrowers who defaulted on their EPAS loans have been taken over and either sold or retained ready for prudent sale.

A major problem was the purchase and refurbishment of O'Hara's Resort Hotel in Launceston, Tasmania. It alone accounts for $7 million of members' moneys. On top of the substantial property asset losses, EPAS also reported a loss of $918,000 in share dealings in 1998. I remind honourable senators this was at a time of strong share growth.

Who is responsible for this total mismanagement of the members' funds? Clearly, I point the finger at the trustees, because trustees have greater liabilities than directors of corporate companies. They have their personal assets at stake. I think it is time that delinquent trustees are made an example of by the authorities. Why hasn't APRA taken action against these delinquent or former trustees to show the need for separate and prudent management of super funds? The blame rests principally on the trustees. I believe they are liable and they should be sued. The question on everybody's lips is: why hasn't APRA taken a more punitive action when clearly it has such powers and when clearly the former directors were so delinquent in the discharge of their responsibilities?

A central principle of the SIS legislation is that trustees are primarily responsible for the viability and prudent operation of superannuation funds. The SI'S legislation imposes fiduciary duties on trustees to act in the best interest of the members. The EPAS Fund, with 12,000 members, should never have been directly investing in property assets and resorts and had such arrangements with 20 other operations with common directors.

The 1998 accounts show an amount of $4,254 directed to `trustees indemnity insurance'. So the trustees have some sort of money they can call upon if they are sued. Why haven't they been sued? Where is APRA in relation to this particular amount? It is doubtful of course that any insurance claim could completely recoup all the money these members have lost, but at least they should be trying.

With award superannuation and superannuation guarantee, many people do not think about the amount of money their employers contribute on their behalf to a superannuation fund. If they do, rarely do they wonder if the money is safe. It is up to this Senate and the regulating authorities to ensure that the money is safe. The disaster is horrifying for every member who stands to lose money. Both APRA and ASIC, with the APRA appointed trustee, are working together to review an untenable situation. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Local Government: New South Wales Elections

talk.start.para: âI rise this evening to comment on the recent local government elections in New South Wales. Whilst I am delighted to be able to report to this chamber that Labor enjoyed electoral success right across New South Wales, I also wish to turn my attention to some of the unscrupulous tactics employed throughout this campaign by various players within the New South Wales division of the Liberal Partyâthose geniuses whom I have had occasion to disparage in this place on a number of earlier occasions.

speech.para: Whilst there have been some very highly publicised examples of the New South Wales Liberal Party's underhanded approach in these electionsâsuch as the sordid Frank Sartor affairâI wish to concentrate on a few less publicised but equally grubby strategies that were employed in the recent round of local government elections. In particular, I wish to bring to the attention of this chamber a number of duplicitous and deceitful tactics employed in the Penrith City local government elections. I specifically want to raise some questions about the apparent role of the office of the member for Lindsay, the Hon. Jackie Kelly, the Minister for Sport and Tourism, in the running of this very grubby and cynical election campaign.

This election was characterised by a particularly high number of micro parties standing for election. This was particularly the case in the city's East Ward, where I happen to live. For reasons that will become a little clearer in a few moments, it is worth pointing out that the Liberal Party's No. 1 candidate was a Mr Steve Simat. It is also worth noting that Mr Simat is currently employed on the member for Lindsay's staff, a point that Mr Simat was at pains to make at every opportunity during the election campaign. It is also significant to note that Mr Simat's running mate at No. 2 on the Liberal ticket was Ms Christine Bourne, also a staff member in the office of the member for Lindsay. But I shall return to Ms Bourne a little later.

At the close of nominations, it appeared there seemed to be a number of unusual links between the Liberal Party and those various single-issue micro parties. In the East Ward of the Penrith City Council elections, the ward in which Mr Simat and Ms Bourne were both running, three candidates all listed 15 Avon Place, St Clair, as their home address on their respective nomination forms.

Two of these candidates, Mr Paul Matosin and Mr Joe Matosin, were representing the Marijuana Smokers Rights Party. This on its own may not seem all that peculiar. However, it must be pointed out that a Mr Adam Brown, also contesting the election, had listed 15 Avon Place, St Clair, as his address on his application form. Interestingly, Mr Adam Brown was the leading candidate for the No Badgerys Creek Airport Party.

All these candidates appear to be guilty of committing electoral fraud, and both these partiesâthe Marijuana Smokers Rights Party and the No Badgerys Creek Airport Partyâappear to be Liberal Party `front parties'. Even though both these single issue parties seem to reflect views that are in direct opposition to the Liberal Party's platform, I will demonstrate that a connection does exist. Let me deal with the issue of electoral fraud first.

A brief visit to 15 Avon Place, St Clair, in the week following the lodgement of nomination forms showed no signs that the house was occupied. An absence of furniture seemed to indicate that no-one was currently living at the address. More interestingly, none of these three candidates were listed at 15 Avon Place, St Clair, on the previous month's electoral roll update. However, all three became enrolled at this address in the month immediately prior to the close of nominations. In the previous month, the Matosins were both listed as enrolled at 20 Herley Avenue, Rossmore. Rossmore is not in the Penrith City Council area.

It is instructive to consider who owns the property at 15 Avon Place, St Clair. A land titles search revealed that the property was co-owned by Ms Liliana Djuka and Mr Stan Celar. Mr Stan Celar appears to be the same Stan Celar that was running in the No. 2 position on the No Badgerys Creek Airport Party's East Ward ticket. The other co-owner of the Avon Place residence, Liliana Djuka, was the No. 4 candidate on the Liberal Party's ticket in East Ward. Not only was she a Liberal Party candidate but she also shares the same electoral enrolment address as Mr Steve Simat, the No. 1 Liberal candidate in East Ward. It has also been reported in the local papers that, when asked for the reasons why he ran in the election, Mr Stan Celar replied, `Because Steve Simat asked me to.'

There was, however, even more to the Liberal Party connection, with what clearly appears to have been a series of front parties designed to funnel preferences back to the Liberals. Both Mr Joe Matosin and Mr Paul Matosin from the Marijuana Smokers Rights Party appear on a print-out dated 11 August 1999 of the Rossmore branch of the Young Liberals, of which Mr Steve Simat was previously a member. Both Matosins are listed as living at 20 Herley Avenue, the Rossmore address at which they were enrolled up to the previous month and which, as I have said previously, is outside the Penrith City Council boundaries.

It leaves unanswered the question as to whether Adam Brown from the No Badgerys Creek Airport Party is in fact the same Adam Brown that has previously worked on the election campaigns for the member for Lindsay and is currently a member of the Willoughby Young Liberals. It is also interesting to make the point that both Steve Simat and Adam Brown are part of the same right wing faction within the Young Liberals, even though in different branches. It is also important to note that Steve Simat was elected to the council on the preferences of the No Badgerys Creek Airport Party.

Further strengthening the suggestion that the Liberal Party has taken control of, or perhaps even established, the No Badgerys Creek Airport Party, is the fact that Mr Al Mewett, the No. 2 Liberal candidate in Penrith's East Ward, ran as the No Badgerys Creek Airport candidate at the last state election for the seat of Mulgoa only six months ago. It is also worth noting that the registered officer of the No Badgerys Creek Airport Party is Mr John Barker, who, strangely enough, ran as a candidate for the Wilderness Party in the Blue Mountains council election. John Barker's brother, David Barker, however, was the No Badgerys Creek Airport Party candidate in the Blue Mountains and was previously the Liberal candidate in the state seat of Liverpool only six months ago.

A further coincidence was that Mr John Barker's Wilderness Party was also contesting the Penrith City Council elections. When doorknocked, the lead candidate for the Wilderness Party, Ms Ana Grguric, in Penrith's East Ward, was in Perth. Ana was not to be seen during the campaign, but her brother John was, as he was a booth captain for the Liberal Party handing out how-to-votes on election day.

Other dubious parties contending the East Ward election were the Seniors Party and the Gun Owners and Sporting Shooters/Hunters Rights Party. It is interesting to see that both the Marijuana Smokers Rights Party and the Seniors Party contested elections in two council areasâPenrith and Leichhardt. On the face of it, there does not seem to be any connection. However, it is worth noting that Ms Christine Bourne, a staffer working for the member for Lindsay, was previously a Leichhardt councillor after the 1995 election. Although Ms Bourne was unseated as a result of a dispute over the counting of the ballot which ultimately went to the High Court, I understand that Ms Bourne has recently been served with a notice of bankruptcy.

In all of this, it might seem reasonable to say that none of this could have happened without the member for Lindsay's knowledge. This seems unlikely, given the member for Lindsay's keen interest and active involvement in the campaign. After becoming the president of the local government conference, the member for Lindsay used her influence to roll the incumbent councillor, and a good councillor, Robin Wiles, in favour of her two staff members. In a letter sent out to the Liberal Party members on her parliamentary letterhead, the member for Lindsay wrote to branch members illustrating the importance of the elections, indicating that the campaign would become the focus of her activities over the four-week campaign period.

The most disturbing aspect of all of this is the opportunistic use of the highly emotive issue of the Badgerys Creek airport. The member for Lindsay, who says one thing in Canberra and another thing in Penrith, along with her staff, have sought to engineer a situation where they were to benefit from the community anger and resentment caused by an airport that her government remains committed to building. It is a shame, and it has damaged her credibility on the issue and her credibility as an honest broker who is committed to achieving the best for the people of her electorate. Sadly, this is not the end of it.

subdebateinfo.title: Local Government: New South Wales Elections
Council for Equal Opportunity in Employment

talk.start.para: âI had intended to speak about something else and I do hope that I get to the topic I wanted to speak about tonight. But before I do, I just wanted to say that it is very disappointing when a senator makes an intemperate attack in this house on another member of parliamentâit is expressly provided in the rules that it is inappropriate to do soâparticularly an attack on our colleague the honourable member for Lindsay, Jackie Kelly, who is a minister in the government, and two members of her staff, Steve Simat and Christine Bourne, and a number of other individuals who were apparently candidates at the recent local council elections in New South Wales.

speech.para: A number of very unfortunate imputations bearing on the credibility and integrity of another member of parliament have been made and in fact, by inference, criminal allegations have been suggested, namely, electoral fraud. I am not entirely sureâI will have to read what Senator Hutchins saidâwhether he is actually accusing the minister of electoral fraud or whether he is suggesting that she aided and abetted it through knowledge. I am not entirely sure exactly how he put it, but he makes a most serious allegation that will require to be dealt with in one way or another.

I am not entirely sure that it is not a breach of privilege in this place to have made the allegations in the way he has, to reflect on the character and intentions of another member. In any event, what Senator Hutchins did seem to be suggesting, on the flimsiest of evidence and on a mishmash of conclusions based upon creeping around and looking through open windows of houses to see whether there are signs of occupation, which is a pretty demeaning activity in the first place, proves really absolutely nothing and is a very unfortunate smear tactic that is entirely unworthy of Senator Hutchins. As I said, it may in fact be a misuse of privilege and it is a matter that ought to be looked at.

What I did want to say tonight was that election to this place does provide one with excellent opportunities to become involved in issues and organisations that are of great importance and significance in the wider community. The Council for Equal Opportunity in Employment is such an organisation that I have become involved with, being appointed as a director as the nominee of the Prime Minister. I want to make a few comments about this fine organisation.

The Council for Equal Opportunity in Employment was actually founded as long ago as 1985 by the Business Council of Australia and the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry. It is a business oriented employer organisation focusing on the elimination of discrimination and harassment, creating workplaces where differences are respected and valued and developing effective business oriented affirmative action strategies. The council provides information, skill development, training and comprehensive consulting and advisory services to member organisations and other clients in both the public and private sectors.

In my capacity as a member of the board, it was my pleasure last Wednesday to attend the Australian Financial Review/Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry 1999 Corporate Work and Family Awards luncheon. The awards were developed in 1992 in conjunction with the Council for Equal Opportunity in Employment to recognise organisations that have actually taken the initiative in providing a family friendly work environment for their employees. This year the awards were also cosponsored by the Work and Family Unit of the Department of Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business.

The Corporate Work and Family Awards recognise certain organisations and small businesses that have made their workplaces more family friendly. As Peter Reith stated in the address he delivered at the awards, `High turnover isn't good for businesses, and family friendly practices such as offering control over working hours in some form or other to low skilled employees is one sure way of helping to keep turnover levels low.'

Changes to industrial relations laws in 1996 have delivered employers the tools and the flexibility to actually make these sorts of changes. As Mr Reith stated, there is significant evidence that throughout the agreement making process available under the federal Workplace Relations Act 1996 plenty of workplaces are adopting family friendly practices. For example, a recent study by the Work and Family Unit showed that 67 per cent of certified agreements contained at least one family friendly provision, and that figure rises to 79 per cent for Australian workplace agreements.

A recent departmental report titled Work and family state of play reiterates the need for such family friendly provisions in legislation when it found that flexible working arrangements are significant in allowing employees job satisfaction to balance their work and family responsibilities and to have lower levels of stress. However, as the minister stressed, `There is still cultural change that needs to happen at many workplaces . . . employers and employees need to think more creatively about how to give all types of employees more control over working hours.'

Those organisations that received awards this year showed great initiative and forethought in establishing a work environment where the family unit was respected. Lawyers Blake Dawson and Waldron showed that flexible working hours are becoming the norm, while at Innovative People Solutions 30 per cent of its Sydney premises are devoted to a creche and employees have the option of an extra two weeks recreation leave a year to spend time with their families.

The awards gold medal winner, Mobil, has also effected massive organisational change. A culture of mistrust and excessive working hours has been altered to one of flexible work options where a family friendly culture is now embedded in the company. Restructuring of wage packages have seen decreases in overtime, yet increases in pay; and industrial action has decreased significantly. Writing about this in the Australian Financial Review, Stephen Long said:

Initiatives like these show that employers don't necessarily have to spend lots of money to promote work and family balance. Big improvements can come from simple things that many take for granted, such as giving people flexibility to alter start and finish times, or to take time off to attend a family or personal issue and make up time later.

These award winners, and the recognition of the changes they have made, show the dramatic nature of workplace changes that have occurred for women in the past decade and, in particular, since the government introduced its workplace relations legislation. Australia's award system was far too restrictive and rigid to provide the necessary conditions for flexible workplace practices. It is fair to say the Labor government missed out on the opportunity to introduce flexible working conditions with the introduction of the Industrial Relations Reform Act in 1993. As Mr Reith confirmed during his address, workplaces dominated by awards are not as likely to have family friendly practices. However, as is shown by the winners of these awards, flexible work sees benefits such as reduced absenteeism, decreased turnover, increased productivity and increases in morale.

Recent ABS figures have also shown the great benefits that inure to women from these changes. Women are enjoying a period of lower unemployment and higher employment opportunities. Choice in determining the level of labour force participation has become very important for women. Measures such as the soon to be implemented $24 million Return to Work program and the new tax system, which contains income tax cuts and increased child-care assistance, will assist women who choose paid work to make the most of their opportunities.

As the only non-profit business sponsored organisation working nationally in these areas, the Council for Equal Opportunity in Employment is uniquely placed to assist employers in meeting legal guidelines and identifying the likelihood that they might be predisposed to a claim. I take this opportunity to commend the winners of these awards as well as the council and to encourage other organisations across the country to bear in mind the value that a flexible, family friendly work environment can have for both them and their employees.

talk.start.para: âThis nation has an interest in achieving the efficient and effective management of the nation's forest resources. To this end, Queensland has finalised a regional forest agreement for south-east Queensland. I will provide some background on this. An RFA, a regional forest agreement, is an agreement about the long-term management and use of forests in a particular region between the Commonwealth and a state government. Its aim is to provide certainty, reduce duplication and provide a single plan for government decision making. The end result is to provide a durable agreement on the management and use of forests. The regional forest agreements are intended to provide the basis for both future forest management and an internationally competitive and ecologically sustainable forest products industry.

speech.para: Queensland has now completed an exhaustive process of consultation to come up with a regional forest agreement. I would like to congratulate the Queensland Labor Premier, Mr Peter Beattie, and the Deputy Premier, Mr Jim Elder, for the leadership shown throughout the process of negotiating the South-East Queensland Regional Forest Agreement. Negotiating an agreeable outcome between different interest groups is certainly not an easy task. It is a testament to the Queensland Labor government that this outcome has been achieved. The state government, the timber industry and the conservationists have all signed off on a historic agreement which provides a blueprint for the future management of our forests and the basis for an internationally competitive and environmentally sustainable forest industry.

The central elements of the plan are as follows. At least 350 extra jobs and an increase of 425,000 hectares in the amount of native forest protected from loggingâand this doubles the size of the existing conservation reserve. By the year 2025, more than one million hectares will not be available for logging. The plan also includes additional funding to manage the increased conservation reserve, 25 years guaranteed resource supply at current levels for all existing mills except for three mills, a $10 million incentive package to encourage new investment into the value adding side of the hardwood sector, 10 million new trees to be planted over the next five years as part of an $18 million softwood and hardwood plantation program and an end to all logging in native forests by the year 2025. These elements will ensure a sensible balance between conservation and the preservation of rural communities.

The Queensland government's plan for the South-East Queensland Regional Forest Agreement had the objectives of providing a comprehensive, adequate and representative environmental reserve system, ensuring the management of forests is on the basis of ecologically sustainable management, and facilitating the development of a competitive and efficient timber industry. The Queensland Labor government has succeeded in ensuring that these objectives were met and, most importantly, that there would be no net loss of jobs.

I have been on record a number of times defending the rights of timber workers to keep their jobs, and I would certainly not be supporting this agreement if it impacted adversely on employment within the timber industry. I had the opportunity of marching in Queensland with the timber industry in support of jobs. I had the opportunity of going to regional Queensland and speaking to various councils about the impact on the industry if the timber industry were to be wound down. However, this agreement not only ensures the security of current employees but will have a positive impact on employment, with over 400 new jobs proposed in a number of areas throughout the industry.

The Queensland Premier's promise of no net job losses is also a vindication of the Australian Workers Union's vigorous campaign to protect its members. Both the union and the industry have consistently maintained that the timber industry is capable of long-term sustainability, and this arrangement agrees with that assertion. The union's efforts have ensured the security of over 500 jobs and the creation of many more. Unlike the mess that has unfolded in Western Australia, the Queensland Labor government has used commonsense to ensure that all parties to the agreement have been listened to.

I call on the Howard government to abandon its confrontational approach to regional forest agreements and support the state Labor government's recommended agreement. Given that the relevant stakeholders in Queensland have overwhelmingly endorsed this agreement, the community rightly expects the government to come through with the money needed to ensure a successful outcome. I would urge this government to focus on the outcome rather than the technicalities of the issue. The agreement is within the spirit of the government's aimâthat is, to preserve jobs in timber towns and to preserve forests. The government should recognise the good faith shown by those involved in this process and ensure that the government backs this historic agreement.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: In response to the recommendations of the National Taskforce on Imported Fish and Fish Products, AQIS imposed restrictions on the importation of prawns not for human consumption and freshwater crayfish in November 1996. Short-term risk minimisation arrangements were not introduced for other aquatic products but import risk analyses were initiated with high priority.

As an interim measure, AQIS prohibited the importation of uncooked prawns, and prawn based products containing uncooked prawns, for purposes other than human consumption with effect from 11 November 1996. This restriction applies to all prawn species including marine, brackish and freshwater. A risk analysis on the importation of green prawns commenced in May 1997. A technical issues paper was released in November 1998. The draft report of the risk analysis will be released in November 1999.

Restrictions on freshwater crayfish also took effect on 11 November 1996. Importers of uncooked freshwater crayfish must obtain an import permit from AQIS prior to presenting product for quarantine entry. No permits have been granted since 1996. A risk analysis of freshwater crayfish commenced in September 1996 and a technical issues paper was released in May 1999. The draft report of the risk analysis paper will be released in February 2000.
The estimated cost of making arrangements for these two short term risk management measures is $35,000, comprising 0.3 staff (full time equivalent) and administrative costs.
With respect to the risk analyses commenced on other categories of imports, the status is as follows:

. The import risk analysis on ornamental fish was finalised on 19 July 1999, when AQIS announced its decision to strengthen quarantine controls. Under new policies, all fish must have official health certification and must undergo post-arrival quarantine of up to three weeks and meet new inspection and testing conditions.

. The import risk analysis on non-viable marine finfish (including fresh frozen aquatic animal feeds and baits and whole fish for human consumption) was finalised on 19 July 1999, when AQIS announced its decision to introduce requirements that imported marine finfish products (eg herring, cod, halibut, hake, bass, and sea bream) be `head off', eviscerated (gutted) and processed in approved plants or treated in a way that provides an equivalent level of protection.
. The import risk analysis on non-viable bivalve molluscs commenced in April 1998. This IRA is presently on hold with resources re-directed to higher priority import risk analyses under WTO deadline.

entry.para: Ornamental finfish24 November 1997; 7 and 8 April 1998; 27 January 1999.
Fresh water crayfish products3 December 1998; 12 February 1999.
Prawns and prawn products25 November 1997; 24â25 March 1998; 27â28 August 1998.
Non-viable bivalve molluscsPanel is yet to meet.

answer.para: (10) (a) Technical Issues Papers were released for ornamental finfish (8 March 1999), freshwater crayfish products (17 May 1999) and prawns and prawn products (14 November 1998).
(b) A copy of each of these reports has been provided to Senator O'Brien.

(12) In all cases, stakeholder comments are provided to Risk Analysis Panels. Draft import risk analysis reports are in preparation for risk analyses on freshwater crayfish and prawns and prawn products. Under the accelerated process announced by the Executive Director of AQIS on 23 April 1999, the draft import risk analysis reports on ornamental finfish and non-viable marine finfish were placed on the AQIS website for public comment during June and July 1999 and stakeholder submissions were taken into account in finalising the import risk analyses. Copies of the reports are available from AQIS's website (http://www.aqis.gov.au/import/index.htm). The WTO was notified of AQIS's decision of 19 July 1999 on these import risk analyses.

(13) AQIS conducted the import risk analyses for ornamental finfish and non-viable marine finfish using an accelerated process. Stakeholders' comments were reviewed by AQIS and a number of independent scientific experts. AQIS's decision was announced on 19 July 1999.

(14) An import risk analysis is not finalised until a determination has been made by the Executive Director of AQIS. The recommendations of the risk analysis panel on ornamental finfish and non-viable marine finfish were considered by AQIS's Executive Director who announced new policies on 19 July 1999 in respect of imports of these aquatic products.

(15) A period of 30 days is normally provided for stakeholders to appeal the process followed. There was no provision for stakeholders to appeal the decision on importation of ornamental finfish and non-viable marine finfish because these import risk analyses were conducted under an accelerated process to meet a deadline set by the WTO.
(17) (a) On average, 2 full time equivalent AQIS specialist staff are engaged on each import risk analysis. (b) The estimated cost for each assessment is $300,000.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged Care, upon notice, on 15 July 1999:

question.para: With reference to the answer to question no. 181 placed on notice at the Community Affair's Legislation Committee estimates hearing on 1 June 1999.
(1) What population figures are used to make the specific calculations with regard to aged care provision ratios.
(2) (a) How frequently is the demographic data reviewed; and (b) what is the source of the demographic data.
(3) What local government areas comprise the Aged Care Planning Region of Central West in New South Wales.
(4) What are the actual number of places currently provided in the region on a local government by local government basis.
(5) What are the forward projections of the needs of the region: (a) as a whole; and (b) on a local government by local government basis.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator Herron
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Aged Care has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The calculation of aged care provision ratios is done using figures on the number of people aged 70 and over in each Aged Care Planning Region. These are derived from Estimated Residential Populations by age by Statistical Local Area provided by the Australian Bureau of Statistics.

(2) (a) Demographic data on the aged population and the provision of services are reviewed annually during preparation of the Regional Distribution Plan that determines where new places are to be advertised.

(b) Data on the aged population is obtained from the ABS. Data on Federally funded aged care places is obtained from the computer payments system operated by the Department of Health and Aged Care. Data on services provided by other levels of government is obtained from the appropriate jurisdictions.
(3) and (4) The following table shows the Statistical Local Areas (SLAs) in the Aged Care Planning Region of Central West and the current provision of residential and community places.
Current provision of residential and community care places

It should be noted that Statistical Local Areas (SLAs) are used for planning purposes. However, in some instances Local Government Areas (LGAs) are used (for example, when all SLA's in an LGA are targeted for new places).

(5) (a) and (b) The Department determines the allocation of places in the course of a round in accordance with the ratio set out below. The Department also receives advice from Planning Committees in each State and Territory on priority needs.

The region of Central West as a whole is currently over the target ratio of 90 places per 1000 people aged 70+ for residential care places, and under the ratio 10 places per 1000 people aged 70+ for community care places. Community care places were made available in Central West in the recent Aged Care Approvals Round which will bring it closer to the benchmark.
The current provision of aged care places indicates that the area is provided with more places on a 70+ population basis than other areas of New South Wales.
The former Hawke/Keating governments left the Australian community 10,000 aged care places short. They did not meet their own publicly established benchmarks.

The Coalition is fixing this and has substantially increased funding to the residential aged care sector. Since the Howard Government was elected in 1996 funding has increased by 42 per cent to $3.5 billion.

subdebateinfo.title: Aviation: Air Traffic Control Australian Advanced Air Traffic System
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1243)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 12 August 1999:

question.para: (1) Did the Air Traffic Control Australian Advanced Air Traffic System (TAAATS) Voice Switching Computer System (VSCS) fail at Melbourne Airport on 2 August 1999.
(2) Was the VSCS down from 11 pm on 2 August 1999 until 4 am on 3 August 1999.

(3) Did this failure result in such phenomena as radio broadcasts from aircraft being routed to the wrong air traffic control consoles and air traffic controllers being unable to coordinate with each other.
(4) (a) Does the VSCS have an emergency standby system; and (b) did that emergency system fail because of flat batteries.
(5) Between 11 pm on 2 August 1999 and 4 am on 3 August 1999 was air traffic control at Melbourne Airport provided on an emergency basis from the control tower rather than the control centre.

(6) On how many occasions, and at which airports, has air traffic control been provided on an emergency basis from the control tower rather than the control centre since Airservices Australia was established.

(7) (a) Between 11 pm on 2 August 1999 and 4 am on 3 August 1999 was enroute control unavailable at Melbourne Airport; and (b) if some enroute control was available during this period, what limits were there on that service.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: Airservices has advised:
(1) Yes. There was a partial failure of the VSCS system on 2 August, 1999.
(2) No. Some elements of the system were not affected and the VSCS was progressively restored to full functionality over this period.

(3) No. Some broadcasts were duplicated to other console positions but the responsible controller received correct radio reception and the coordination functions were able to be carried out between controllers in the normal manner.

(4) (a) Yes. A handset which bypasses the VSCS, is provided at each console position which allows the air traffic controller direct access to the predesignated radio frequency. However, on 2 August 1999 the VSCS bypass was not effective at a small percentage of console positions due to an interface problem between the VSCS bypass and external radio equipment. This problem has now been corrected.
(b) No.
(5) As part of normal contingency plans the control tower provided an approach control service in consultation with the control centre.

(6) Airservices management advises that it can not recollect any similar occasions when contingency plans have been utilised to provide such services from a tower. A more definitive answer would require a search to be undertaken of tower log records over a four year period at all major air traffic control centres.

(b) Enroute services were provided to aircraft throughout the evening. Two inbound aircraft were delayed slightly and two aircraft were held on the ground at Melbourne for a few minutes at the onset of the problem with the VSCS.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 24 August 1999:

question.para: (1) What were the circumstances surrounding the failure of the department to notify the Australian Federal Police (AFP) of the granting of a new Australian passport to Ms Lisa Marie Smith until 6 months after it was issued on 10 September 1996.

(2) Did the department contact Interpol or the Government of Thailand following the granting of the new passport; if so, when did they contact Interpol and/or the Government of Thailand; if not, why not.
(3) (a) When was the application for a new passport for Ms Smith received by the Australian Embassy in Athens; and (b) When was the new passport granted.
(4) When did the department receive the passenger alert for Ms Smith issued by the AFP.
(5) What action did the department take upon becoming aware of the passenger alert issued for Ms Smith.
(6) When did the department first become aware that the Australian Embassy in Athens had granted a new passport to Ms Smith.
(7) What legislative impediments exist that effect the flow of information between government agencies in cases such as that of Ms Smith.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator Hill
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's questions:

answer.para: (1) The Department is only required to contact or notify those authorities who place alerts on the Department's Passport Issue and Control System when the Australian citizen, who is the subject of an alert, makes application for an Australian passport. There was no alert in place for Ms Smith at the time she applied for and was granted an Australian passport.

(2) The Department did not advise Interpol or the Government of Thailand about Ms Smith's passport issue. There is no agreement in force with Thailand to advise on these matters nor is there any formal requirement for the Department to notify the AFP or other agencies of passport issues to Australian citizens. The AFP and other agencies have access to information held on the Department's Passport Issue and Control System.

(3) (a) Ms Smith lodged her passport application with the Australian Embassy in Athens on 30 August 1996; and (b) Ms Smith's passport was authorised for issue on 9 September 1996 and issued on 10 September 1996.
(4) The Department does not receive passenger alerts issued by the AFP.
(5) The Department was not aware of the passenger alert issued by the AFP.

(6) The Department first became aware of Ms Smith being issued with a passport when the issue was recorded on the Department's Passport Issue and Control System by the Australian Embassy in Athens on 10 September 1996.
(7) Apart from the Privacy Act, there are no legislative impediments to effect the transfer of information between Government agencies in these cases.
